sentence.662: Winnti Group: Geostrategic and TTP (Tactics, Techniques and Procedures)
sentence.663: China is one of the world powers with more presence within the international market of the gaming sector, controlling the Southeast Asian market and even more than half of the global market of the Gaming sector.
sentence.664: Winnti Group is currently considered to be an APT group allegedly attributed to the government of China ([1]).
sentence.665: **Geostrategic analysis of China and Winnti Group’s cyber attacks on Thailand’s gaming industry:**
sentence.666: The increase in cyber-attacks within Southeast Asian countries is correlating with the progressive shift in the accumulation of the Gross Domestic Product towards the same area of Southeast Asia.
sentence.669: As the percentages on the map show, the evolution of the global distribution of GDP will be concentrated in the countries of Southeast Asia.
sentence.670: Innovations within the IT sector are and will continue to be highly confidential information for those companies and States that maintain an interest in economic control over the Southeast Asian area ([3]).
sentence.671: The countries of Southeast Asia have acquired significant relevance in relation to their design and subsequent production.
sentence.674: The group of countries in the Asia-Pacific region has generated up to $71.4 billion, more than half of which has been generated by China ($37 Bn), surpassing the annual profits of the US within the “gaming” sector ([5 ]).
sentence.675: In Southeast Asia, China controls 64% of sales related to the “Gaming” sector.
sentence.676: Its main regional competitor is Japan and South Korea.
sentence.677: Supposedly, the Chinese government, with the intention of maintaining growth and control within the international “gaming” market, has been attributed links with the activity of the APT Winnti Group.
sentence.678: The ESET company has published an investigation about a Winnti Group campaign where the company “Thai developer Electronics Extreme” was cyber-attacked and could have distributed infected versions of its product called “Infestation Gameplay”.
sentence.679: As the following graph shows, it can be seen that the highest percentage of infected products have been distributed in Thailand.

sentence.682: *Illustration 4 Countries most infected by the Winnti Group campaign*

sentence.685: The vast majority of companies in Thailand’s gaming sector are SMEs with Thai capital.
sentence.686: However, these same companies usually work with international organizations such as Nintendo or Xbox, among others.
sentence.687: Another feature of high value within the gaming market in Thailand are the companies focused on the behavioral study of videogame consumers, such as “Asiasoft”.

sentence.718: Leviathan: Geostrategy and TTP (Tactics, Techniques and Procedures)
sentence.719: FireEye posted a relevant report regarding one of the most active threat groups; Leviathan, also known as TEMP, Periscope or TEMP. Jumper.
sentence.720: This APT is supposedly attributed to the Chinese government ([1]).
sentence.721: China is the main supplier of Europe in several products.
sentence.722: Approximately since 2009, China has aimed to build up a maritime route known as OBOR (One Belt, One Road).
sentence.723: The main goal of this project is to develop a safe trading corridor to export Chinese products to all European countries in a fluid way with lower international tax.
sentence.724: However, the geostrategic trouble begins in the South Chinese Sea as there are many bordering countries which are trying to control the area by carrying out military operations with their navy forces.
sentence.725: Presumably, to afford the conflict China has designed a strategic plan to quickly develop its navy to become one of the most important in the world.
sentence.726: Leviathan has carried out several cyberattacks against the following countries: Cambodia, Belgium, Germany, Hong Kong, Phillipine Islands, Malaysia, Norway, Saudi Arabia, Switzerland and the United States.
sentence.727: The fields of the organizations which have been cyber attacked by Leviathan belong to the logistic, engineering, naval technology and naval defense industry ([1]).

sentence.732: The main diplomatic conflicts in the OBOR route are among United States, Malaysia, Taiwan, Vietnam, Japan, Indonesia and the Philippine Islands ([12]).

sentence.737: The relation among the States involved in this geostrategic conflict in the Chinese Sea and the organizations that have been targeted by APT 40 is highly strong.

sentence.1150: On 30 March 2021, the United States Internal Revenue Service (IRS) [issued](https://www.irs.gov/newsroom/irs-warns-university-students-and-staff-of-impersonation-email-scam) a security alert detailing an ongoing email-based IRS impersonation campaign primarily targeting educational institutions.

sentence.1152: What makes 2021 unique are the continuing and unprecedented pandemic, healthcare, and financial crises that these threat actors are combining with typical tax lures in the ongoing campaigns Proofpoint observed.
sentence.1153: Proofpoint observed over 30 tax-themed malicious email campaigns totaling over 800,000 email messages so far in 2021.
sentence.1154: Proofpoint also observed multiple campaigns aligned with [business email compromise](https://www.proofpoint.com/us/threat-reference/business-email-compromise) activities.
sentence.1155: So far in 2021, Proofpoint identified over 30 discrete campaigns targeting thousands of people from multiple threat actors that leveraged malicious email lures associated with taxes, tax and refund support, and government revenue entities.
sentence.1156: At least four threat actor groups tracked by Proofpoint have leveraged tax-themed malicious email campaigns.
sentence.1157: Credential theft phishing attempts – which can be used to target individuals or leveraged for email account takeovers – accounted for 40% of the tax-themed email campaigns, followed by remote access trojan ([RAT](https://www.proofpoint.com/us/threat-insight/post/threat-insight-2019-review-year-rat)) campaigns at 17%.
sentence.1158: However, despite RATs featuring in fewer campaigns, they were far more popular in total message volume.
sentence.1159: Half of identified tax-themed and related messages containing [malware](https://www.proofpoint.com/us/threat-reference/malware) were used to distribute the Remcos RAT, a commodity malware with extensive data theft and surveillance capabilities.
sentence.1160: Other broad tax-themed malware distribution campaigns included Dridex, TrickBot, and ZLoader.
sentence.1161: Over the course of 2020, threat actors began [increasingly](https://www.csoonline.com/article/3597913/why-excel-4-0-macro-exploits-are-surging.html) leveraging Excel 4.0 (XL4) macros to distribute malware, and this trend has continued in 2021.
sentence.1162: Proofpoint observed a 500% increase in tax-themed email threat campaigns delivering weaponized XL4 Macros in the first three months of 2021.
sentence.1163: Proofpoint assesses this is due to limited detection coverage in modern security systems.
sentence.1164: (Although Microsoft still supports XL4 macros, the company [suggests](https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/working-with-excel-4-0-macros-ba8924d4-e157-4bb2-8d76-2c07ff02e0b8) migrating them to the latest version of Microsoft Visual Basic Application.
sentence.1166: One of the most prolific IRS-themed malware campaigns leveraged IRS tax credit distribution for employee retention lures benefiting employers impacted by COVID-19.
sentence.1167: It distributed the TrickBot banking trojan.
sentence.1168: TrickBot is designed to steal banking information and acts as an initial payload for additional malware, gaining notoriety in 2018 for distributing Ryuk ransomware which [reportedly](https://www.securitymagazine.com/articles/93769-ryuk-ransomware-responsible-for-one-third-of-all-ransomware-attacks-in-2020) accounted for a third of [ransomware](https://www.proofpoint.com/us/threat-reference/ransomware) distributed by many actors across the threat landscape in 2020.

sentence.1170: Unlike typically observed activity, this TrickBot campaign distributed malicious Excel files leveraging the XLSB filetype, a lightweight file format that can only be opened in Excel.
sentence.1171: Proofpoint assesses with moderate confidence the threat actor leveraged this document format as it is less likely to be detected by anti-virus systems.

sentence.1200: New Variant of Buer Loader Written in Rust
sentence.1201: Proofpoint researchers identified a new variant of the Buer malware loader distributed via emails masquerading as shipping notices in early April.
sentence.1202: [Buer](https://malpedia.caad.fkie.fraunhofer.de/details/win.buer) is a downloader sold on underground marketplaces that is used as a foothold in compromised networks to distribute other malware, [including ransomware](https://www.cert.ssi.gouv.fr/uploads/CERTFR-2021-CTI-006.pdf).
sentence.1204: In the associated campaigns, the emails purported to be from DHL Support.
sentence.1205: They contained a link to a malicious Microsoft Word or Excel document download that used macros to drop the new malware variant.
sentence.1206: Proofpoint is calling this new variant RustyBuer.
sentence.1207: It is unusual to see common malware written in a completely different way.
sentence.1208: * The new Buer variant is written in Rust, an efficient and easy-to-use programming language that is becoming increasingly popular.
sentence.1209: Proofpoint is calling this variant RustyBuer.
sentence.1210: * Rewriting the malware in Rust enables the threat actor to better evade existing Buer detection capabilities.
sentence.1211: * Proofpoint observed RustyBuer campaigns delivering Cobalt Strike Beacon as a second-stage payload in some campaigns.
sentence.1212: * Researchers assess some threat actors may be establishing a foothold with the Buer loader to then sell access to other threat actors.
sentence.1213: Proofpoint analysts observed a series of malicious campaigns that delivered the Buer malware loader.
sentence.1214: The campaigns generally used DHL-themed phishing emails to distribute malicious Word or Excel documents.
sentence.1215: While sharing similar email lure themes, the campaigns distributed two distinct variants of the Buer malware: one was written in C while the other was rewritten in the Rust programming language.
sentence.1217: The campaigns also used different lure techniques, with RustyBuer attachments containing more detailed content to better engage the recipient.
sentence.1218: The rewritten malware, and the use of newer lures attempting to appear more legitimate, suggest threat actors leveraging RustyBuer are evolving techniques in multiple ways to both evade detection and attempt to increase successful click rates.
sentence.1219: Figure 1: Emails masquerading as DHL shipping themes used to distribute RustyBuer and Buer loaders.
sentence.1220: Figure 2: Malicious Excel attachment distributing RustyBuer containing multiple security software brand logos in an attempt to add legitimacy to the document.
sentence.1221: RustyBuer was embedded directly into the document macro and required user interaction to initiate the infection.
sentence.1222: This macro leveraged an Application Bypass (Windows Shell DLL via [LOLBAS](https://lolbas-project.github.io/lolbas/Libraries/Shell32/)) to evade detection from endpoint security mechanisms.
sentence.1223: Once RustyBuer is dropped, it establishes persistence by using a shortcut (.LNK) file which runs at startup.
sentence.1224: Both the Rust and C versions of the malware followed this same pattern including:
sentence.1225: Proofpoint researchers observed RustyBuer distributing Cobalt Strike Beacon as a second-stage payload in some instances, like previous Buer campaigns.
sentence.1226: Cobalt Strike is a legitimate security tool used by penetration testers to emulate adversary activity in a network that is becoming increasingly popular as a tool for threat actors.
sentence.1227: However, not all identified campaigns contained a second-stage payload.
sentence.1228: These threat actors may be attempting to establish initial access in victim environments to then sell their access to other threat actors in underground marketplaces.
sentence.1229: Other security firms have [documented this behavior](https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2020/10/28/hacks-for-sale-inside-the-buer-loader-malware-as-a-service/) from threat actors using Buer loader previously.
sentence.1231: Proofpoint classified the new variant of Buer (RustyBuer) as a rewritten version in Rust based on present anti-analysis features, strings, and encoding and format of the command and control (C2) requests.
sentence.1232: It is unclear why the threat actors took the time and effort to rewrite the malware in a new programming language, however Proofpoint researchers identify two likely reasons:
sentence.1233: 1. Rust is an increasingly popular programming language that is more efficient and has a broader feature set than C. (Microsoft, for example, is [increasingly](https://www.zdnet.com/article/microsoft-why-we-used-programming-language-rust-over-go-for-webassembly-on-kubernetes-app/) using it in its products and [joined](https://cloudblogs.microsoft.com/opensource/2021/02/08/microsoft-joins-rust-foundation/) the Rust Foundation in February 2021.
sentence.1234: 2. Rewriting the malware in Rust can enable the threat actor to evade existing Buer detections that are based on features of the malware written in C.
sentence.1235: The malware authors have programmed it in a way that it should maintain compatibility with existing Buer backend C2 servers and panels.
sentence.1236: * Checks locale to make sure the malware is not running in specific countries (Figure 8).
sentence.1237: These countries appear to be a part of the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS).
sentence.1238: The C2 requests are nearly identical to the requests used in the latest version of Buer.
sentence.1239: The C2 functions are handled via HTTP(S) POST requests.
sentence.1240: The POST request contains both pseudorandom characters and encrypted information about the compromised system.
sentence.1242: Figure 7: Buer Loader initial POST request
sentence.1243: 3. RC4 decryption (the key used in the analyzed samples was “kpM5WOtfo”)
sentence.1244: As with Buer, the JSON object returned in the beacon response contains various options on how to download and execute a payload:
sentence.1245: * options - specifies options for the payload to download:
sentence.1247: + AccessToken - used to download the payload
sentence.1248: + External - indicates whether the payload is downloaded from the C&C or an external URL
sentence.1249: * autorun - indicates whether to setup Registry RunOnce persistence for the payload
sentence.1250: Despite existing since 2019, the new variant of Buer loader malware suggests threat actors continue to modify their payloads in a likely attempt to evade detection.
sentence.1251: When paired with the attempts by threat actors leveraging RustyBuer to further legitimize their lures, it is possible the attack chain may be more effective in obtaining access and persistence.
sentence.1252: RustyBuer and the original Buer loader have been observed as a first-stage loader for additional payloads including Cobalt Strike and multiple ransomware strains, as well as possibly providing victim access to other threat actors in the underground marketplace.
sentence.1253: Proofpoint anticipates this activity will continue.
sentence.1254: Based on the frequency of RustyBuer campaigns observed by Proofpoint, researchers anticipate we will continue to see the new variant in the future.

sentence.1273: In one of Proofpoint’s more recently observed supplier invoice fraud attacks, a threat actor attempted to steal over $100,000 in payment.

sentence.1276: Security Brief: Threat Actors Exploit Microsoft and Google Platforms to Host and Send Millions of Malicious Messages
sentence.1277: In recent months we have observed an acceleration in threat actors abusing Microsoft and Google’s popular infrastructure to host and send threats across Office 365, Azure, OneDrive, SharePoint, G-Suite, and Firebase storage.
sentence.1278: Last year, 59,809,708 malicious messages from Microsoft Office 365 targeted thousands of our customers.
sentence.1279: And more than 90 million malicious messages were sent or hosted by Google, with 27% sent through Gmail, the world’s most popular email platform.
sentence.1280: In Q1 2021, we observed seven million malicious messages from Microsoft Office 365 and 45 million malicious messages from Google infrastructure, which far exceed per quarter Google-based attacks in 2020.
sentence.1281: The malicious message volume from these trusted cloud services exceeded that of any [botnet](https://www.proofpoint.com/us/threat-reference/ddos) in 2020, and the trusted reputation of these domains, including outlook.com and sharepoint.com, increases the difficulty of detection for defenders.
sentence.1282: This authenticity perception is essential, as email recently regained its status as the top vector for [ransomware](https://www.coveware.com/blog/ransomware-marketplace-report-q4-2020) and threat actors increasingly leverage the supply chain and partner ecosystem to compromise accounts, steal credentials, and siphon funds.
sentence.1283: We recently released [supply chain findings](https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/email-and-cloud-threats/98-organizations-received-email-threats-suppliers-what-you-should-know) that 98% of nearly 3,000 monitored organizations across the U.S., UK, and Australia, received a threat from a supplier domain over a 7-day window in February 2021.
sentence.1285: Below is a round-up of recent [phishing](https://www.proofpoint.com/us/threat-reference/phishing) campaigns that demonstrate how threat actors use both Microsoft and Google when trying to convince users to act.
sentence.1286: For example, the following credential phishing attempt features a Microsoft SharePoint URL claiming to host a corporate policy and COVID-19 guidelines document.
sentence.1287: The document contains a link leading to a fake Microsoft authentication page designed to harvest user credentials.
sentence.1288: An additional example of a recent fake video conferencing credential phishing campaign featured the “.onmicrosoft.com” domain name.
sentence.1289: The messages contain a URL which leads to a fake webmail authentication page designed to harvest user credentials.
sentence.1290: A March 2021 Gmail-hosted campaign featured a fake employee benefits message and Microsoft Excel attachment targeting manufacturing, technology, and media/entertainment organizations.
sentence.1291: If macros are enabled, it will install and run The Trick, a trojan that intercepts and logs banking website visits to steal credentials.
sentence.1292: In February 2021, we also observed a very low volume Xorist ransomware campaign from a Gmail-hosted email address.
sentence.1293: It attempts to trick accounting recipients into access password-protected zipped MS Word documents.
sentence.1294: These documents contain macros which, if enabled, drop the ransomware.
sentence.1295: Our research clearly demonstrates that attackers are using both Microsoft and Google infrastructure to disseminate malicious messages and target people as they leverage popular cloud collaboration tools.
sentence.1296: When coupled with heightened ransomware, supply chain, and cloud account compromise, advanced people-centric email protection must remain a top priority for security leaders.

sentence.1309: 1. BazaLoader affiliates continue to use elaborate infection chains requiring significant victim interaction to distribute BazaLoader malware.
sentence.1310: 2. Emails directed the victim to call a customer service line which sent them to a website containing malicious content.
sentence.1311: Proofpoint researchers identified a BazaLoader campaign requiring significant human interaction to execute and install the BazaLoader backdoor.
sentence.1312: The threat actor leveraged phone-based customer service representatives to direct victims to unknowingly download and install the [malware](https://www.proofpoint.com/us/threat-reference/malware).
sentence.1313: This campaign is representative of a broader trend leveraged by the BazaLoader threat actors using call centers as part of an intricate attack chain.
sentence.1314: BazaLoader is a downloader written in C++ that is used to download and execute additional modules.
sentence.1315: Proofpoint first observed BazaLoader in April 2020.
sentence.1316: It is currently used by multiple threat actors and frequently serves as a loader for disruptive malware including [Ryuk](https://www.proofpoint.com/us/resources/webinars/what-healthcare-industry-should-know-about-ryuk-ransomware) and Conti [ransomware](https://www.proofpoint.com/us/threat-reference/ransomware).
sentence.1317: Proofpoint assesses with high confidence there is a strong overlap between the distribution and post-exploitation activity of BazaLoader and threat actors behind The Trick malware, also known as Trickbot.
sentence.1318: In the recent BazaLoader campaign, messages purport to be from various senders with subjects such as:
sentence.1319: *Figure 1: Initial BazaLoader email masquerading as an entertainment streaming service*
sentence.1320: When the user visits the site mentioned, navigates to the Frequently Asked Questions component of the website, and follows the directions to unsubscribe via the “Subscribtion” page, they will be directed to the download of an Excel Sheet.
sentence.1321: The Excel sheet contains macros that, if enabled, will download BazaLoader.
sentence.1323: At this time, Proofpoint has not observed the second-stage payload in this campaign.

sentence.1325: Proofpoint has [previously observed](https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/baza-valentines-day) BazaLoader email threat campaigns requiring significant human interaction in order to execute the malware.

sentence.1327: By leveraging attack chains that require a lot of human interaction, threat actors can bypass some automated threat detection services that only flag on malicious links or attachments in email.
sentence.1328: Proofpoint anticipates the threat actors behind BazaLoader and The Trick will continue to use these techniques in future campaigns.

sentence.1335: Ransom DDoS Extortion Actor “Fancy Lazarus” Returns
sentence.1336: * The ransom distributed denial of service extortion threat actor known as "Fancy Lazarus" is back, taking aim at an increasing number of industries, including the energy, financial, insurance, manufacturing, public utilities, and retail sectors.
sentence.1337: * There is no known connection between this group and the APT actors with the same names.
sentence.1338: * These latest campaigns have some differences to previous campaigns, including a change to the group's name, the amount of Bitcoin being ransomed, and variations in the email body content.
sentence.1339: As of May 12, 2021, Proofpoint researchers are tracking renewed distributed denial of service (DDoS) extortion activity targeting an increasing number of industries, including the energy, financial, insurance, manufacturing, public utilities, and retail by the threat actor “Fancy Lazarus.
sentence.1340: Proofpoint researchers have observed the activity primarily at U.S. companies or those with a global footprint.
sentence.1341: * New name: The group, who have previously identified themselves as “Fancy Bear”, “Lazarus,” “Lazarus Group,” and “Armada Collective,” among others, is now going by “Fancy Lazarus.
sentence.1342: There is no known connection between this group and the APT actors with the same names.
sentence.1343: * New price: The extortion emails now have adjusted ransom pricing, lowering it from ransoms as high as ten Bitcoin (BTC) to its current two BTC starting price.
sentence.1344: This change is likely to account for Bitcoin’s fluctuating value.
sentence.1345: In mid-to-late August 2020, [Akamai](https://blogs.akamai.com/sitr/2020/08/ransom-demands-return-new-ddos-extortion-threats-from-old-actors-targeting-finance-and-retail.html) and the U.S. Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) [alerted](https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/7070798-FLASH-MU-000132-DD.html) organizations to a spate of ransom denial-of-service extortion emails from this group.
sentence.1346: In each case the threat actor demanded Bitcoin payment or else a small-scale denial-of-service attack would be launched with a more substantial attack mere days later.
sentence.1347: They then threaten a DDoS attack in seven days, and, to prove it is not a hoax, mention a "small attack" that will be launched on a specific IP, subnet, or Autonomous System.
sentence.1348: Example of current emails being sent by “Fancy Lazarus.
sentence.1349: Previously the sender often contained “Fancy Bear,” "F.B.,” "Armada Collective,” "A.C.,” "Lazarus,” or "Lazarus Group," and even at times included the targeted company’s highest-ranking person such as the CEO’s name.
sentence.1350: Proofpoint has observed ransom demands of two BTC, which roughly equated to $76,000 USD on May 26, 2021.
sentence.1351: The Bitcoin addresses are unique to each potential target.
sentence.1352: While Proofpoint does not have visibility into the actual “Fancy Lazarus” DDoS attacks and whether they are carried out, FBI [reporting](https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/7070798-FLASH-MU-000132-DD.html) indicates that many affected companies that pass the threatened deadline either do not see any additional activity or the activity is successfully mitigated.
sentence.1353: A recent [report](https://blogs.akamai.com/2021/06/the-rapid-resurgence-of-ddos-extortion-that-didnt-take-long.html "https://blogs.akamai.com/2021/06/the-rapid-resurgence-of-ddos-extortion-that-didnt-take-long.html") by Akamai also notes a resurgence of this activity since May 2021 and provides a great amount of details and examples on the specific nature of the DDoS traffic.

sentence.1377: Ransomware Insights from Proofpoint’s Senior Director of  Threat Research and Detection, Sherrod DeGrippo
sentence.1378: While email has historically been the undisputed champion of [ransomware](https://www.proofpoint.com/us/threat-reference/ransomware) attack vectors, its role has undergone a major transformation.
sentence.1379: Sherrod DeGrippo explains the changing landscape as she’s seen it from her perch as Proofpoint’s Senior Director, Threat Research and Detection.
sentence.1380: Ransomware was once sent to users directly, usually in an email attachment.
sentence.1381: These direct or “[first stage](https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/first-step-initial-access-leads-ransomware)” attacks peaked in 2017 during the [Locky ransomware](/us/threat-insight/post/dridex-actors-get-in-ransomware-with-locky "Locky Ransomware Is Becoming More Sophisticated - Cybercriminals Continue Email Campaign Innovation") outbreak.
sentence.1382: As DeGrippo tells Dark Reading: “Many IT and information security teams in corporate settings were able to quickly adapt to the handling of a ransomware incident on a single laptop or host, treating it in some ways as stolen hardware and simply reformatting and moving on.
sentence.1383: That began changing in 2018 as [ransomware attackers](/us/security-awareness/post/ransomware-roundup-march-2018 "Ransomware Roundup: March 2018") increasingly leveraged cybercriminal organizations – mostly banking trojan distributors – to install “access facilitators.
sentence.1384: Instead of directly launching a ransomware attack, malicious links and attachments within the email quietly download backdoor trojans unbeknownst to users.
sentence.1385: Some attackers maintain the access and sell it, some cover their tracks toremove traces of their presence.
sentence.1386: “Threat actors moved to downloaders as a first stage to give themselves more choice and flexibility,” she continues.
sentence.1387: While direct ransomware attacks are not extinct, they’re getting there.
sentence.1388: In fact, only one strain accounted for 95 percent direct, first-stage ransomware attacks in the first half of 2021.
sentence.1389: ### That Was Then, This is Now These days, banking trojans – often used as ransomware loaders –are the runaway favorite among malware distributors.
sentence.1390: According to DeGrippo, banking trojans accounted for almost 20 percent of malware her researchers observed in identified campaigns.
sentence.1391: Banking trojans are also the most popular type of malware in the overall threat landscape observed by Proofpoint.
sentence.1392: Compounding the problem, criminal groups already distributing banking trojans can join ransomware “affiliate networks” to further their reach.
sentence.1393: Proofpoint currently tracks 10 threat actors acting as initial access facilitators or likely ransomware affiliates.
sentence.1394: Prior to its takedown in 2020, the [Emotet botnet](/us/threat-insight/post/proofpoint-q1-2019-threat-report-emotet-carries-quarter-consistent-high-volume "Proofpoint Q1 2019 Threat Report: Emotet carries the quarter with consistent high-volume campaigns") was one of the most prolific ransomware distributors between 2018 and 2020.
sentence.1395: Since Emotet’s disruption, DeGrippo’s team has tracked a myriad of other malware such as The Trick, Dridex, Qbot, IcedID, ZLoader, Ursnif, serving as first-stage malware payloads in attempts to enable further infections.
sentence.1396: Proofpoint researchers have also tracked downloaders like Buer Loader and [BazaLoader](/us/blog/threat-insight/bazaflix-bazaloader-fakes-movie-streaming-service "BazaFlix: BazaLoader Fakes Movie Streaming Service ") which often serve as an initial attack vector for ransomware.
sentence.1397: Over the last six months, Proofpoint has seen almost 300 downloader campaigns distributing nearly six million malicious messages.
sentence.1398: The article notes that ransomware is not the only second stage payload associated with the above malware and downloaders, and that ransomware purveyors do use other attack methods to distribute their product.
sentence.1399: In other words, ransomware isn’t limited to existing backdoors.
sentence.1400: Dark Reading concludes with some findings by Check Point Research which point to a dramatic surge in ransomware, including a 93 percent growth year-over-year.
sentence.1401: In 2021 alone, ransomware has experienced a 41 percent growth, felt most in Latin America (62 percent) and Europe (59 percent).
sentence.1402: For more on Proofpoint’s Advanced Threat Protection, visit:
sentence.1403: For more on Proofpoint’s Targeted Attack Protection, visit:
sentence.1404: To learn more about Proofpoint’s ransomware research, visit:
sentence.1406: * After a months-long absence, the malware loader JSSLoader returned in June 2021 campaigns rewritten from the .NET programming language to C++.
sentence.1407: * Rewriting the [malware](https://www.proofpoint.com/us/threat-reference/malware) could be an effort by threat actors to evade current detections.
sentence.1408: * Current TA543 campaigns delivering JSSLoader are using similar lures to those observed by Proofpoint researchers in 2019 and the emails continue to contain links to a TDS landing page.
sentence.1409: In June 2021, Proofpoint researchers observed a new variant of the downloader JSSLoader in several campaigns impacting a variety of organizations.
sentence.1410: This version of the malware loader was rewritten from .NET to the C++ programming language.
sentence.1411: This change, while not unheard of, is not a common occurrence and could be an effort by the threat actors utilizing JSSLoader to evade current detections.
sentence.1412: JSSLoader is often dropped in the first or second stage of a campaign and has the functionality to profile infected machines and load additional payloads.
sentence.1413: The campaigns are ongoing and use similar lures to those initially observed by Proofpoint researchers in 2019.
sentence.1415: Proofpoint researchers initially observed [JSSLoader](https://malpedia.caad.fkie.fraunhofer.de/details/win.jssloader) in September 2019.
sentence.1416: Fast forward nearly two years and Proofpoint has now identified this latest variant of the malware loader written in C++.
sentence.1418: JSSLoader is an initial access malware that was written in .NET and was named after its “JSS” namespace and “jssAdmin” command and control (C&C) panel login page:
sentence.1419: *Figure 1. JSSLoader C&C panel login page from September 27, 2019 version.*
sentence.1420: Its C&C used HTTPS requests with base64-encoded data:
sentence.1421: *Figure 2. Example C&C request from September 27, 2019 version.*
sentence.1422: The initial C&C beacon contained verbose system information:
sentence.1423: Its commands and functionality focused on executing a next stage executableor JavaScript:
sentence.1424: Its commands and functionality focused on executing a next stage executable or JavaScript:
sentence.1426: Since the initial version of JSSLoader, there have been gradual changes and improvements to the malware in successive campaigns.
sentence.1427: Morphisec wrote about some of these in a January 2021 paper titled “[Threat Profile the Evolution of the FIN7 JSSLoader (PDF)](https://www.morphisec.com/hubfs/eBooks_and_Whitepapers/FIN7%20JSSLOADER%20FINAL%20WEB.pdf).
sentence.1428: For example, the JSSLoader used in a December 14, 2020 email-based campaign sent the following system information:
sentence.1429: In addition to the changes in the C&C protocol, several new commands were added.
sentence.1430: After this December 2020 campaign, activity paused and the malware went through a redevelopment phase, according to Proofpoint’s visibility.
sentence.1432: In June 2021, email campaigns resumed, but the JSSLoader malware had been redeveloped from using the .NET programming language to C++ (this change was also [noticed on infosec Twitter](https://twitter.com/Arkbird_SOLG/status/1400845449515372555)).
sentence.1433: It is not common for a malware to be redeveloped in a different programming language, but it does happen occasionally.
sentence.1434: Proofpoint recently [documented](https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/new-variant-buer-loader-written-rust) another initial access malware known as “Buer Loader” that was redeveloped from the C programming language to Rust.
sentence.1435: As noted in that blog post, rewriting a malware can enable threat actors to better evade existing detection capabilities.
sentence.1436: The C++ version of JSSLoader analyzed here is from a June 8, 2021 email-based campaign.
sentence.1437: It sets up “registry run” persistence using a value name of “AppJSSLoader” and has similar style of system information beacon as the later .NET versions:
sentence.1438: C&C protocol and command similarity was likely a choice to remain backwards compatible with the existing .NET version’s C&C panel software.
sentence.1439: JSSLoader appears to be exclusive to several threat actors.
sentence.1440: In fact, Proofpoint has only observed two actors using it since the first email campaign in 2019.
sentence.1441: Most of the campaigns were attributed to the threat actor tracked by Proofpoint as TA543.
sentence.1442: A typical campaign contains thousands of email messages and targets several hundred organizations.
sentence.1443: The lures used by TA543 typically focus on invoices and delivery information of packages.
sentence.1444: The following sections describe and compare the original campaigns observed by Proofpoint in 2019 to the June 2021 campaigns.
sentence.1445: On September 27, 2019 Proofpoint analysts observed a TA543 campaign spoofing Intuit branding.
sentence.1446: The threat actor used a likely compromised account for an email marketing service to send the malicious emails that purported to be invoices and contained URLs linking to a landing page hosting BlackTDS. The TDS would direct the user to the download another file, a VBS downloader, hosted on SharePoint.
sentence.1447: The VBS downloader would then download JSSLoader.
sentence.1448: During our analysis of JSSLoader, it additionally loaded a Griffon payload which is historically associated with another actor, TA3546, also known as FIN7 or Carbanak.
sentence.1449: In the following months Proofpoint analysts observed TA543 shift to primarily delivering JSSLoader and/or other loaders that were often observed downloading other TA3546-associated payloads.
sentence.1450: *Figure 9. TA543 email that leads to the download of JSSLoader.*
sentence.1451: On June 8, 2021, Proofpoint analysts observed a TA543 campaign spoofing UPS branding (Figure 10).
sentence.1452: The email contained URLs linking to a Keitaro TDS landing.
sentence.1453: If executed, it downloaded an intermediate script, which then downloaded and executed the C++ version of JSSLoader.
sentence.1454: *Figure 10. TA543 email sample from June 8, 2021, that leads to the download of JSSLoader.*
sentence.1455: The threat actors behind JSSLoader have continuously made modifications since its debut in 2019 and are likely to continue doing so using the 2021 variant.
sentence.1456: With the redevelopment of the malware into C++, which was possibly done to evade current detections and make analysis more difficult, Proofpoint researchers have not seen the .NET version in play.

sentence.1464: 2033074 - ET TROJAN FIN7 JSSLoader Variant Activity (GET)

sentence.1466: Cobalt Strike: Favorite Tool from APT to Crimeware
sentence.1467: * Malicious use of Cobalt Strike in threat actor campaigns is increasing.
sentence.1468: * Threat actor use of Cobalt Strike increased 161 percent from 2019 to 2020 and remains a high-volume threat in 2021.
sentence.1469: * Cobalt Strike is currently used by more cybercrime and general commodity [malware](https://www.proofpoint.com/us/threat-reference/malware) operators than APT and espionage threat actors.
sentence.1470: In 2021, Cobalt Strike is appearing in Proofpoint threat data more frequently than ever.
sentence.1471: Cobalt Strike is a legitimate security tool used by penetration testers to emulate threat actor activity in a network.
sentence.1472: However, it is also increasingly used by malicious actors – Proofpoint saw a 161 percent increase in threat actor use of the tool from 2019 to 2020.
sentence.1473: When mapped to the [MITRE ATT&CK framework](https://attack.mitre.org/matrices/enterprise/), Proofpoint’s visibility into the attack chain focuses on [Initial Access](https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/first-step-initial-access-leads-ransomware), Execution, and Persistence mechanisms.
sentence.1474: Based on our data, Proofpoint assesses with high confidence that Cobalt Strike is becoming increasingly popular among threat actors as an initial access payload, not just a second-stage tool threat actors use once access is achieved, with criminal threat actors making up the bulk of attributed Cobalt Strike campaigns in 2020.
sentence.1475: In December 2020, the world learned about an expansive and effective espionage campaign that successfully backdoored the popular network monitoring software SolarWinds.
sentence.1476: Investigators [revealed tools](https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2020/12/evasive-attacker-leverages-solarwinds-supply-chain-compromises-with-sunburst-backdoor.html) used by the threat actors included Cobalt Strike Beacon.
sentence.1477: This campaign was attributed to threat actors working for Russia’s Foreign Intelligence Service – a group with Cobalt Strike in their toolbox [since at least](https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2018/11/not-so-cozy-an-uncomfortable-examination-of-a-suspected-apt29-phishing-campaign.html) 2018.
sentence.1478: Cobalt Strike [debuted](https://blog.cobaltstrike.com/2016/03/02/a-history-of-cobalt-strike-in-training-courses/) in 2012 in response to perceived gaps in an existing red team tool, the Metasploit Framework.
sentence.1479: In 2015, Cobalt Strike 3.0 launched as a standalone adversary emulation platform.
sentence.1480: By 2016, Proofpoint researchers began observing threat actors using Cobalt Strike.
sentence.1481: Historically, Cobalt Strike use in malicious operations was largely associated with well-resourced threat actors, including [large cybercrime operators](https://community.broadcom.com/symantecenterprise/communities/community-home/librarydocuments/viewdocument?DocumentKey=257dd693-5986-41bf-bc33-f9dc76d9c6a8&CommunityKey=1ecf5f55-9545-44d6-b0f4-4e4a7f5f5e68&tab=librarydocuments) like TA3546 (also known as FIN7), and advanced persistent threat (APT) [groups such as TA423](https://www.proofpoint.com/us/threat-insight/post/leviathan-espionage-actor-spearphishes-maritime-and-defense-targets) (also known as Leviathan or APT40).
sentence.1482: Proofpoint researchers have attributed two-thirds of identified Cobalt Strike campaigns from 2016 through 2018 to well-resourced cybercrime organizations or APT groups.
sentence.1483: That ratio decreased dramatically the following years – between 2019 and present, just 15 percent of Cobalt Strike campaigns were attributable to known threat actors.
sentence.1484: *Figure 1: Number of email messages associated with a Cobalt Strike payload observed over time.
sentence.1485: Threat actors can obtain Cobalt Strike in a variety of ways: purchasing it directly from the vendor’s website, which requires verification; buying a version on the dark web via various hacking forums; or using cracked, illegitimate versions of the software.
sentence.1486: In March 2020, a cracked version of Cobalt Strike 4.0 was released and made available to threat actors.
sentence.1488: Cobalt Strike is used by a diverse array of threat actors, and while it is not unusual for cybercriminal and APT actors to leverage similar tooling in their campaigns, Cobalt Strike is unique in that  its built-in capabilities enable it to be quickly deployed and operationalized regardless of actor sophistication or access to human or financial resources.
sentence.1489: Cobalt Strike is also session-based — that is, if threat actors can access a host and complete an operation without needing to establish ongoing persistence, there will not be remaining artifacts on the host after it is no longer running in-memory.
sentence.1490: Threat actors can also use the malleability of Cobalt Strike to create customized builds that add or remove features to achieve objectives or evade detection.
sentence.1491: For example, APT29 frequently uses custom Cobalt Strike Beacon loaders to [blend in](https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2018/11/not-so-cozy-an-uncomfortable-examination-of-a-suspected-apt29-phishing-campaign.html) with legitimate traffic or [evade analysis](https://www.microsoft.com/security/blog/2021/05/28/breaking-down-nobeliums-latest-early-stage-toolset/).
sentence.1492: For defenders, customized Cobalt Strike modules often require unique signatures, so threat detection engineers may be required to play catch-up to Cobalt Strike use in the wild.
sentence.1493: Cobalt Strike is also appealing to threat actors for its inherent obfuscation.
sentence.1494: If an organization has a red team actively making use of it, it is possible malicious traffic could be mistaken as legitimate.
sentence.1495: Proofpoint data shows Cobalt Strike is a popular tool for everything from strategic compromises to noisy, widespread campaigns.
sentence.1496: The following examples illustrate a small sampling of the types of threat actors leveraging Cobalt Strike tracked by Proofpoint.
sentence.1498: TA800 is a large crimeware group tracked by Proofpoint since mid-2019.
sentence.1499: This actor attempts to deliver and install banking malware or malware loaders, including The Trick and BazaLoader.
sentence.1500: In April 2020, TA800 became the first group observed distributing BazaLoader.
sentence.1501: In these early campaigns, the threat actor distributed emails with a malicious link to an executable or a landing page hosted on Google Docs with a link to an executable.
sentence.1502: The executable downloaded the BazaLoader backdoor which in turn downloaded Cobalt Strike.
sentence.1503: In February 2021, the group pivoted to distributing Cobalt Strike as a first-stage payload via malicious URLs.
sentence.1504: There has been some evidence suggesting TA800’s [NimzaLoader](https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/nimzaloader-ta800s-new-initial-access-malware)is being used to download and execute Cobalt Strike as its secondary payload.
sentence.1506: TA547 is a crimeware actor tracked by Proofpoint since October 2017.
sentence.1507: This group appears to be interested in distributing primarily banking trojans – including The Trick and ZLoader – to various geographic regions.
sentence.1508: Since mid-2020, this actor favors using malicious Microsoft Office attachments to distribute malware.
sentence.1509: In February 2021, TA547 began distributing Cobalt Strike as a second-stage payload for command and control.
sentence.1511: TA415 is an APT actor believed to be associated with People’s Republic of China (PRC) state interests.
sentence.1512: The group has been noted in United States court filings to be tied to PRC’s Ministry of State Security.
sentence.1513: TA415 is also known as Barium and APT41.
sentence.1514: Proofpoint identified TA415 delivering Cobalt Strike as a first-stage payload in limited campaigns during mid-2020.
sentence.1515: In September 2020, the United States Department of Justice announced the indictment of several threat actors associated with this threat group, and [detailed](https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/seven-international-cyber-defendants-including-apt41-actors-charged-connection-computer) the threat actors use of Cobalt Strike in the indictment.
sentence.1516: TA415 used Cobalt Strike in a campaign against an entity in the airlines sector.
sentence.1517: The following timeline provides a small sample of threat actor use of Cobalt Strike across cybercrime and APT threats.
sentence.1518: The selected events were identified based on their significance, and are not representative of the full Cobalt Strike threat landscape.
sentence.1519: *Figure 2: Timeline of threats using Cobalt Strike.
sentence.1520: Proofpoint has observed dozens of threat actors using Cobalt Strike.
sentence.1521: Threat actors use different lure themes, threat types, droppers, and payloads.
sentence.1522: For example, the earliest Cobalt Strike campaigns distributed email threats with malicious document attachments to distribute the malware, but campaigns distributing malicious URLs directly in the email body have overtaken attachments as the more frequently utilized threat type.
sentence.1523: While instances of Cobalt Strike being sent directly as an initial payload have dramatically increased, deployment as a second stage payload remains popular.
sentence.1524: Cobalt Strike has been observed in a variety of attack chains alongside malware such as The Trick, BazaLoader, Ursnif, IcedID, and many more popular loaders.
sentence.1525: In these cases, the preceding malware typically loads and executes Cobalt Strike.
sentence.1526: Likewise, there is a wide array of techniques leveraged in cases where Cobalt Strike is delivered directly, such as via malicious macros in weaponized Office documents, compressed executables, PowerShell, dynamic data exchange (DDE), HTA/HTML files, and traffic distribution systems.
sentence.1527: After Cobalt Strike has been executed and a Beacon established for C2 communication, actors have been observed attempting to enumerate network connections and dumping Active Directory credentials as they try to move laterally to a network resource such as a Domain Controller, allowing for deployment of ransomware to all networked systems.
sentence.1529: Use the net dclist command to find the Domain Controller for the domain the target is joined to.
sentence.1530: Use the net view command to find targets on the domain the target is joined to.
sentence.1531: Use the net viewcommand to find targets on the domain the target is joined to.
sentence.1532: In addition to network discovery and credential dumping, Cobalt Strike Beacon also has the capability to elevate privileges, load and execute additional tools, and to inject these functions into existing running host processes to attempt to avoid detection.
sentence.1533: Proofpoint researchers anticipate Cobalt Strike will continue to be a commonly used tool in threat actor toolsets.
sentence.1534: According to internal data, tens of thousands of organizations have already been targeted with Cobalt Strike, based on observed campaigns.
sentence.1535: *Figure 3: Number of customers targeted by threats using Cobalt Strike*
sentence.1536: Cobalt Strike is a useful tool, for legitimate security researchers and threat actors alike.
sentence.1537: Its malleability coupled with its usability makes it a robust and effective tool for siphoning data, moving laterally, and loading additional malware payloads.
sentence.1538: Cobalt Strike is not the only red team tool appearing more often in Proofpoint data.
sentence.1539: Others include Mythic, Meterpreter, and the Veil Framework.
sentence.1540: The use of publicly available tooling aligns with a broader trend observed by Proofpoint:
sentence.1541: Threat actors are using as many legitimate tools as possible, including executing Windows processes like PowerShell and WMI; injecting malicious code into legitimate binaries; and frequently using allowable services like Dropbox, Google Drive, SendGrid, and Constant Contact to host and distribute malware.

sentence.1561: * Threat actors created a detailed, legitimate looking “Privacy Tools” website to trick victims into downloading malware.
sentence.1562: * The Privacy Tools site purports to offer file protection via encryption and decryption services but leads to the installation of multiple malware families.
sentence.1563: * Smoke Loader is downloaded first as the malicious executable which drops follow-on malware including Racoon Stealer and RedLine malware.
sentence.1564: Proofpoint researchers found a new threat enticing users to download malware by masquerading as a “Privacy Tools” service offering a tool that “encrypts” user data using a zip-like utility.
sentence.1565: The fake website is professional-looking and contains detailed descriptions of the alleged service including step-by-step instructions on how to download the privacy tools – which turn out to be malware.
sentence.1566: Proofpoint researchers identified the initial payload as Smoke Loader, a popular downloader available on easily accessible forums for buying and selling malware and used by multiple threat actors.
sentence.1567: The malware subsequently installs follow-on data-stealing malware including Raccoon Stealer and RedLine.
sentence.1568: While investigating the observed campaign, Proofpoint identified [additional](https://twitter.com/pmmkowalczyk/status/1369647346997469186) related [samples](https://twitter.com/jorgemieres/status/1382400601158455297) publicly shared by other researchers since March 2021.
sentence.1569: The privacy theme is ironic considering the ultimate payload is designed to exfiltrate information from an infected host.
sentence.1570: However, it may appeal to users who are concerned about data sharing and privacy – a number that is likely increasing due to the recent mainstream marketing of user-focused [privacy controls](https://www.npr.org/2021/04/26/990943261/apple-rolls-out-major-new-privacy-protections-for-iphones-and-ipads) from major companies like Apple.
sentence.1571: Visitors are instructed to download and install Privacy Tools software via a specific section of the website.
sentence.1572: The website actually downloads Smoke Loader, a modular downloader with multiple capabilities.
sentence.1573: Smoke Loader first appeared in 2011 and is available for purchase on criminal forums.
sentence.1574: Proofpoint researchers observed that the Smoke Loader infection subsequently downloads follow-on malware to conduct information-gathering activities.
sentence.1575: Identified second-stage payloads include RedLine and Raccoon Stealer malware.
sentence.1576: Additional [security researchers](https://twitter.com/pmmkowalczyk/status/1369647346997469186) noticed this activity in 2021 along with Proofpoint observations.
sentence.1577: Raccoon Stealer is an increasingly popular malware that first appeared in 2019.
sentence.1578: It was [advertised as](https://blog.cyberint.com/raccoon-stealer) a “malware as a service” on cybercriminal forums.
sentence.1579: It can steal credentials such as passwords, website cookies, credit card data, system information, and bitcoin wallet contents.
sentence.1580: RedLine Stealer is a malware that aims to steal information from browsers such as login, autocomplete, passwords, and credit cards.
sentence.1581: It also collects information about the user and their system, such as the username, location, hardware configuration, and installed security software.
sentence.1582: An [update](https://bartblaze.blogspot.com/2021/06/digital-artists-targeted-in-redline.html) to [RedLine](https://www.proofpoint.com/uk/threat-insight/post/new-redline-stealer-distributed-using-coronavirus-themed-email-campaign) Stealer in early 2021 also added the ability to steal cryptocurrency cold wallets.
sentence.1583: Proofpoint does not attribute the activity to a specific group.
sentence.1584: The privacy-themed websites delivering Smoke Loader in this campaign were registered by ssserviceshop1@yandex[.]ru via Registrar of Domain Names REG[.]ru, LLC.
sentence.1585: Multiple other privacy-themed domains and C2 IPs were also registered with the same email address and registrar.
sentence.1586: ***Analyst Note:***[*Previous research*](https://www.ptsecurity.com/ww-en/analytics/pt-esc-threat-intelligence/operation-ta505-part3/) *published in May 2020 attributed a Smoke Loader-related domain registered with the same email and URL naming conventions as observed in this campaign to TA505.
sentence.1587: Proofpoint cannot confirm the veracity of that reporting.
sentence.1588: There is no available evidence to attribute the observed activity in the privacy-themed campaigns to TA505.*
sentence.1589: The use of a privacy-themed lure to download information-stealing malware is an ironic yet predatory mechanism for enticing users to download malware.
sentence.1590: Based on additional indicators uncovered, it is likely this threat actor is conducting – and has previously conducted – similar campaigns using privacy themes and convincing lures to distribute Smoke Loader and follow-on malware.
sentence.1591: Proofpoint anticipates this type of theme and activity to continue, especially for consumers who do not have corporate privacy and security services already installed on their hosts.
sentence.1592: Observed in Identified Smoke Loader Campaign
sentence.1683: Operation SpoofedScholars: A Conversation with TA453
sentence.1684: * [TA453](https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/badblood-ta453-targets-us-and-israeli-medical-research-personnel-credential), an Iranian - state aligned actor, masqueraded as British scholars to covertly target individuals of intelligence interest to the Iranian government in what Proofpoint has dubbed Operation SpoofedScholars.
sentence.1685: * The email conversations were benign until TA453 provided a link to a compromised website hosting a credential harvesting page.
sentence.1686: * The use of a legitimate but actor-compromised website is an increase in sophistication compared to TA453’s historical Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures of using actor-controlled credential phishing websites.
sentence.1687: * Proofpoint has worked with the appropriate authorities to conduct victim notification.
sentence.1688: Masquerading as UK scholars with the University of London’s School of Oriental and African Studies (SOAS), the threat actor TA453 has been covertly approaching individuals since at least January 2021 to solicit sensitive information.
sentence.1689: The threat actor, an APT who we assess with high confidence supports Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) intelligence collection efforts, established backstopping for their credential phishing infrastructure by compromising a legitimate site of a highly regarded academic institution to deliver personalized credential harvesting pages disguised as registration links.
sentence.1690: Identified targets included experts in Middle Eastern affairs from think tanks, senior professors from well-known academic institutions, and journalists specializing in Middle Eastern coverage.
sentence.1691: Once the conversation was established, TA453 delivered a “registration link” to a legitimate but compromised website belonging to the University of London’s SOAS radio.
sentence.1692: Of note, TA453 also targeted the personal email accounts of at least one of their targets.
sentence.1693: In subsequent phishing emails, TA453 shifted their tactics and began delivering the registration link earlier in their engagement with the target without requiring extensive conversation.
sentence.1694: This operation, dubbed SpoofedScholars, represents one of the more sophisticated TA453 campaigns identified by Proofpoint.
sentence.1696: In early 2021, a TA453 persona, “Dr.Hanns Bjoern Kendel, Senior Teaching and Research Fellow at SOAS University in London,” used email address hannse.kendel4[@]gmail.com to solicit conversations with targets.
sentence.1697: The following is a brief summary of an example conversation observed by Proofpoint Threat Research:
sentence.1698: TA453 sent an initial email trying to entice the target with a prospective invitation to an online conference on “The US Security Challenges in the Middle East.
sentence.1699: TA453sent an initial email trying to entice the target with a prospective invitation to an online conference on “The US Security Challenges in the Middle East.
sentence.1700: TA453 strived to connect with the individual via phone to discuss the invitation; however, after the target hedged and emphatically stated that they wanted a written proposal with the details, TA453 acquiesced with conference specifics.
sentence.1701: After a little back and forth that verified the target’s interest, TA453 provided a detailed invitation to the fake conference (Figure 1).
sentence.1702: The conversation concluded with TA453 attempting to get the target to connect via videoconferencing.
sentence.1703: Throughout the conversation, Proofpoint identified a few interesting themes:
sentence.1704: * TA453 demonstrates passable English skills and is open to voice communication via videoconferencing.
sentence.1705: * TA453 demonstrates an interest in mobile phone numbers, possibly for mobile malware or additional phishing.
sentence.1706: * TA453 repeatedly demonstrated a desire to connect with the target in real-time.
sentence.1707: In addition to Hanns’ solicitations, at least one target received a credential harvesting email to their personal email account.
sentence.1708: This attempt did not masquerade as Dr. Kendel but did still attempt to harvest credentials from the target.
sentence.1709: Currently, Proofpoint does not have more information on this specific kill chain.
sentence.1710: TA453 targets in Operation SpoofedScholars can be clustered into three main categories that are consistent with the IRGC’s historical collection priorities.
sentence.1711: * Journalists focused on Middle Eastern affairs
sentence.1712: These groupings consistently have information of interest to the Iranian government, including, but not limited to, information about foreign policy, insights into Iranian dissident movements, and understanding of U.S. nuclear negotiations, and most of the identified targets have been previously targeted by TA453.
sentence.1713: Targeting appeared to be highly selective, with less than ten organizations targeted, according to Proofpoint data.
sentence.1714: Once TA453 established a time for the target to activate their invitation, the TA453 persona provided the personalized link to the intended victim.
sentence.1715: The link led to a “Webinar Control Panel” on a legitimate but compromised website belonging to University of London’s SOAS, a research institution.
sentence.1716: According to Proofpoint research, while TA453 does appear to have elevated privileges allowing them to create credential harvesting pages at soasradio[.]org, other pages on the site continue to host legitimate SOAS-affiliated content.
sentence.1717: TA453 strengthened the credibility of the attempted credential harvest by utilizing personas masquerading as legitimate affiliates of SOAS to deliver the malicious links.
sentence.1718: The displayed webpage (Figure 2) offers users the ability to use “OpenID” to log in with the following mail providers; Google, Yahoo, Microsoft, iCloud, Outlook, AOL, mail.ru, Email, and Facebook.
sentence.1720: When a particular provider is clicked, a pop-up box (Figure 3) displays the actual credential phishing box.
sentence.1721: Of the options, Google, Microsoft, and Email buttons prefilled the target’s email address.
sentence.1722: Based on the variety of email providers along with TA453’s insistence that the target log on when TA453 was online, Proofpoint assesses that TA453 was planning on immediately validating the captured credentials manually.
sentence.1723: Hanns Kendel was not the only SOAS scholar spoofed by TA453 during Operation SpoofedScholars.
sentence.1724: Months later, TA453 began spoofingTolga Sinmazdemir, another individual associated with SOAS.
sentence.1725: Months later, TA453 began spoofing Tolga Sinmazdemir, another individual associated with SOAS.
sentence.1726: These emails solicited contributions to a “DIPS Conference” and would have likely followed a similar kill chain discussed above.
sentence.1727: In mid-May, TA453 returned, using a different email (hanse.kendel4[@]gmail.com) to recruit for a webinar.
sentence.1728: As discussed previously in Proofpoint’s research on TA453’s [BadBlood](/us/blog/threat-insight/badblood-ta453-targets-us-and-israeli-medical-research-personnel-credential "BadBlood: TA453 Targets US and Israeli Medical Research Personnel in Credential Phishing Campaigns ") campaign, Proofpoint analysts cannot independently confirm that TA453 is part of the IRGC.
sentence.1729: However, the tactics and techniques used by the group and their overall targeting detected by Proofpoint is in line with IRGC intelligence collection priorities, which gives us high confidence in our assessment that TA453 operates in support of the IRGC. The IRGC, specifically the IRGC Intelligence Organization, collects intelligence and conducts operations in support of a variety of assigned responsibilities.
sentence.1730: According to the Meir Amit Intelligence and Terrorism Information Center’s November 2020 [report](https://www.terrorism-info.org.il/en/the-intelligence-organization-of-the-irgc-a-major-iranian-intelligence-apparatus/), some of the IRGC IO’s responsibilities include foiling political subversion, combating western cultural penetration, and supporting the arrest of Iranian dual nationals.
sentence.1731: Likewise, attribution specifically for Operation SpoofedScholars is based on TTP similarities to previous TA453 campaigns and consistency with TA453’s historical targeting.
sentence.1732: TA453 often uses free email providers to spoof individuals familiar to their targets to increase the likelihood of successful compromise.
sentence.1733: Additionally, as previously discussed, TA453 concentrates their credential phishing to specific individuals of interest to collect intelligence through exfiltration of sensitive email and contacts or initial access for future phishing campaigns.
sentence.1734: For specific mitigations against Operation SpoofedScholars, Proofpoint recommends investigating network traffic to soasradio[.]org, specifically URIs starting with hxxps://soasradio[.]org/connect/?memberemailid=.
sentence.1735: Broader mitigation efforts against TA453 campaigns include increased awareness and investigation of unusual communication from professional contacts.
sentence.1736: Using multifactor authentication provides another layer of protection against TA453 credential harvesting.
sentence.1737: TA453 illegally obtained access to a website belonging to a world class academic institution to leverage the compromised infrastructure to harvest the credentials of their intended targets.
sentence.1738: The use of legitimate, but compromised, infrastructure represents an increase in TA453’s sophistication and will almost certainly be reflected in future campaigns.
sentence.1739: TA453 continues to iterate, innovate, and collect in support of IRGC collection priorities.
sentence.1740: While some of the identified selectors no longer appear to be active in TA453 operations, Proofpoint assesses with high confidence that TA453 will continue to spoof scholars around the world in support of TA453’s intelligence collection operations in support of Iranian government interests.
sentence.1742: I Knew You Were Trouble: TA456 Targets Defense Contractor with Alluring Social Media Persona
sentence.1743: * TA456, anIranian-state aligned actor, spent years masquerading as the persona “Marcella Flores” in an attempt to infect the machine of an employee of an aerospace defense contractor with malware.
sentence.1744: * TA456, an Iranian-state aligned actor, spent years masquerading as the persona “Marcella Flores” in an attempt to infect the machine of an employee of an aerospace defense contractor with malware.
sentence.1745: * The malware, dubbed by Proofpoint as LEMPO, was designed to establish persistence, perform reconnaissance, and exfiltrate sensitive information.
sentence.1746: * TA456 actively targets smaller subsidiaries and contractors in support of efforts to compromise larger defense contractors using a supply chain compromise.
sentence.1747: * While targeting defense contractors is not new for TA456, this campaign uniquely establishes the group as one of the most determined Iranian-aligned threat actors tracked by Proofpoint because of its significant use of social engineering, cross platform communication, and general persistence.
sentence.1748: Proofpoint researchers have identified a years-long social engineering and targeted malware campaign by the Iranian-state aligned threat actor TA456.
sentence.1749: Using the social media persona “Marcella Flores,” TA456 built a relationship across corporate and personal communication platforms with an employee of a small subsidiary of an aerospace defense contractor.
sentence.1750: In early June 2021, the threat actor attempted to capitalize on this relationship by sending the target malware via an ongoing email communication chain.
sentence.1751: Designed to conduct reconnaissance on the target’s machine, the macro-laden document contained personalized content and demonstrated the importance TA456 placed on the target.
sentence.1752: Once the malware, which is an updated version of [Liderc](https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2019/09/tortoiseshell-fake-veterans.html)  that Proofpoint has dubbed LEMPO, establishes persistence, it can perform reconnaissance on the infected machine, save the reconnaissance details to the host, exfiltrate sensitive information to an actor-controlled email account via SMTPS, and then cover its tracks by deleting that day’s host artifacts.
sentence.1753: In mid-July, Facebook disrupted a network of similar personas they attributed to Tortoiseshell.
sentence.1754: LEMPO, the malware, whose delivery Proofpoint disrupted, along with the network of personas, are attributed to TA456.
sentence.1755: This actor is believed to be loosely aligned with the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) via association with the Iranian company Mahak Rayan Afraz (MRA), according to Facebook’s analysis.
sentence.1757: Proofpoint data shows that over at least eight months, “Marcella (Marcy) Flores” sent TA456’s target benign email messages, photographs, and a video to establish her veracity and build rapport with the intended victim.
sentence.1758: At one time, TA456 attempted to send a benign, but flirtatious video via a OneDrive URL. In early June, a TA456 actor self-identified as “Marcy” sent another OneDrive link, this time masquerading as a diet survey (Figure 1).
sentence.1759: If the content is enabled, the macro will create and hide the directory \Appdata\Perflog and then write LEMPO, a very simple but ingenious plaintext stealer comprised of Visual Basic Script (VBS), to that directory (Schedule.vbs 1534f95f49ddf2ada38561705f901e5938470c1678d6a81f0f4177ba7412ef5b).

sentence.1768: Leveraging built-in Windows commands it enumerates the host in a variety of ways, records the collected data and then exfiltrates the intelligence to an actor-controlled email account using Microsoft’s Collaboration Data Objects (CDO).

sentence.1795: *Figure 4. *Open-source research indicates “Marcella” interacted with TA456’s target on social media starting in late 2019.

sentence.1797: Proofpoint’s analysis indicates the profile bears strong similarities to fictitious profiles previously used by Iranian APTs to socially engineer targets of intelligence value.
sentence.1798: The “Marcella” profile appeared to be friends with multiple individuals who publicly identify as defense contractor employees and who are geographically dispersed from “Marcella’s” alleged location in Liverpool, UK.
sentence.1799: On July 15, 2021, [Facebook announced](https://about.fb.com/news/2021/07/taking-action-against-hackers-in-iran/) they had disrupted a network of Facebook and Instagram personas, including “Marcella’s,” they attributed to the Iranian-aligned actor.
sentence.1800: TA456 routinely conducts reconnaissance campaigns disguised as news related spam that target individuals employed by aerospace defense contractors.
sentence.1801: The targeting of U.S. defense contractors, particularly those supporting contracts in the Middle East, is consistent with historical Iranian cyber activity.
sentence.1802: Additionally, Proofpoint has observed TA456 targeting individuals employed at multiple subcontractors and subsidiaries of larger defense companies.
sentence.1803: This is consistent with TA456’s TTP of targeting business and information technology-related individuals within their target organization.
sentence.1804: Proofpoint attributes this campaign to TA456, an Iranian-aligned adversary focused on espionage efforts against defense industrial base employees and contractors, particularly those supporting efforts in the Middle East.
sentence.1805: TA456 overlaps with activity tracked as Tortoiseshell, and Imperial Kitten.
sentence.1806: On July 15, 2021, Facebook [attributed](https://about.fb.com/news/2021/07/taking-action-against-hackers-in-iran/) a portion of Tortoiseshell’s activity to Mahak Rayan Afraz (MRA), an Iranian IT company with ties to the IRGC.
sentence.1807: Based on previous malware analysis and historical open-source research, Proofpoint concurs with this attribution.
sentence.1808: Additionally, LEMPO shares multiple similarities with [Tortoiseshell’s Liderc](https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2019/09/tortoiseshell-fake-veterans.html), including extensive machine reconnaissance, exfiltration via email, hardcoded email addresses with similar formatting, and overall pattern of targeting companies and individuals aligned with the American defense industrial base.
sentence.1809: TA456 demonstrated a significant operational investment by cultivating a relationship with a target’s employee over years in order to deploy LEMPO to conduct reconnaissance into a highly secured target environment within the defense industrial base.
sentence.1810: Facebook’s announcement demonstrated TA456 had established an extensive network of these personas dedicated to enabling cyberespionage operations.
sentence.1811: While Proofpoint did not observe the delivery of any remote access trojans or command and control channels like TA456’s [Syskit](https://symantec-enterprise-blogs.security.com/blogs/threat-intelligence/tortoiseshell-apt-supply-chain), the information potentially gathered by LEMPO could be operationalized in a variety of ways.
sentence.1812: These include the utilization of stolen VPN credentials, exploitation of vulnerabilities in the identified software, or the customization of more advanced malware delivered from “Marcella.
sentence.1813: TA456’s dedication to significant social engineering engagement, benign reconnaissance of targets prior to deploying malware, and their cross platform kill chain establish TA456 to be one of the most resourceful Iranian-aligned threats tracked by Proofpoint.
sentence.1814: TA456’s dedication to significantsocial engineering engagement, benign reconnaissance of targets prior to deploying malware, and their cross platform kill chain establish TA456 to be one of the most resourceful Iranian-aligned threats tracked by Proofpoint.
sentence.1815: The “Marcella Flores” persona is likely not the only one in use by TA456, making it important for those working within or tangentially to the defense industrial base to be vigilant when engaging with unknown individuals regardless of whether it is via work or personal accounts.
sentence.1816: As Delta Variant Spreads, COVID-19 Themes Make Resurgence In Email Threats
sentence.1817: * Proofpoint researchers observed an increase in COVID-19 related threats since late June 2021.
sentence.1818: * Proofpoint researchers observed high-volume COVID-19 related campaigns from malware including RustyBuer, Formbook, and Ave Maria.
sentence.1819: The newly observed campaigns related to the identified malware follow a lull in COVID-19-themed threat campaigns through the Spring and early Summer of 2021.
sentence.1820: Proofpoint has tracked ongoing threats leveraging COVID-19 and related coronavirus themes since the beginning of the pandemic.
sentence.1821: TA542, known to distribute Emotet, first began using COVID-19 in email threats in January 2020.
sentence.1822: Although the virus has remained an ongoing theme, Proofpoint researchers observed a significant increase in the number of messages leveraging COVID-19 themes in recent months.
sentence.1823: Since late June 2021, Proofpoint has observed high volume COVID-19 themed campaigns distributing RustyBuer, Formbook, and Ave Maria malware, in addition to multiple corporate phishing attempts to steal Microsoft and O365 credentials.
sentence.1824: Proofpoint researchers also identified an increase in [business email compromise](https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/bec-taxonomy-proofpoint-framework)  threats leveraging COVID-19 themes in this timeframe.
sentence.1825: The increase in COVID-19 themes in Proofpoint data aligns with public interest in the highly contagious [COVID-19 Delta variant](https://www.yalemedicine.org/news/5-things-to-know-delta-variant-covid).
sentence.1826: According to global Google Trend data, worldwide searches for “Delta variant” first peaked the last week in June 2021 and have continued through August 2021 so far.
sentence.1827: *Figure 1. Google Trend data for searches related to “Delta variant.”*
sentence.1828: Proofpoint observed tens of thousands of messages intended for recipients in various industries worldwide.
sentence.1829: South Korea, for example, [recently raised](http://tbs.seoul.kr/eFm/newsView.do?typ_800=N&idx_800=3445116&seq_800=20437693)  its cyber threat warning level in response to an increase of threats related to its COVID-19 relief programs.
sentence.1830: Proofpoint researchers have observed multiple high-volume COVID-19 related credential theft campaigns, including a Microsoft credential theft campaign targeting thousands of organizations globally.
sentence.1831: The messages contained a URL which likely leads to a fake Microsoft authentication page designed to harvest user credentials.
sentence.1832: Recently, many major American companies began requiring employees to be vaccinated before returning to the office.
sentence.1833: Proofpoint researchers observed a new high-volume Formbook campaign sent to hundreds of organizations masquerading as a human resource professional.
sentence.1834: The emails contain a zipped file(e.g. Scan.Salary.zip) and tell the recipients that their jobs are being eliminated due to the financial impact of COVID-19.
sentence.1835: To further entice the recipient to open the malicious file, the email states a “2 months salary receipt” is attached.
sentence.1836: The emails contain a malicious .ZIP attachment, that when extracted and executed leads to the installation of Formbook malware.
sentence.1838: Proofpoint researchers identified new Ave Maria malware campaigns largely targeting energy and industrial organizations.
sentence.1839: Ave Maria is a remote access trojan, written in C++, that is capable of process and file system manipulation, command shell access, webcam control, keylogging, password theft, and remote desktop access.
sentence.1840: The contents of the emails claimed there was new COVID-19 preventative measures included in the attachment.
sentence.1841: The following week, Proofpoint observed additional Ave Maria campaigns distributing COVID-19 themed messages, for example:
sentence.1842: All the observed Ave Maria COVID-19 themed messages contained an Excel attachment that exploits various Equation Editor vulnerabilities.
sentence.1843: The malware’s command and control infrastructure utilized Dynamic DNS and communication over port 5200.
sentence.1845: Currently, one of the most active COVID-19 related threats is RustyBuer, a new Rust-based Buer Loader strain [first identified](https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/new-variant-buer-loader-written-rust) by Proofpoint researchers in April 2021.
sentence.1846: [Buer](https://malpedia.caad.fkie.fraunhofer.de/details/win.buer) is a downloader  that is used as a foothold in compromised networks & an ‘Initial Access Broker’ to distribute other secondary payloads [including ransomware](https://www.cert.ssi.gouv.fr/uploads/CERTFR-2021-CTI-006.pdf).
sentence.1847: Historically, threat actors leveraging Buer and RustyBuer generally did not use COVID-19 themes; the virus theme was previously observed once associated with this malware in November 2020.
sentence.1848: COVID-19 infections at higher than Covid and rubbed his restaurants and COVID-19 vaccinations for its mask mandate for the ongoing disaster which The observed messages contain password protected zipped Microsoft Excel attachments with macros which, if enabled, will download and execute RustyBuer.
