sentence.1877: Proofpoint researchers in the [sixth](/us/blog/threat-insight/bec-taxonomy-gift-carding "BEC Taxonomy: Gift Carding ") of the [Business Email Compromise](/us/threat-reference/business-email-compromise "Business Email Compromise (BEC)") (BEC) taxonomy series explored the gift carding theme from the Email Fraud Taxonomy framework (Figure 1).
sentence.1879: Advance Fee Fraud, which in the past has been referred to as ‘419,’ ‘Nigerian 419,’ or ‘Nigerian Prince’ email fraud, occurs when a threat actor asks the potential victim for a small amount of money in advance of a larger, promised payout to be given to the victim at a later date.
sentence.1880: ### Advance Fee Fraud and the Email Fraud Taxonomy Framework
sentence.1881: Advance Fee Fraud leverages impersonation from the Deception layer of the Email Fraud Taxonomy.
sentence.1882: Advance Fee Fraud emails use a variety of lures to convince recipients of their legitimacy and to entice them to follow through on the request.
sentence.1883: Most Advance Fee Fraud emails are simple and easy to spot as fraudulent with few being well-crafted and more complex than the examples provided above.
sentence.1884: While Advance Fee only makes up a small fraction of the fraud emails Proofpoint researchers see in a day, the average loss can still be about $5,100 per incident when someone does fall for them.
sentence.1885: To better understand Proofpoint’s approach to BEC and how our researchers think of the various fraud themes, take a look at the first blog in this series, [BEC Taxonomy: A Proofpoint Framework](/us/blog/threat-insight/bec-taxonomy-proofpoint-framework "BEC Taxonomy: A Proofpoint Framework").
sentence.1886: Golden Chickens: Uncovering a Malware-as-a-Service (MaaS) Provider
sentence.1887: Over the last few years, [QuoIntelligence](https://quointelligence.eu/) (QuoINT) has tracked activities attributed to the Cobalt group, and observed their notable evolution and continuously improving Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures (TTPs).
sentence.1888: Since September 2018, we have identified multiple attacks that share similar TTPs used by Cobalt during a specific timeframe but exhibit enough differenced to attribute them to separate threat actors.
sentence.1889: This blog post provides an overview on a specific Malware-as-a-Service (MaaS) used within the e-Crime threat actor landscape.
sentence.1890: It also provides details on two different threat actors using the MaaS that fall under the umbrella of a family we dubbed *Golden Chickens*: GC01 and GC02.
sentence.1891: The success of Golden Chickens (GC) operations heavily relies on a specific MaaS sold in underground forums, which provides customers with the malwares and the infrastructure they need for targeted attacks.
sentence.1892: The service owner provides the MaaS through the use of the following toolkits: Venom and Taurus building kits for crafting documents used to deliver the attack, and the more\_eggs (aka Terra Loader, [SpicyOmelette](https://www.secureworks.com/blog/cybercriminals-increasingly-trying-to-ensnare-the-big-financial-fish)) backdoor for taking full control of the infected computer.
sentence.1893: Between November 2017 and July 2018, we attributed to GC02 five spear phishing waves which indiscriminately targeted companies and organizations in at least India and the United States.
sentence.1894: As a result of using the same MaaS provider, GC02 and Cobalt group’s TTPs and infrastructure strongly overlapped in May 2018, making it hard at first glance to differentiate the two threat actors.
sentence.1895: Between August and October 2018, we attributed to GC01 nine spear phishing waves targeting multiple companies and organizations operating in the financial industry.
sentence.1896: Throughout the campaign, we observed the installation of multiple Remote Access Tool (RAT) variations as the result of a successfully compromised victim machine.
sentence.1897: By highlighting the multi-layer infrastructure adopted by Cobalt and Golden Chickens, as well as the multi-client business model of the MaaS behind it, we emphasize the difficulty of performing reliable attribution for cyberattacks, and the high uncertainty that analysts are confronted with during the process.
sentence.1898: To note, other [researchers](https://researchcenter.paloaltonetworks.com/2018/10/unit42-new-techniques-uncover-attribute-cobalt-gang-commodity-builders-infrastructure-revealed/) reported the same Indicators of Compromise (IoC) and C2 infrastructure covered in this blog post.
sentence.1899: Especially for e-Crime actors, it is a common practice to rent the same bulletproof infrastructure or botnet used by other e-Crime groups, resulting in the increased likelihood for an overlap of C2 servers.
sentence.1900: In the last years, we have noted a tendency of threat actors outsourcing even more parts of the kill-chain to third parties by using/offering MaaS solutions.
sentence.1901: A threat actor can buy several malware from multiple developers, rent the C2 infrastructure from various providers, and deliver the attack vector to victims from yet another provider.
sentence.1902: On the other hand, those providers offering MaaS solutions simplify the entire process through *One Stop Shop* solutions, where one single entity sells and rents both the malware and the infrastructure needed for an attack.
sentence.1903: When profiling e-Crime threat actors, we always deal with the hypothesis that the malware and C2 infrastructure we are analyzing do not belong to the threat actor *per se*, but rather to the used MaaS provider.
sentence.1904: When we confirm the use of a MaaS, the attribution process focuses on *how* and *when* threat actors used it, and *who* they targeted.
sentence.1905: By using such an approach, we were able to differentiate past spear phishing campaigns mistakenly attributed to the Cobalt group and characterize two distinct threat actors — GC01 and GC02 — and the MaaS used by them to carry out their attacks.
sentence.1907: From November 2017 to October 2018, we attributed 14 campaigns to the Golden Chickens (GC) threat actors that used a specific MaaS provider (hereinafter “*the Provider*”) offered by a known individual (hereinafter *“the Provider Operator”*).
sentence.1908: 1.Threat actors buy the service offered and then give the Provider Operator the final payload to be executed on the infected machine.
sentence.1909: 2.The Provider Operator builds the malicious document (maldoc), the backdoor, and prepares the server infrastructure needed for the execution of the attack.
sentence.1910: Next, the backdoor is stored on a webserver and the full URL path of it is embedded into the maldoc. Lastly, the C2 panel that the backdoor will beacon to is set up.
sentence.1911: Although not confirmed, the Provider Operator also likely delivers the access details for the backdoor’s C2 web panel.
sentence.1912: 4.The threat actor disseminates (directly or through the use of a botnet) the maldoc via spear phishing.
sentence.1913: 5.Once the maldoc is executed on a victim’s machine, it will retrieve and execute the backdoor from the hardcoded web location.
sentence.1914: 6.The backdoor beacons to the hardcoded C2 on a regular basis and executes the commands it receives.
sentence.1915: 7.Finally, the threat actor (or the Provider) will review the system details of the infected machine reported by the backdoor, and eventually deploy the final payload.
sentence.1916: Those artifacts are generated by three building kits and offered to paying customers with the supporting C2 infrastructure.
sentence.1917: **VenomKit.** VenomKit is a tool that threat actors can use to craft malicious Rich Text File (RTF) documents that exploit multiple vulnerabilities, including CVE-2017–11882, CVE-2018–0802, and CVE-2018–8174.
sentence.1918: Successful exploitation leads to batch and scriptlet files being dropped and executed in order to download the second stage payload from a Web resource.
sentence.1919: The AV detection rate for RTF documents generated by VenomKit is *moderate* to *high* due to the exploitation of known vulnerabilities.
sentence.1920: **Taurus Builder Kit.** The Taurus Builder Kit generates Microsoft Word documents weaponized with malicious Visual Basic for Application (VBA) macro code.
sentence.1921: Unlike the malicious RTFs created by VenomKit, the weaponized Word documents require user interaction in order to enable the contained malicious code.
sentence.1922: On the other hand, documents generated by this kit are more resilient to AV detection due to the use of multiple layers of obfuscation in the VBA code.
sentence.1923: Once the VBA code is enabled by the user, documents created by Taurus Builder Kit will download and execute additional malware by using multiple legit Windows tools in order to bypass AppLocker.
sentence.1924: **More\_Eggs Backdoor.** More\_eggs is a JavaScript (JS) backdoor capable of beaconing to a fixed C2 server and executing additional payloads downloaded from an external Web resource.
sentence.1925: The backdoor is delivered encrypted inside of another JavaScript, with changing function names, variable names, and encryption keys.
sentence.1926: The more\_eggs building kit allows customization of its multiple variables, for values such as the C2 server, beaconing and sleeping time, and part of the cryptographic key used for ciphering the C2 communications.
sentence.1927: Figure 3 shows an example of more\_eggs configuration that includes the version number *BV*, C2 address *Gate*, and part of the ciphering key used to encrypt C2 communications, *Rkey*.
sentence.1928: For instance, more\_eggs samples attributed to GC02 contained the extra variable *Researchers,* differently from the ones attributed to GC01 or Cobalt Group.
sentence.1929: Although not confirmed, it is reasonable to assume that multiple more\_eggs used by different threat actors cannot share the same *Gate* value due to the derived complication that would imply for the backend to understand which C2 communications belong to which threat actor using the infrastructure.
sentence.1930: However, the same C2 server can host multiple gates by using different web pages; hence, multiple threat actors might use distinct gates hosted on the same domain name.
sentence.1931: The following section highlights the operations and TTPs of three distinct threat actors that have used the Provider in the last year: the Cobalt Group, GC01 and GC02.
sentence.1932: Figure 4 represents the multiple spear phishing campaigns we have attributed to either Cobalt[1] or the Golden Chickens (GC) family during the last year.
sentence.1933: While all GC campaigns used the Provider, only those attributed to Cobalt in May, June, and on 2 August used the Provider.
sentence.1934: 2.**Use of the MaaS.** How the Provider was used, to what extent, and the configuration requested.
sentence.1935: 3.**Final Payload.** What final payload the MaaS delivered.
sentence.1936: Figure 4 — Timeline analysis of attacks conducted by GC family and Cobalt Group
sentence.1937: In May 2018, Cobalt executed three different spear phishing campaigns in between two GC02 campaigns.
sentence.1938: The attacks leveraged the same Provider since they used maldocs generated by either VenomKit or Taurus Building Kit, more\_eggs, and the Provider’s C2 infrastructure.
sentence.1939: Figure 4 also shows that the Cobalt group ceased to use the Provider after the campaign on 2 August, and then started to consistently use different malware and infrastructure.
sentence.1940: Figure 5 — Cobalt and GC campaigns using the Provider
sentence.1941: 1.Delivery.Each campaign began with a spear phishing email, but each presented differences depending on the threat actor behind the attack:
sentence.1942: * GC threat actors used either compromised or spoofed email addresses.
sentence.1943: Furthermore, GC01 targeted companies and organizations operating in the financial industry mainly in Europe, Africa, and Asia.
sentence.1944: Differently, GC02 indiscriminately targeted companies and organizations in at least India and the United States.
sentence.1945: The other 12 spear phishing emails were sent from domain names previously registered by them, imitating a specific organization.
sentence.1946: Registration of look-alike domains is a common technique used by Cobalt Group.
sentence.1947: Lastly, all Cobalt campaigns targeted financial institutions and organizations mainly in Europe, Asia and Middle East.
sentence.1948: 2.Exploitation I (Optional).Both threat actor groups used a non-malicious PDF, luring the user to click on the contained link in order to download the maldoc.
sentence.1949: The attackers used a technique known as [*Google Redirecto*r](https://www.securitysift.com/why-google-makes-my-job-more-difficult/) which consists of appending the malicious URL at the end of a Google logout URL.
sentence.1950: By doing this, the user will first visit the legit Google logout page and then automatically be redirected to the final URL, triggering the download of the malicious document.
sentence.1951: * Cobalt only used this technique two times, during the campaigns of 7 and 29 June.
sentence.1952: It is not clear to us if the Provider Operator offers the non-malicious PDF (with Google Redirector technique) directly or recommends the use of a third-party kit.
sentence.1953: 3.Exploitation II — Getting the Maldoc.The user downloads either a macro-weaponized Word document created by Taurus Builder Kit, or a malicious RTF created by VenomKit.
sentence.1954: Successful execution of the maldocs initiates the download of additional batch scripts and then the ultimate download of the more\_eggs backdoor.
sentence.1955: * Cobalt Group only used more\_eggs versions 2.0, having a specific command named *via\_x*.
sentence.1956: This command is used to execute additional executables via cmd.exe.
sentence.1957: For those campaigns that were not using the non-malicious PDF attack vector, the victims got the downloader through either browsing a link included in the email body, or directly through the email attachment.
sentence.1958: 4.C2 I — Getting the Backdoor.The maldoc retrieves more\_eggs from a remote location and executes it. Next, the backdoor starts beaconing to the C2 defined in the *Gate* variable.
sentence.1959: 5.C2 II — Getting the Final Payload.Once the threat actor (or the Provider Operator) determines that the infected system is of interest, the final payload is eventually pushed and executed.
sentence.1960: To note, we were not always able to get the final payload because the more\_eggs C2 normally has a short lifetime.
sentence.1961: * Campaigns attributed to GC01 resulted in the download of three different RATs: Netwire, Remcos, and Revenge.
sentence.1962: * Campaigns attributed to Cobalt Group resulted in the download of either the CobInt backdoor, or the Cobalt Strike beacon.
sentence.1963: So far, CobInt is a backdoor that was only observed in Cobalt Group campaigns, while Cobalt Strike is a notorious attack framework used to execute Red Team exercises.
sentence.1964: We consider the use of CobInt and Cobalt Strike as a final payload a strong indicator while attributing attacks to the Cobalt Group.
sentence.1965: In general, the continued adoption of threat actors leveraging MaaS plays two roles in the cyber threat landscape: (a) it enables less sophisticated actors to execute attack campaigns against high value targets, which may otherwise be out of scope due to the potentially multi-layer perimeter defenses, and; (b) it creates a cluster of technical indicators from the same infrastructure that complicates attribution efforts.
sentence.1966: During our analysis, we identified three threat actors utilizing one particular MaaS which has operated for almost two years, proving its success and profitability.
sentence.1967: As a result, this scenario of multiple actors using the same MaaS further corroborates why attribution of campaigns incorporating aspects of MaaS becomes more complex to distinguish due to the presumable overlap in technical indicators.
sentence.1968: [1] To note, we only included in the timeline those campaigns attributed to Cobalt group that used the Provider or occurred near or in the same month of GC’s activities.
sentence.1972: New Evidence Might Link Lazarus Tool Found in Chile RedBanc Intrusion to Previous Attacks in Pakistan
sentence.1973: QuoINT has uncovered an attack against a Pakistani financial service provider’s employee that highly matched the Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures (TTPs) [reported](http://www.trendtic.cl/2019/01/exclusivo-asi-fue-el-intento-de-ciberataque-a-redbanc-en-diciembre/) in a recent intrusion at the Chilean interbank network Redbanc [linked by Flashpoint](https://www.flashpoint-intel.com/blog/disclosure-chilean-redbanc-intrusion-lazarus-ties/) to the prolific North Korea-linked Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) group Lazarus (also known as HIDDEN COBRA).
sentence.1974: Further, we uncovered new evidence that might link the November 2018 attacks against multiple Pakistani banks to Lazarus.
sentence.1975: On 16 January 2019, we identified a sample on VirusTotal which is almost identical to the one reportedly used to attack the Chilean financial institution Redbanc in late December 2018.
sentence.1976: The sample, named ApplicationPDF.exe, was uploaded from Pakistan to VirusTotal on January 16 as a part of a ZIP archive, which also contained a generated PDF and the Windows DLL required for its execution.
sentence.1977: The PDF contains what is highly likely the personal information of the targeted victim.[1]
sentence.1978: Further OSINT analysis revealed the victim being an employee at a financial services provider in Pakistan and knowledgeable in financial systems and technologies including Point-of-Sales (POS) and Automated Teller Machine (ATMs).
sentence.1979: The targeted profile matches the one described by Chilean newspapers while detailing the attack against RedBanc.
sentence.1980: The timestamps obtained from analyzing the artifacts place this incident within a period where multiple Pakistani sources reported incidents against the local banking sector, such as the compromise of BankIslami that reportedly resulted in the loss of RS 2.6 million.
sentence.1981: Figure 1 highlights the timeline of malicious activity targeting both Pakistan and Chile.
sentence.1982: * BankIslami reporting suspicious transactions resulting in RS 2.6 of losses (27 October);
sentence.1983: * The date an unknown user located in Chile uploaded the alleged malware sample used to target RedBanc (13 December); and
sentence.1984: * The date the highly likely compromised user in Pakistan submitted the malware sample used to target him (16 January).
sentence.1985: It is unknown, however, if this newly discovered activity is related to any of the publicly reported Pakistani incidents
sentence.1986: According to the reported disclosure of the RedBanc intrusion, the lure begins with a job offer posted to a social media network (LinkedIn).
sentence.1987: The interviewer eventually asks applicants to download and execute a tool (ApplicationPDF.exe) on their computer in order to generate their application form in PDF format.
sentence.1988: The execution of the tool kicks off the infection process.
sentence.1989: Shortly after, we identified a compressed archive also uploaded to VirusTotal containing the exact same sample, along with two additional non-malicious files, one of which is interesting for our victimology efforts.[2]
sentence.1990: **Figure 3** — QuoLab screenshot of the similarity in the kill-chain between tool variants used in Chile and Pakistan
sentence.1991: Similar to the dropper used in the Chilean RedBanc attack, this tool is a GUI program (Figure 4) faking an application form.
sentence.1992: The evidence obtained suggests that the victim executed ApplicationPDF.exe: the compressed archive we found also included the PDF that was most likely generated by the victim.

sentence.1997: PowerRatankba is a PowerShell based reconnaissance tool that conducts initial information gathering from the victim’s system and functions as a backdoor.

sentence.1999: The backdoor functionality provided by the toolkit could enable the actor to deploy further stages of the attack if the victim’s system is deemed interesting.

sentence.2007: * No command executes a batch script
sentence.2008: In December 2017, researchers first discovered and documented [PowerRatankba](https://www.proofpoint.com/us/threat-insight/post/north-korea-bitten-bitcoin-bug-financially-motivated-campaigns-reveal-new).
sentence.2009: Reportedly, the malware is a successor to an earlier implant dubbed Ratankba, used within the Lazarus group’s financially focused attacks.
sentence.2010: We identified an [earlier version](https://www.hybrid-analysis.com/sample/db8163d054a35522d0dec35743cfd2c9872e0eb446467b573a79f84d61761471?environmentId=100) of [PowerRatankba](https://www.proofpoint.com/us/threat-insight/post/north-korea-bitten-bitcoin-bug-financially-motivated-campaigns-reveal-new) submitted to Hybrid Analysis in January 2018, and comparative analysis of the sample in both cases exhibits some aspects of evolution.
sentence.2011: Lazarus is known for continuously evolving its toolset and Tactics, Techniques and Procedures (TTPs).
sentence.2012: Considering the initial attack vector used in Chile also targeted an IT staff member at RedBanc, it is highly likely that the same threat actors would target the above described individual.
sentence.2013: Lazarus is an APT threat actor group that has operated since at least 2009, and attributed to a variety attacks across multiple sectors including financials, and entertainment.
sentence.2014: WINNTI GROUP: Insights From the Past
sentence.2015: Newly uncovered DNS tunnelling technique, and new campaign against South Korean gaming company
sentence.2016: * In January 2020, [QuoIntelligence](https://quointelligence.eu/) (QuoINT) detected a new Winnti sample uploaded to a public virus scanner from a German location.
sentence.2017: * In the following weeks after our internal reporting, the German news media source Tagesschau [reported](https://www.tagesschau.de/investigativ/ndr/hackerangriff-chemieunternehmen-101.html) our initial detection and analysis of the sample, and confirmed the chemical company’s awareness of the attack in the second half of 2019.
sentence.2018: * The Winnti sample we analysed was highly likely developed in 2015, and likely used around this year for the first time, it is unclear how long the compromise existed in the compromised environment.
sentence.2019: * Although the malware was likely used years ago, further analysis revealed a previously unreported C2 technique never attributed to any Winnti Group’s toolkits.
sentence.2020: * The technique relies on a DNS Tunneling communication channel through a custom implementation of the [iodine source code](https://github.com/yarrick/iodine), an open-source software that enables the tunneling of IPv4 data through a DNS server.
sentence.2021: * Additionally, we uncovered a previously unknown stolen digital certificate being used to digitally sign Winnti-related attack components, and the targeting of a previously-unreported South Korean video game company.
sentence.2022: * The sophistication of the techniques we uncovered confirms that the Winnti Group is a highly sophisticated, and highly committed Advanced Persistent Group  targeting a plethora of different industry sectors in Europe and South Asia.
sentence.2023: The Winnti Group (also known as APT41, BARIUM, and Blackfly) is an alleged Chinese state-sponsored umbrella organization in China’s intelligence branch linked through their use of shared goals and attack resources.
sentence.2024: The suspected state-sponsor link to China’s government pinpoints that it likely has an incentive to continue targeting a variety of industries, especially one’s highlighted as priority for China’s economic development.
sentence.2025: On Friday, 13 January, QuoIntelligence (QuoINT) detected a new Winnti sample uploaded to a public virus scanner from a German location.
sentence.2026: Additionally, during our analysis we uncovered a previously unknown stolen digital certificate being used to digitally sign Winnti related drivers, and a potential campaign against an already known South Korean video game company.
sentence.2027: In the last year, researchers and journalists have publicly disclosed that the Winnti group targeted and eventually compromised Henkel (2014), BASF (2015), Bayer (2018) and Roche (2019).
sentence.2028: This most recent previously unreported German chemical company is yet another German chemical company targeted by Winnti since 2015.
sentence.2029: *Figure 1: Timeline of attacks located in Germany and attributed to Winnti*
sentence.2030: In December 2019, Germany’s Federal Office for the Protection of the Constitution (BfV) released a [report](https://www.verfassungsschutz.de/download/broschuere-2019-12-bfv-cyber-brief-2019-01.pdf) related to the alleged Chinese state sponsored umbrella organization known as the Winnti Group.
sentence.2031: Through our internal malware analysis, we are confident that the sample we discovered is highly similar to the Winnti sample described in the BfV report.
sentence.2032: The sample also matches known characteristics of Winnti’s arsenal shared through intelligence reports produced by [ESET](https://www.welivesecurity.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/ESET_Winnti.pdf).
sentence.2034: Notably, various operations attributed to other China-linked threat actor groups, such as APT17 and Ke3chang, have also leveraged its backdoor malware.
sentence.2035: The suspected state-sponsor link to China’s government, pinpoints that it likely has an incentive to continue targeting a variety of industries, especially one’s highlighted as priority for China’s economic development.
sentence.2036: In the latest Winnti Group public report, FireEye researchers [reported](https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2020/03/apt41-initiates-global-intrusion-campaign-using-multiple-exploits.html) of a new widespread campaign attributed to APT41 which involves exploitation attempts of recently disclosed and patched vulnerabilities for products of Cisco, Citrix, and Zoho.
sentence.2037: According to the researchers, identified victim systems demonstrated the threat actor leveraged commercially available post exploitation tools such as Cobalt Strike and Meterpreter, which are essentially full featured backdoors.
sentence.2038: The main artifact uploaded to VirusTotal is a Dynamic Link Library (DLL) file, with a compilation timestamp suggesting the sample was built in August 2015.
sentence.2040: Similar to other Winnti samples, the configuration section contains a string referring to the name of the campaign.
sentence.2042: This is essentially [Windows x64 Driver Signature Enforcement Overrider](https://github.com/hfiref0x/DSEFix) (DSEFix), used   to temporarily disable the driver signature enforcement on Windows systems by using an included old, legit VirtualBox driver, both signed and exploitable.
sentence.2043: By running dsefix.exe, the malware can bypass driver verification and install its own drivers.
sentence.2044: This is the vulnerable, correctly signed with a digital certificate, VirtualBox driver that is used for exploitation.
sentence.2045: It is used regularly by various threat actors, and by the previously highlighted dsefix.exe*.* The driver can also be used to perform the Turla Driver Loader (TDL) exploitation [technique](https://github.com/hfiref0x/TDL), a similar technique as DSEFix.
sentence.2046: In late 2019, [ExaTrack](https://exatrack.com/public/winnti_EN.pdf)released their analysis of a signed Winnti rootkit previously observed in the wild, which we confirm is essentially the same rootkit driver.
sentence.2047: This rootkit driver seems to be largely the same as driver1.sys with the same characteristics including structure, I/O control, and device strings.
sentence.2049: *Figure 3 – observed network IoCs in Winnti sample*
sentence.2050: This IP is pushed into a list that is generated by the malware at runtime. Likely, the initiation routine also populates the list with the system’s DNS, and the OpenDNS server is only used as fallback case to ensure the C2 domain gets resolved.
sentence.2051: Notably, in the last years, multiple researchers have reported Winnti/PlugX C2 hostnames hosted in the mooo[.]com zone.
sentence.2052: Upon further investigation we found out that the malware includes the open source [iodine source code](https://github.com/yarrick/iodine) – software that enables the tunneling of IPv4 data through a DNS server.
sentence.2053: Interestingly, we are not aware of any earlier documentation highlighting Winnti specifically leveraging iodine for DNS tunneling.
sentence.2054: However, researchers at the Ruhr University Bochum, while hunting for DNS tunnels, [observed](https://www.farsightsecurity.com/assets/documents/A_Study_of_Newly_Observed_Hostnames_and_DNS_Tunneling_in_the_Wild.pdf) APT32 and Wekby APT groups using NULL and TXT records as a C2 communication channel, as well as mentioning the mooo[.]com top level domain in their findings.
sentence.2055: The implementation of iodine used in the Winnti sample is integrated and uses some custom wrapper, as evidence by the matching functions we discuss in further detail in the following section.
sentence.2056: **Use of Iodine for C2 DNS Tunneling**
sentence.2057: The iodine DNS tunneling solution is embedded in the DLL that is initially loaded and executed in memory, and includes at least the following 15 matching functions:
sentence.2059: For instance, the 64bit executable contains the build\_hostname function (Code 2), which corresponds with the older 32bit version (compiled with debug symbols) of iodine 0.6.0 (Code 3):
sentence.2062: Further, comparative analysis indicates that for the implementation of iodine in this Winnti attack operation, there is no perfect match for the two versions having 64bit pre-compiled binaries.
sentence.2063: This indicates iodine was compiled from source, and it is reasonable it is being used as a library, and not in its normal distribution format of a standalone executable.
sentence.2064: The DNS Tunneling technique adopted by the malware through the use of iodine is detailed in the figure below.
sentence.2066: 1.The malware generates a hostname and appends it to the embedded C2 dick[.]mooo[.]com, and makes a NULL query to the resulted FQDN (e.g. abcde is appended to .dick[.]mooo[.]com).
sentence.2067: Notably, NULL and TXT DNS request types are iodine’s preferred channels since they are “[*expected to provide the largest downstream bandwidth*](https://github.com/yarrick/iodine)”.
sentence.2068: It is hence not a coincidence that researchers at Ruhr University Bochum also observed an extensive use of NULL request types for DNS Tunneling purposes in their research.
sentence.2069: 2.The infected host sends the DNS query to one of the DNS servers included in the list populated at runtime, eventually to the OpenDNS fallback server.
sentence.2070: At this point the DNS server executes a recursive DNS query by contacting the Name Servers (NS) of each zone, until the Authoritative NS of dick[.]mooo[.]com is obtained.
sentence.2071: To note, FreeDNS does provide users the capability to delegate the authority of their subdomains to external NS. In the described scenario, attackers delegated the NS of their subdomain to use their NS as a de-facto C2 server.
sentence.2072: Notably, the legit DNS server acts as a proxy between the infected host and the malicious server, by making impossible for defenders the application of any filtering at the Network (L3) level.
sentence.2074: According to [common.h](https://github.com/yarrick/iodine/blob/27e5d6fadd997ff167c70a431d41adae26428d41/src/common.h#L86), “struct query” is defined as:
sentence.2075: Since QUERY\_NAME\_SIZE equals to 512  (4 *128 – integers are 4 bytes) the query[128] call obtained from the reversing activity is indeed the DNS query type.
sentence.2077: ### Winnti Signed Code With Digital Certificate from IQ Technology
sentence.2078: During our analysis of the Winnti sample configured to target the German chemical company, our comparative analysis of other Winnti related drivers revealed a digital certificate issued to *IQ Technology*, a Taiwanese company producing Natural language processing (NLP) and Artificial Intelligence (AI) software.
sentence.2079: The rootkit driver aligns with the already known driver1.sys*.* While it is a known TTP that Winnti attributed attacks have involved stolen digital certificates for code signing its malware components, the use of this certificate is not publicly discussed, except for a brief report from a security researcher apparently associated with a Vietnamese security company.
sentence.2080: *Table 3 – observed network IoCs in Winnti sample*
sentence.2081: On 21 February, we detected the new submission of a 64-bit Winnti executable to a public online malware scanning service.
sentence.2082: As multiple researchers have reported, Winnti operators embed the name of their target directly into the malware, but in an obfuscated manner.
sentence.2083: The sample resembles the Winnti Dropper Install.exe described by ESET, since it is a command line executable used to drop and load additional encrypted payload:
sentence.2084: Unfortunately we were not able to find the payload meant to be decrypted by this dropper.
sentence.2085: Based on previous knowledge and targeting of the Winnti Group, we assess that this sample was likely used to target Gravity Co., Ltd., a South Korean video game company.
sentence.2086: As we have also reported in the past, the video game industry is one of the preferred targets of the Winnti Group, especially for those companies operating in South Korea and Taiwan.
sentence.2087: Interestingly, ESET researchers, while reporting on multiple Winnti Group campaigns targeting the video game industry, listed in their report a C2 server having a Campaign ID ***GRA** KR 0629*.
sentence.2088: *Excerpt from ESET Research White paper “*[*CONNECTING THE DOTS Exposing the arsenal and methods of the Winnti Group*](https://www.welivesecurity.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/ESET_Winnti.pdf)*”*
sentence.2089: At this time, we do not have any further evidence supporting a potential link between the sample we analysed and the C2 detailed by ESET, but the coincidence between the C2 Campaign ID/Location with the Campaign ID we extracted from the Winnti dropper is worth noting.
sentence.2090: The Winnti Group has exhibited their ability to breach different organizations and conduct sophisticated attack operations, typically motivated by espionage and financial gain, with various TTPs and malware toolkits.
sentence.2091: While attribution is not concrete due to the complexity of the group, there are links that can be drawn between operations which suggest the threat actors purporting the attacks are likely operating within the Winnti Group, or at least sharing resources.
sentence.2092: The detection of this unreported Winnti variant uploaded to VirusTotal and targeting a German chemical company aligns with our prior observations and research from [previous intelligence reporting](https://web.br.de/interaktiv/winnti/index.html)highlighting Winnti Group’s interest in German DAX companies.
sentence.2093: As a result, organizations of all sizes, but especially small to medium sized companies, including Germany’s *hidden champions*, should prepare against such threats as they are vital to the economic ecosystem and continuous development of niche markets.

sentence.2101: The [European Central Bank](https://www.ecb.europa.eu/home/html/index.en.html) (ECB) developed the TIBER-EU framework to address exactly this: to test an organization’s critical live production services based on real-life and current attack scenarios pertaining specifically to the tested organization.
sentence.2102: The ECB published the TIBER-EU framework in 2018 and several European countries are currently implementing the framework.
sentence.2103: While the individual testing is bespoke to each organization, the test is undertaken based on a standardized framework created by the ECB and applied by each member state.
sentence.2104: * **Provide guidance to authorities** on how they might establish, implement, and manage this form of testing at a national or European level
sentence.2105: In Germany, the Bundesbank is currently establishing the TIBER-DE framework, which is compatible with German regulations.

sentence.2109: Given the interconnectedness of the European financial system, successful cyber incidents at one organization can potentially impact the wider European system and, in the worst case, affect the European economy.
sentence.2110: BlackWater Malware Leveraging Beirut Tragedy in New Targeted Campaign
sentence.2111: * [QuoIntelligence](https://quointelligence.eu/) discovered a new targeted campaign delivering the novel BlackWater malware
sentence.2112: * The campaign used the Beirut incident to lure the targets, with an attempt to spoof an official OSCE report
sentence.2113: * The campaign was launched on 5 August, only one day after the Beirut incident.
sentence.2114: The provider hosting the attack infrastructure promptly shot down the C2 servers after our notification on 7 August
sentence.2115: * The attack used state-of-the-art techniques, such as DNS over HTTPs (DoH)
sentence.2116: * Based on the advanced TTPs and the discovered targets, we classify the threat actor as an Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) group named “ReconHellcat”
sentence.2117: * Observed ReconHellcat targets consist of -at least- defense and diplomatic government bodies in Bulgaria and Azerbaijan
sentence.2118: On 6 August, QuoIntelligence discovered a malicious file uploaded to VirusTotal using the Beirut incident as a theme to lure the targets.
sentence.2119: Further analysis attributed the analysed artifact to BlackWater: [a recently-discovered](https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/blackwater-malware-abuses-cloudflare-workers-for-c2-communication/) malware that uses [Cloudflare Workers](https://blog.cloudflare.com/cloudflare-workers-unleashed/) as a C2 communication interface and DNS over HTTPS (DoH) as name resolution channel.
sentence.2120: Cloudflare promptly shutdown the C2 servers after our notification.
sentence.2121: On 5 August, a compressed archive was uploaded to [VirusTotal](https://www.virustotal.com/gui/file/b4ed39b6852bce329686ec44e2e8e39b1c0be9b7095cec2e1682e6e2ef724c69) from Azerbaijan, containing a malicious, macro-enabled Word Document (maldoc) themed for the recent explosion in Beirut.
sentence.2122: The name of the maldoc (*047-20 – OSCE Report Beirut explosion.doc*) might indicate attackers’ intent to spoof the [Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe](https://www.osce.org/) (OSCE), however, we discovered that attackers weaponized a legit Word document available in the web portal of the [Organismo Supervisor de las Contrataciones del Estado](https://www.gob.pe/en/osce) (OSCE), which is a supervisory body of the Peruvian Ministry of Economy.
sentence.2123: The image below shows the comparison between the maldoc and the legit Word file from the Peruvian OCSE available in their website.
sentence.2124: The maldoc contains an obfuscated macro that retrieves the second-stage encrypted payload from one of the three hardcoded C2 URLs depending on the user’s Windows version.
sentence.2125: To decrypt the payload, attackers implemented the old-fashion substitution cipher technique *[Book cipher](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Book_cipher)*using the legit Windows file `C:\Windows\Fonts\cambriab.tff` as key.
sentence.2126: To note that the content of this file differs depending on the Windows version , this is why the malicious macro checks the Windows version at the beginning of its execution, and contacts a specific URL depending of the result of this check.
sentence.2127: Finally, the decrypted payload is written in `%APPDATA%\\Microsoft\Word\STARTUP\Moon.wll` .
sentence.2128: Finally, the decrypted payload is written in `%APPDATA%\\Microsoft\Word\STARTUP\Moon.wll`.
sentence.2129: By storing a Word add-in in such path allows Microsoft Word to load and execute it a malicious payload whenever it is launched.
sentence.2130: Although this technique ([T1137/006](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1137/006/)) was firstly documented by F-Secure in 2017, only this year researchers publicly reported two APT groups firstly using it: [Naikon APT](https://research.checkpoint.com/2020/naikon-apt-cyber-espionage-reloaded/) and [Vicious Panda](https://research.checkpoint.com/2020/vicious-panda-the-covid-campaign/).
sentence.2131: The malicious `Moon.wll`contains another encrypted set of three different C2 URLs, and once executed by Word, it downloads an encrypted x64 executable as the final backdoor.
sentence.2132: The decryption technique used to decrypt the x64 backdoor still uses the Windows font file as key, however, the C2 URL is passed as an encrypted parameter which is decrypted via a different substitution cipher relying on an hardcoded alphabet as a key.
sentence.2133: Finally, the Blackwater backdoor starts communicating with the Clouldflare Worker via JSON.
sentence.2134: Notably, both the loader and the backdoor resolve the C2 hostnames via DNS-over-HTTP (DoH) by using a built-in feature of libcurl.
sentence.2135: Only the malicious Macro is using the system’s default DNS server to get the first-stage payload.
sentence.2136: To note that all the samples we have analysed had a very low AV detection rate when they were firstly uploaded to VirusTotal.
sentence.2137: The C2 infrastructure was hosted on Cloudflare Workers platform, which is a service enabling users to register a subdomain and then have serverless code running to handle requests.
sentence.2138: Our technical findings overlap with the Tactics, Techniques and Procedures (TTPs) previously attributed to the BlackWater malware campaign first identified in March:
sentence.2142: * C2 hosted on Cloudflare Workers service
sentence.2143: As shown in the picture below, the analysis of the x64 sample revealed multiple strings containing the word “BlackWater”.
sentence.2144: We researched the targets of both BlackWater campaigns (March and August) and concluded that -at least- defense and diplomatic government bodies in Bulgaria and Azerbaijan were highly likely targeted.
sentence.2145: Based on the advanced TTPs and the targeted institutions we classify the threat actor as an Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) group.
sentence.2146: Since we have not found yet any solid overlap with any already-known APT group, we are naming the attackers behind the two BlackWater campaigns as “ReconHellcat”.
sentence.2147: APT28 Delivers Zebrocy Malware Campaign using NATO Theme as Lure
sentence.2148: * On 9 August, [QuoIntelligence](https://quointelligence.eu/) detected an ongoing APT28 campaign, which likely started on 5 August.
sentence.2149: * The malware used in the attack was the Zebrocy Delphi version.
sentence.2150: All the artifacts had very low Anti-Virus (AV) detection rates on VirusTotal when they were first submitted.
sentence.2151: * At the time of the discovery, the C2 infrastructure hosted in France was still live.
sentence.2152: * The campaign used NATO’s upcoming trainings as a lure.
sentence.2153: * The campaign targeted a specific government body in Azerbaijan, however; it is likely that attackers also targeted NATO members or other countries involved in NATO exercises.
sentence.2154: * Analysis revealed interesting correlations with ReconHell/BlackWater attack, which we [uncovered](https://quointelligence.eu/2020/08/blackwater-malware-leveraging-beirut-tragedy-in-new-targeted-campaign/) in August.
sentence.2155: * As part of our responsible disclosure, we reported our findings to French authorities for taking down the C2, and to NATO for their awareness.
sentence.2156: On 9 August, QuoIntelligence disseminated a Warning to its government customers about a new APT28 (*aka* Sofacy, Sednit, Fancy Bear, STRONTIUM, etc.
sentence.2157: campaign targeting government bodies of [NATO](https://www.nato.int/) members (or countries cooperating with NATO).
sentence.2158: In particular, we found a malicious file uploaded to VirusTotal, which ultimately drops a Zebrocy malware and communicates with a C2 in France.
sentence.2159: After our discovery, we reported the malicious C2 to the French law enforcement as part of our responsible disclosure process.
sentence.2160: Zebrocy is a malware used by APT28 (also known as Sofacy), which was reported by multiple security firms[[1]](#_ftn1)[[2]](#_ftn2)[[3]](#_ftn3)[[4]](#_ftn4)[[5]](#_ftn5)[[6]](#_ftn6) in the last two years.
sentence.2161: Finally, our investigation concluded that the attack started on 5 August and targeted at least a government entity located in the Middle East.
sentence.2162: However, it is highly likely that NATO members also observed the same attack.
sentence.2163: In fact, if the file is renamed as a JPG, the Operating System will show the logo of the Supreme Headquarters Allied Powers Europe ([SHAPE](https://shape.nato.int/)), which is the NATO’s Allied Command Operations (ACO) located in Belgium.
sentence.2164: This technique works because JPEG files are parsed from the beginning of the file and some Zip implementations parse Zip files from the end of the file (since the index is located there) without looking at the signature in the front.
sentence.2165: The technique is also used by threat actors to evade AVs, or other filtering systems since they might mistake the file for a JPEG and skip it.
sentence.2166: Interestingly, in order to trigger the decompression of the file on Windows after the user clicks on it, the following conditions need to be met:  a) the file must be correctly named .zip(x); b) the file needs to be opened with WinRAR. The file will show an error message claiming it is corrupted if the targeted victim uses WinZip or the default Windows utility.
sentence.2168: Considering the lure uses a NATO image, the attackers likely picked the filenames in order to leverage upcoming [NATO courses](https://www.natoschool.nato.int/Academics/Portfolio/Course-Catalogue#2aid-aid) in October 2020.
sentence.2169: Additionally, the Excel file (XLS) is corrupted and cannot be opened by Microsoft Excel, it contains – what seems to be – information about military personnel involved in the military mission “African Union Mission for Somalia”.
sentence.2170: The rationale could be that the attacker makes the user attempt to first open the XLS file, and then open the .exe with the same filename as a second try.

sentence.2206: ReconHellcat Uses NIST Theme as Lure To Deliver New BlackSoul Malware
sentence.2207: On 27 November, QuoIntelligence detected a new malware, seemingly uploaded to VirusTotal by a user in Turkmenistan, which shares multiple similarities to the threat actor we previously dubbed ReconHellcat.
sentence.2208: The campaign ultimately delivers a **previously undocumented remote access Trojan (RAT), which we dubbed *BlackSoul*.** After promptly alerting our customers, we notified Cloudflare about the C2 infrastructure hosted on their [Workers service](https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=&cad=rja&uact=8&ved=2ahUKEwjk96Lux4buAhXUGFkFHeTyDCQQFjAAegQIARAC&url=https%3A%2F%2Fworkers.cloudflare.com%2F&usg=AOvVaw2Zt-uFSsvY_asdQQ5FHkKr) as per our responsible disclosure process.
sentence.2209: Further analysis revealed the malware being part of a targeted campaign, that likely originated with a spear phishing email delivering a [CAB](https://www.virustotal.com/gui/file/690872b8d0205203029b2b388b27f15a7673e9c02dab99f76216efc4a305cd4c/detection) archive.
sentence.2210: Both the CAB and the file contained within are named 1-10-20-hb44\_final to impersonate one of the documents available on the [National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST)](https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=&cad=rja&uact=8&ved=2ahUKEwjzuM7Vy4buAhUjGFkFHS83CiAQFjAAegQIARAD&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nist.gov%2F&usg=AOvVaw0908J5PhTOUQuVLJt9JE9z) website.
sentence.2211: *Figure 2: Legitimate NIST document URL and filename*
sentence.2212: During our analysis, we determined 1-10-20-hb44\_final.exe is a malicious loader, which uses obfuscation similar to the variant observed in the previously [reported](https://quointelligence.eu/2020/08/blackwater-malware-leveraging-beirut-tragedy-in-new-targeted-campaign/) ReconHellcat campaign delivering BlackWater malware.
sentence.2213: Another similarity is that the loader utilizes C2 infrastructure hosted on the Cloudflare Workers service.
sentence.2214: Following a successful C2 connection, the loader retrieves two files: (1) an executable named *blacksoul*, and (2) a Dynamic-Link Library (DLL) named *blacksoulLib*. Additionally, the loader opens Microsoft Word with the aforementioned legitimate document from the NIST website. Essentially, ReconHellcat uses this legitimate document as a decoy.
sentence.2216: The second stage executable is a newly observed malware family, which we linked to the ReconHellcat threat actor.
sentence.2217: We named the malware “BlackSoul” to match its internal name, main class name, and file name.
sentence.2219: The malware is a classical minimal RAT, which is capable of file transfers and running arbitrary commands.
sentence.2220: Through static analysis, we determined that the executable’s main loop supports handling the following commands from its C2 server:
sentence.2221: | **3** | paths | Likely retrieves a specified file from the machine and uploads it to the C2.
sentence.2222: | **3** | paths | Likely retrieves aspecified file from the machine and uploads it to the C2.
sentence.2223: | **4** | config | Updates the configuration file (UsrClass.json) which contains C2 server info and miscellaneous fields.

sentence.2226: It is unclear if this file is mandatory or merely used to save existing configurations between invocations of BlackSoul.
sentence.2227: BlackSoul uses information gathered by blacksoulLib to call back to the C2 over the RESTful Strapi protocol and JSON based data encoding.
sentence.2228: The RAT’s string obfuscation applies only to strings in the main program but excludes strings of third-party compiled in libraries.
sentence.2229: BlackSoul additionally uses various other techniques for obfuscation.
sentence.2230: In particular, strings are constructed dynamically on the stack and deobfuscated with a variety of mechanisms, such as a fixed key XOR cipher and a Caesar cipher using variable shift values.
sentence.2231: The file is a DLL with a single export, Init(), which is called by BlackSoul.

sentence.2240: However, it is likely that the BlackSoul campaign targeted a government-related body based on the theme lure, since NIST develops and publicizes security compliance standard for the US Federal Government and any organization who handles government data.
sentence.2241: As well, previously observed ReconHellcat campaign targets consisted of primarily defense and diplomatic government bodies.
sentence.2242: When we initially discovered ReconHellcat, its campaign characteristics and Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures (TTPs) were unique enough to classify it as a new threat actor.
sentence.2243: During our analysis of the new BlackSoul campaign, we identified limited yet sufficient similarities overlapping with the earlier observed BlackWater campaign.
sentence.2244: As a result, we have high confidence attributing this attack to ReconHellcat.

sentence.2267: Taurus: The New Stealer in Town
sentence.2268: A sandbox is a valuable tool in the ongoing battle against cybercriminals and bad actors are continually looking for ways to avoid detection.
sentence.2269: One of the newest ones we observed, Taurus, includes techniques to evade sandbox detection.
sentence.2270: Was this new malware able to go undetected by the [Zscaler Cloud Sandbox](/products/sandboxing).
sentence.2271: Let's take a closer look at the Taurus stealer.
sentence.2272: In early June 2020, we observed and began tracking a new malware campaign.
sentence.2273: During our research, we observed that the "Predator the Thief" cybercriminal group is behind the development of this stealer, named Taurus, and is selling it on dark forums for $100 or rebuilt with a new domain for $20.
sentence.2274: The group selling Taurus claims that this stealer is capable of stealing passwords, cookies, and autofill forms along with the history of Chromium- and Gecko-based browsers.
sentence.2275: Taurus can also steal some popular cryptocurrency wallets, commonly used FTP clients credentials, and email clients credentials.
sentence.2276: This stealer also collects information, such as installed software and system configuration, and sends that information back to the attacker.
sentence.2277: Taurus is designed to not execute in countries within the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS), which includes Azerbaijan, Armenia, Belarus, Georgia, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Moldova, Russia, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan, and Ukraine.
sentence.2278: (Turkmenistan and Ukraine are both unofficial members of the organization.
sentence.2279: Georgia was a member of the CIS but left the group in 2008.
sentence.2281: *Figure 1: Infection cycle of the Taurus campaign*
sentence.2282: While tracking the campaign, we noticed that attackers initiated this campaign by sending a spam mail to the victim containing a malicious attachment.
sentence.2283: Below are the details of the spam mail we observed:
sentence.2284: The attachment (pay-violation1011066.doc) contained malicious macro code to download further payloads.
sentence.2286: *Figure 2: The attached malicious doc asks users to enable a macro.*
sentence.2287: Once the document is opened, it prompts the user to enables the macro.
sentence.2288: Once the content is enabled, an AutoOpen() subroutine is called, which will run the malicious Visual Basic for Applications (VBA) macro wherein a PowerShell script is executed via BitsTransfer, downloads three different files of the **Taurus Project** from the Github site, then saves them in a Temp folder with predefined names.
sentence.2291: The macro contains the URL of the payload as a combination of the following obfuscations: Base64 encoded and reversed string.
sentence.2293: *Figure 4: The decrypted PowerShell script used to download the payload.*
sentence.2294: Further, these three files get downloaded from Github and dropped in the %Temp% directory.
sentence.2295: 3.**wsNcf.com** → saved with the name **“wsNcf.com”** → Taurus Stealer
sentence.2296: Here, PowerShell is using the Certutil.exe command to decode the payload and execute it on the victim's machine.
sentence.2297: The Twitter handle [@3xp0rt](https://twitter.com/3xp0rtblog/status/1254079067810336768), which exposes documents from a Russian hacking forum, shows some of the claims of the Taurus project.

sentence.2299: *Figure 5: The Taurus project claims to have the stealing ability of malware.*
sentence.2300: The author claims that Taurus has the following stealing capabilities:
sentence.2301: * Stealing cookies, Auto-form details, browsing history, and credit card information from Chromium- and Gecko-based browsers.
sentence.2302: * Cookies and passwords from Microsoft Edge browsers.
sentence.2303: * Credential stealing of some cryptocurrency wallets, including Electrum, MultiBit, Ethereum, Jaxx Liberty, Bytecoin, Atomic, and Exodus
sentence.2304: * Stealing credential of FTP clients, including FileZilla, WinFTP, and WinSCP
sentence.2305: * Stealing session files from applications, including Discord, Steam, Telegram, and Authy
sentence.2306: * Collects system information, such as system configuration and list of installed software.
sentence.2309: The Taurus project has also built a dashboard where the attacker can keep an eye on the infection counts according to geolocations.
sentence.2311: *Figure 7: The Taurus d[ashboard](https://twitter.com/MalwareInt/status/1257838534993621002/photo/3) to see infection count according to geolocation.*
sentence.2312: This dashboard also provides the attacker with the ability to customize the configuration of Taurus.
sentence.2314: *Figure 8: The attacker can update the configuration of Taurus in the [dashboard](https://twitter.com/3xp0rtblog/status/1254079343581675525/photo/2).*
sentence.2316: Once PowerShell downloads the three different files from the GitHub repository, it uses the utility “Certutil.exe” to decode the payload.
sentence.2317: Then, Certutil.exe decrypts the second file, which is a Base64-encoded AutoIT file having a certificate as a header.
sentence.2318: This AutoIT file will decrypt the third file, which is the Taurus Stealer.
sentence.2319: After deobfuscating the AutoIT script, we noticed that it has multiple anti-sandbox techniques.
sentence.2320: It checks for the Sleep patch in the sandbox using the GetTickCount function.
sentence.2322: *Figure 9: The anti-sandbox patch with the GetTickCount API.*
sentence.2323: ![Multiple check for files, computer name & internet connectivity](/cdn-cgi/image/format=auto/sites/default/files/images/blogs/Taurus%20Project/Multiple%20check%20for%20files%2C%20computer%20name%20%26%20internet%20connectivity.png)
sentence.2324: *Figure 10: Taurus performs multiple checks for files, the computer name, and internet connectivity.*
sentence.2325: Finally, the AutoIT script reads and decodes the **wsNcf.com** file, then loads the deobfuscated shellcode for injecting the decoded payload into dllhost.exe.

sentence.2329: *Figure 12: The shellcode checking for the executable to inject in the dllhost.exe.*

sentence.2354: Deep Dive Into the M00nD3V Logger
sentence.2355: ThreatLabZ observed a **multifunctional** information-stealing Trojan named "**M00nD3V Logger''** that is being dropped by a multistage loader.
sentence.2356: Due to its multiple stealing features, **M00nD3V Logger** has gradually gained popularity on hacking forums.
sentence.2357: Recently [Blueliv](https://www.blueliv.com/cyber-security-and-cyber-threat-intelligence-blog-blueliv/covid-19-cybercrime-m00nd3v-hawkeye-malware-threat-actor/) published a blog discussing the relationship of M00nD3V with the HawkEye stealer, along with information about the bad actor selling M00nD3V.
sentence.2358: Aside from keystroke logging, the M00nD3VLoggerhas the ability to steal confidential information such as browser passwords, FTP client passwords, email client passwords, DynDNS credentials, JDownloader credentials and capture Windows Keystrokes, as well as gain access to the webcam and hook the clipboard.
sentence.2359: In all, it has the ability to steal passwords from 42 applications.
sentence.2360: M00nD3VLogger is also equipped with other major functionality, including a botkiller, an antivirus killer, communicating over SMTP/FTP/proxy, downloading additional plugins, and the BouncyCastle crypto package.
sentence.2361: During our research, we found M00nD3V was delivered via spam mail or through a compromised website that drops a payload on the victim's machine.
sentence.2362: One such spam mail claims to be from "Hyundai Heavy Industries Co., Ltd" regarding a bid on a project for Qatargas.
sentence.2363: The spam mail includes zip attachments that contain malicious executables.
sentence.2365: *Figure 3: M00nD3V Logger subscription and payment method pages.*
sentence.2366: In this blog, we will provide a detailed technical analysis of commercial M00nD3V Logger malware.
sentence.2367: Delivering malware without triggering any suspicious activity while blending into an existing benign Windows process makes detection a bit harder.
sentence.2368: Here, the M00nD3V malware does one such trick to deliver its payload without getting easily noticed.
sentence.2369: *Figure 4: The M00nD3V malware register running with RegAsm.exe* - *Microsoft utility.*
sentence.2370: Figure 4 shows the post execution of the malware.
sentence.2371: Hence, the malware can do its job on the fly without getting caught.
sentence.2372: The malware also runs by elevating its own privileges.
sentence.2373: The malware unpacks the encrypted payload using multibyte XOR decryption.
sentence.2374: While unpacking, the malware also uses null bytes in the XOR key.
sentence.2376: Even though key length is 24, the malware uses only the first 16 bytes to decrypt the resource section of the encrypted data.
sentence.2377: The above decryption routine results in a .NET PE file.
sentence.2378: In this dumped file, there is also a similar XOR routine to decrypt the data but with a different key to run the final payload.
sentence.2379: We have written a Python script to decrypt the encrypted payload, which can be found in Appendix I and Appendix II.
sentence.2380: StubConfig Class contains the configuration details - some of them are initialized with Base64 values while others are hardcoded.
sentence.2381: Before starting to log user data, the M00nD3V Logger initializes its configuration.
sentence.2382: The initialization phase includes several checks, such as an anti-debugger, a bot killer, an antivirus killer, and more.
sentence.2383: * DependencyLoader - Downloads the DLL from m00nd3v[.]com/M00nD3v/Decryption/BouncyCastle[.]Crypto.dll and loads it in memory.
sentence.2384: * Persistence - Copies the parent file to AppData directory and begins the startup entry [SOFTWARE\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\Run].
sentence.2385: * Antidebugger - Checks to see if any of the following processes are running: SbieDll.dll, Wireshark, Winsock Packet Editor.
sentence.2386: If any are found, the malware terminates.
sentence.2387: * Antivirus killer - Uses Image File Execution Options (IFEO) to interfere with the executables shown in Figure 10.
sentence.2388: By modifying the registry entry  [Software\\Microsoft\\Windows NT\\CurrentVersion\\Image File Execution Options\\], the malware attaches rundll32.exe as debugger to each of the executables.
sentence.2389: This way, it disables all the listed applications to run.
sentence.2390: * Process elevation - As shown in Figure 11, the malware contains a process elevation module, which is responsible for elevating the privilege of the malware executable.
sentence.2391: The malware sets the security identifier type as "WorldSid" with AceQualifier AccessDenied.
sentence.2392: Before starting to log the stored credentials and other personal data, it checks whether the malware was previously installed or not on the victim's machine by looking for a specific file name with a combination of Processor Id and Volume Serial Number in the temp directory.
sentence.2393: The malware has three kinds of communication methods to send logged data: SMTP, FTP, and proxy.
sentence.2394: But this stub is configured to use only and send data over SMTP only.
sentence.2395: If the value is not set in config, then it won't execute the "keystroke functionality".
sentence.2396: As shown in Figure 14, the Stub is configured to execute the keystroke but not the webcam as the webcam value is not assigned.
sentence.2397: The Stub starts its core stealing functionality by sending full victim machine information, as shown in Figure 15**,** to the attacker over SMTP port 587
sentence.2398: *Figure 15: Basic machine information sent to the attacker.*
sentence.2399: The malware communicates with the attacker over SMTP using port 587.
sentence.2400: The malware crafts an email with the captured details shown in Figure 16 and sends it to the attacker.
sentence.2401: The attackers use "**smtp.privateemail.com"** service to transfer the captured data.
sentence.2403: The **LogTypeName** mentioned below is used to tag the data to inform the attacker what module it is running currently.
sentence.2404: While uploading data over FTP, it first converts plain text data to bytes and creates FTP requests by configuring all the FTP request fields (i.e., ftp\_host, credentials, method).
sentence.2405: The FTP method used to upload files is "STOR".
sentence.2407: The malware sets the proxy URL from the config class and uploads the below-mentioned data using the POST method.
sentence.2409: **Password stealer:** M00nD3V Logger has the capability to steal passwords and cookies from all possible browsers and email clients, as well as FTP clients.
sentence.2410: Interestingly, the malware has three separate classes named "ChromiumProvider", "MailProvider", and "MozillaProvider" as shown in Figure 21.
sentence.2411: The malware first tries to decrypt the password with the data protection APT (DPAPI) library.
sentence.2412: But if it isn't successful, then it attempts to decrypt the passwords using "**BouncyCastle**", which the malware downloaded from "m00nd3v.]com/]M00nD3v/Decryption/BouncyCastle.Crypto.dll".
sentence.2413: It includes "**GcmBlockCipher**" and "**AeadParameters**" classes, whose instances help the malware decrypt the final password.
sentence.2414: The collected passwords are sent to the attacker over SMTP.
sentence.2415: *Figure 23: The collected passwords sent over SMTP.*
sentence.2416: The malware has the capability to secretly access the device's webcam and capture the image.
sentence.2417: The malware copies the captured image onto the clipboard, extracts the image from clipboard, then saves it in the temp directory.
sentence.2418: To send stolen images over SMTP, it reads the image path and attaches the .bmp image as an email attachment with a personalize the subject line, such as "**Dear M00nD3v user Please find the attachment of Webcam. Regards M00nD3v"**
sentence.2419: Similarly, the other modules named keystrokes, clipboard, and screen sender, execute with individual threads and send stolen data to the attacker, then sleep for some period of time before repeating the same stealing process.
sentence.2420: *Figure 24: The Zscaler Cloud Sandbox report for the M00nD3V Logger.*
