sentence.2441: New Voicemail-Themed Phishing Attacks Use Evasion Techniques and Steal Credentials
sentence.2442: Through the intelligence gathered from the Zscaler cloud, we discovered several newly registered domains that use VoIP and voicemail as themes for their credential-stealing phishing campaigns.
sentence.2443: In the most recent instance we saw, attackers were spoofing Cisco’s Unity Connection voicemail platform.
sentence.2444: The use of voicemail delivered in an email message, and the use of phishing pages that spoof enterprise applications, such as Office 365 and Outlook, signal the attackers’ motives.
sentence.2445: If successful in obtaining a user’s credentials, attackers can access confidential data from the enterprise, potentially selling it or holding it for ransom.
sentence.2446: The attacks are being distributed through email with an HTML attachment that contains JavaScript code which redirects the user to the credential phishing site.
sentence.2447: Contents of the email are crafted to mimic a system-generated voicemail notification, luring the user to open the attachment to access the recorded voice message as shown in Figure 1.
sentence.2448: *Figure 1: Email message spoofing a voicemail notification*
sentence.2450: We observed different variants of HTML attachments used in these credential-phishing campaigns.
sentence.2451: The email attachment is an HTML file that contains a short code snippet of JavaScript.
sentence.2452: It uses *window.location.replace()* to redirect the user to the phishing site, as shown in Figure 2.
sentence.2453: * All these HTML attachments have a very low detection rate on VirusTotal as shown in Figure 3 below.
sentence.2454: Figure 3: No detection against AV engines, as seen on VirusTotal
sentence.2455: In the second variant, the HTML attachment contains JavaScript code that is used to decode the next-stage HTML.
sentence.2457: The decoded content shown in Figure 5 uses the meta-refresh tag to redirect the user to the target credential phishing site.
sentence.2458: *Figure 5: Decoded content which uses meta-refresh tag to redirect*
sentence.2460: In a few variants of the phishing landing pages, we observed that the final landing page used an external JavaScript to display the credential-phishing page in the browser.
sentence.2461: Figure 6 shows the source code of the phishing page; the highlighted part is the external JavaScript used to display the phishing content.
sentence.2462: All of these external JavaScript files use long filenames of 32 characters resembling an MD5 hash.
sentence.2463: *Figure 6: Phishing landing page referencing an externally hosted JavaScript to load phishing content*
sentence.2464: Unlike common credential-phishing landing pages, we can see in this case that there is no information related to the brand being targeted.
sentence.2465: This allows the threat actors to bypass many automated URL analysis engines and extend its survival.
sentence.2466: Figure 7 shows the relevant JavaScript code and where the user’s credentials are being sent.
sentence.2467: This code is present in randomly named and externally hosted JavaScript files.
sentence.2468: *Figure 7: JavaScript file used to send user’s credentials to attacker’s server*
sentence.2469: Figure 8 shows a sample packet capture which highlights the method used to exfiltrate the stolen credentials to the attacker’s site.
sentence.2470: It is important to note that in the first attempt, this phishing page will always give the "password incorrect" message, which prompts users to enter their passwords more cautiously the next time.
sentence.2471: *Figure 8: Packet capture showing credentials being exfiltrated*
sentence.2472: In one of the campaigns related to voicemail, attackers used Google’s reCAPTCHA on the landing page to evade automated URL analysis, as shown in Figures 9 and 10.
sentence.2473: *Figure 9: Google’s reCAPTCHA used for evading automated URL analysis*
sentence.2474: *Figure 10: Google reCAPTCHA used as a security challenge on the phishing page for evasion*
sentence.2475: Users will be redirected to the main credential-phishing page after solving the captcha.
sentence.2476: The final phishing page spoofs the Microsoft Office 365 login page, as shown in Figures 11 and 12.
sentence.2477: *Figure 11: Credential-phishing landing page to steal Office 365 credentials*
sentence.2479: Below is a list of domains we identified that were registered between June and mid-July 2020 and were used by the threat actor(s) for conducting credential-phishing campaigns using the voicemail theme.
sentence.2480: * The URL pattern used for credential phishing is: hxxp://domain\_name.xyz/?e=<email\_address>
sentence.2481: * If the URL is accessed directly without the email address in the URL as a parameter, the user will be redirected to the office.com site
sentence.2483: On July 6, 2020, we observed in the Zscaler cloud several connection attempts to the domain: *secure.ciscovoicemail.cf* which is a site created by the threat actor to spoof Cisco’s Unity Connection voicemail portal, as shown in Figure 13.
sentence.2484: *Figure 13: Web page spoofing Cisco Unity Connection – voicemail portal*
sentence.2485: Once this icon is clicked, the user is redirected to the credential-phishing landing page, which is designed to target multiple brands, as shown in Figure 14.
sentence.2487: Once the user clicks on any of the above links, a corresponding phishing page is displayed.
sentence.2488: As an example, the OWA phishing page is displayed (Figure 15) when the user clicks the “Outlook Web Access” link on the web page.
sentence.2490: Zscaler’s multilayered cloud security platform detects indicators at various levels, as seen here:
sentence.2491: This threat actor leverages well-crafted social engineering techniques and combines them with evasion tactics designed to bypass automated URL analysis solutions to achieve better success in reaching users and stealing their credentials.
sentence.2492: As an extra precaution, users should not open attachments in emails sent from untrusted or unknown sources.
sentence.2493: The Zscaler ThreatLabZ team will continue to monitor this campaign, as well as others, to help keep our customers safe.
sentence.2495: Infostealer is one of the most profitable tools for cybercriminals, as information gathered from systems infected with this malware could be sold in the cybercrime underground or used for credential stuffing attacks.
sentence.2496: The Zscaler ThreatLabZ team came across a new Infostealer called PurpleWave, which is written in C++ and silently installs itself onto a user’s system.
sentence.2497: It connects to a command and control (C&C) server to send system information and installs new malware onto the infected system.
sentence.2498: The author of this malware is advertising and selling PurpleWave stealer on Russian cybercrime forums for 5,000 RUB (US$68) with lifetime updates and 4,000 RUB (US$54) with only two updates.
sentence.2500: *Figure 1: A PurpleWave selling post on a Russian forum.*
sentence.2501: The author selling PurpleWave claims that this stealer is capable of stealing passwords, cookies, cards, and autofill forms of Chromium and Mozilla browsers.
sentence.2502: This stealer also collects files from the specified path, takes screenshots, and installs additional modules.
sentence.2503: The capabilities of the PurpleWave stealer include:
sentence.2504: * Stealing passwords, cookies, cards, autofill(s) data, browser history from Chromium and Mozilla.
sentence.2505: * Collecting files from the specified path
sentence.2514: The author also built a dashboard where the attacker can keep an eye on the infection counts according to dates, access the stolen logs of infected machines, and change the malware configuration settings.
sentence.2517: The dashboard also provides the attacker with the ability to customize the configuration of the PurpleWave stealer.
sentence.2519: *Figure 4: The dashboard for customizing the PurpleWave configuration.*
sentence.2520: Upon execution of the PurpleWave binary, it gives a fake error message in the Russian language that can be customized by the attacker in their panel.
sentence.2521: But in the background, it performs all of its malicious activities.
sentence.2522: *Figure 5: The fake error message in Russian.
sentence.2523: The name of the stealer (PurpleWave) and the version (1.0) are hardcoded and encrypted in the binary.
sentence.2524: Most of the strings in the binary are encrypted, but they get decrypted on runtime with the help of the decryption loop present in the binary (shown in Figure 6).
sentence.2525: *Figure 6: The common decryption function for the encrypted strings in the binary.*
sentence.2526: The PurpleWave binary creates a mutex with the name “MutexCantRepeatThis” to avoid multiple executions of malware instances.
sentence.2527: After that, it sends the HTTP POST request with the custom header and body to the C&C URL to get the configuration data.
sentence.2528: *Figure 7: Sending request to the C&C server to get the config data.*
sentence.2529: It creates an HTTP request header with content type as “form-data”.
sentence.2530: It creates a request body with a form name as “id” and the value assigned to it is 1.
sentence.2531: *Figure 8: The configuration request with the custom header and body.*
sentence.2532: We have observed three different configurations and different hosts of the PurpleWave binaries.
sentence.2534: *Figure 9: The configuration from different PurpleWave binaries.*
sentence.2535: dirs - It consists of directory information from which files to be collected.
sentence.2536: For Config-2, PurpleWave will traverse path “%userprofile%/Desktop” and collect the files having extensions txt, doc and docx.
sentence.2537: In Config-3, it will not collect any files but it has a module named “Kv2TDW4O” in the loaders, which will get downloaded and executed on the system.
sentence.2538: For installing additional modules mentioned in the received configuration (Config-3), PurpleWave again creates an HTTP POST request with the same headers mentioned in the previous request to the C&C host followed by “/loader/module\_name”.
sentence.2539: *Figure 10: The request to download an additional module.*
sentence.2540: PurpleWave enumerates the loaders list from a JSON configuration, downloads the module name from the C&C server and stores it in %appdata% directory, then executes it.
sentence.2542: The downloaded module that we observed in some PurpleWave binary is the Electrum wallet stealer, which is written in .NET and capable of stealing Electrum wallet data from the infected system.
sentence.2545: PurpleWave is capable of stealing credentials, autofills data, card data, cookies, and browser history from Chromium and Mozilla.
sentence.2546: For Chromium browsers, it fetches the login credentials from “\%AppData%\Local\{Browser}\User Data\Default\Login Data”, cookies from “\%AppData%\Local\{Browser}\User Data\Default\Cookies”, and other information, such as autofills data, card data, and browser history, from “\%AppData%\Local\{Browser}\User Data\Default\Web Data”.
sentence.2548: The stolen browser info is collected in the form of a form-data field with the names shown below followed by their value.
sentence.2550: Along with the browser’s data, the stealer captures the current screen and appends it to the browser's stolen data in the form-data with the filename as “screenshot.png”.
sentence.2551: After that, it collects all the information about infected systems, such as operating system, CPU info, GPU info, machine GUID, username, machine name, and more.
sentence.2552: *Figure 16: The system information collected by PurpleWave.*
sentence.2553: The stealer also collects the SSFN files from the Steam application.
sentence.2554: It fetches the Steam path from the registry “Software\\Valve\\Steam” and reads all the SSFN files stored into the config directory.
sentence.2555: PurpleWave also steals session-related files from the Telegram application.
sentence.2556: It reads the value of the default key in the system registry branch “HKCU\Software\Classes\tdesktop.tg\DefaultIcon” to obtain a path of Telegram and collects all the files starts with “map” in the “D877F783D5D3EF8C” directory.
sentence.2558: PurpleWave merges all the collected file data, browser data, screenshots, Steam data, Telegram data, and system info, then sends it to a C&C server using an HTTP POST request.
sentence.2560: *Figure 18: Sending stolen data to C&C server*
sentence.2561: The observed indicators in this attack were successfully blocked by the Zscaler Cloud Sandbox.
sentence.2562: ![The Zscaler Cloud Sandbox report for the PurpleWave Stealer](/cdn-cgi/image/format=auto/sites/default/files/images/blogs/sadique/purplewave/sandbox1.JPG)
sentence.2563: *Figure 19: The Zscaler Cloud Sandbox report for PurpleWave.*
sentence.2564: In addition to sandbox detections, Zscaler’s multilayered cloud security platform detects indicators at various levels.
sentence.2565: The following advanced threat protection signatures have been released for detecting the malware:
sentence.2566: Zscaler believes that PurpleWave represents an active and ongoing threat, as the C&C servers are still alive and responding as of this writing.
sentence.2567: The malware also still appears to be available for purchase on the black market.
sentence.2568: PurpleWave has incredible potential to steal sensitive information.
sentence.2569: The malware is in the early stages of development, with the author likely to enhance its stealing capabilities and add more features.
sentence.2583: Malware Leveraging XML-RPC Vulnerability to Exploit WordPress Sites
sentence.2584: We have written a number of blogs about [vulnerabilities within](/blogs/research/cybercriminals-targeting-multiple-vulnerabilities-wordpress-plugins) and [attacks on](/blogs/research/compromised-wordpress-sites-used-distribute-adwind-rat) sites built with WordPress.
sentence.2585: And, when you consider that [34 percent of all websites](https://hostingtribunal.com/blog/wordpress-statistics/) in the world are built with WordPress, it’s understandable that cybercriminals will continue to focus their attention on this popular platform.
sentence.2586: One of the most common attack vectors employed by these bad actors is to launch an XML-RPC attack.
sentence.2587: XML-RPC on WordPress, which is enabled by default, is actually an API that provides third-party applications and services the ability to interact with WordPress sites, rather than through a browser.
sentence.2588: Attackers use this channel to establish a remote connection to a WordPress site and make modifications without being directly logged in to your WordPress system.
sentence.2589: However, if a WordPress site didn’t disable XML-RPC, there is no limit to the number of login attempts that can be made by a hacker, meaning it is just a matter of time before a cybercriminal can gain access.
sentence.2590: Recently, the Zscaler ThreatLabZ team came across a scheme to attack WordPress sites where a malicious program gets a list of WordPress sites from a C&C server which then are attacked leveraging the XML-RPC pingback method to fingerprint the existing vulnerabilities on the listed WordPress sites.
sentence.2591: Even though we saw a payload used in this attack in our Zscaler cloud and also found a campaign of similar files on [VirusTotal](https://www.virustotal.com/graph/g4f708a8a274f4ef1a8727d0c6e00d5a5f5d879652067434797084e53f5d37bef), we haven’t found any specific spam templates used for this campaign.
sentence.2592: In the sample set we worked on, we found that almost all samples used Microsoft-version information, but all of them lack a legitimate Windows Digital Signature and left the company name as TODO, which implies that these files are being generated through a script and this section is still a work in progress.
sentence.2593: The initial layer of the malware is for decoding the URIs used to make initial contact with the C&C server.
sentence.2594: The first section is unpacked as shown in Figure 2:
sentence.2596: *Figure 2: The decryption loop of this program.*
sentence.2597: This decryption loop is a simple XOR decryption that sequentially runs from B5 to C7, which gives us /lk4238fh317/update.php.
sentence.2598: *Figure 3: The decrypted string of this program.*
sentence.2599: Next, the domain is generated using another XOR-based decryption where the key goes from B5 to C0.
sentence.2600: *Figure 4: The decryption loop for this program.*
sentence.2601: The blockchain DNS URI is decrypted using a similar XOR loop as shown in Figure 6.
sentence.2604: The DNS request generated produces a C&C IP of 217.8.117[.]48, which can be confirmed online at explorer.emercoin[.]com/nvs/dns.
sentence.2605: The segment of a URL created during the first decryption loop (as shown above) is then used with the IP address to contact the C&C.
sentence.2606: The C&C then replies back with 217.8.117[.]48/j537djjlhg763/svchst.exe, which is the downloaded payload.
sentence.2608: *Figure 12: The program downloading an updated version of itself.*
sentence.2609: The downloaded sample (MD5:86374F27C1A915D970BE3103D22512B9) is an updated version of the parent sample, which downloads itself to ensure that the latest version of the malicious program is running on the system.
sentence.2610: The string is obfuscated by breaking the string in two parts—k623 and 9847.lib, which are concatenated in memory.
sentence.2611: The program then enumerates system information including information such as user name, processor architecture, and more.
sentence.2612: Here, the malicious program is using ***<methodName>wp.getUsersBlogs</methodName>*** to execute a brute force attack via the “*wp.getUsersBlogs*” method of xmlrpc.php where an attacker is actually doing a reverse IP lookup for the IPs fetched from the C&C and is looking for all the available methods on the corresponding DNS.
sentence.2613: Once found, it attempts to gain the login via cookie-based authentication by logging into WordPress using cURL, authenticating the server (which ran the cURL script) and providing the username/password to the login page of the desired WordPress site.
sentence.2614: Here is a redacted list of a few WordPress sites the attacker is trying to attack leveraging this malware payload:
sentence.2616: *Figure 15: The list of WordPress sites targeted for a brute force attack.*
sentence.2617: The samples we found had similar activity but used a .space TLD domain as one of its C&C.
sentence.2618: The malware payload was successfully detected and blocked by the Zscaler Cloud Sandbox as seen in the Figure 16.
sentence.2619: ![Figure 16: The Zscaler Cloud Sandbox successfully detected the malware.](/cdn-cgi/image/format=auto/sites/default/files/images/blogs/WPbrutebot/Figure%2016.png)
sentence.2620: *Figure 16: The Zscaler Cloud Sandbox successfully detected the malware.*
sentence.2621: Due to its popularity, WordPress is a common target for cyberattacks.
sentence.2622: As such, WordPress admins need to be on alert to reports of newly found vulnerabilities and attacks.
sentence.2623: In addition, WordPress admin should keep the XML-RPC option disabled and refrain from using logins from third-party applications.
sentence.2624: Zscaler continues to protect our customers from such attacks and detects these malicious programs in our Cloud Sandbox in real time.
sentence.2631: Spear Phishing Campaign Delivers Buer and Bazar Malware
sentence.2632: Zscaler ThreatLabZ became aware of a prevalent phishing campaign targeting employees of various organizations.
sentence.2633: During the past couple of weeks, many enterprise users have been getting spear phishing emails indicating that their employment with the company has been terminated.
sentence.2634: These emails contain a Google document link that leads to the Bazar backdoor (from the TrickBot gang).
sentence.2635: What's interesting is that this campaign also used the Buer loader, which is the first time we have seen these two malware strains used together.
sentence.2636: Use of the Buer loader by the TrickBot gang comes as no surprise as this group is known to work with different malware groups.
sentence.2637: In the past, the TrickBot gang has also worked with other botnets, such as Emotet.
sentence.2638: In this email campaign, instead of relying on attachments, the attackers included links to what appeared to be a legitimate Google Docs document, which itself contained links to malicious files hosted on Google Drive or, in some cases, hosted elsewhere.
sentence.2639: In some previous phishing email campaigns, attackers leveraged SendGrid to distribute the initial emails to hide the Google Drive links in the documents behind a SendGrid URL as a way to bypass traditional defences.
sentence.2641: *Figure 1: One of the spear phishing email templates targeting an employee.*
sentence.2644: The link in both emails is a Google Docs link claiming to host a PDF file with a list of employees that have been terminated, as shown in Figure 3.
sentence.2645: *Figure 3: The link to the fake Google Doc containing the download link.*
sentence.2646: The link in the Google Doc redirects to the URL unitedyfl[.]com/print\_preview.exe to download the malware payload.
sentence.2648: In most cases, the payload that is downloaded is the Bazar malware but, in some cases, it is the Buer loader.
sentence.2649: The packer used in both malware payloads is identical.
sentence.2650: Most notably, the packed binaries are exe files with a randomly named export function.
sentence.2651: The export function is responsible for payload decryption and injection.
sentence.2652: First, a shellcode is decrypted, which further decrypts a headerless PE loader that has the final payload in its overlay.
sentence.2653: The headersless loader allocates memory, maps the payload into memory with proper permissions, and finally transfers control to it.
sentence.2654: In this campaign, no process self-injection is used to load the payload.
sentence.2656: *Figure 4: The decrypted header less PE loader.*
sentence.2657: *Figure 5: The payload embedded at the end of the loader.*
sentence.2659: The Bazar backdoor is a new stealthy malware, part of the TrickBot group’s toolkit arsenal and leveraged for high-value targets.
sentence.2660: The Bazar loader is used to download and execute the Bazar backdoor on the target system.
sentence.2661: The goal of this backdoor is to execute binaries, scripts, modules, kill processes, and then remove itself from the compromised machine.
sentence.2662: The samples used in this campaign heavily rely on control flow obfuscation.
sentence.2663: The Bazar loader downloads the Bazar backdoor from the C&C using the following URI format:
sentence.2665: The downloaded payload is XOR-encrypted and can be decrypted using the script provided in the appendix.
sentence.2666: The downloaded malware was successfully captured by the Zscaler Cloud Sandbox:
sentence.2668: The C&C TLS communications of the Bazar backdoor have been using certificates created in the same manner that TrickBot certificates have been created.
sentence.2669: The C&C server TLS certificate is shown in Figure 7.
sentence.2672: Researchers also observed that the backdoor downloads and executes the Cobalt Strike penetration testing and post-exploitation toolkit on the victim's machine within some period of time after the infection.
sentence.2673: By deploying Cobalt Strike, it is clear that this stealthy backdoor is being used to gain a foothold in corporate networks so that ransomware can be deployed, data can be stolen, or network access could be sold to other threat actors.
sentence.2675: The Buer loader was first discovered around the end of 2019.
sentence.2676: It is a very capable malware written in C and primarily sold on Russian underground forums for around US$400.
sentence.2677: Notably, this malware does not function in the CIS.
sentence.2678: It has most of the important strings encrypted and APIs are loaded by hash, just like most of the sophisticated malware these days.
sentence.2679: The Buer loader was captured by the Zscaler Cloud Sandbox.
sentence.2681: *Figure 8: The Zscaler Cloud Sandbox report for the Buer loader.*
sentence.2682: In addition to sandbox detections, Zscaler’s multilayered cloud security platform detects indicators at various levels:
sentence.2683: The TrickBot group has been running similarly themed campaigns for some time.
sentence.2684: We at Zscaler ThreatLabZ are always on the lookout for bad stuff—be it for our company or for our customers—to provide protection against it.

sentence.2725: Targeted Attacks on Oil and Gas Supply Chain Industries in the Middle East
sentence.2726: Cybercriminals are known to look to current events to make their schemes and campaigns more engaging and relevant to unsuspecting victims.
sentence.2727: So when the Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (ADNOC) terminates [engineering, procurement and construction (EPC) contracts it had previously awarded,](https://meed.com/adnoc-awards-dalma-gas-project-to-petrofac-and-sapura) attentive cybercriminals have new fodder for another scheme.
sentence.2728: Since July 2020, the Zscaler ThreatLabZ team has observed an increase in targeted attacks against multiple supply chain-related organizations in the oil and gas sector in the Middle East.
sentence.2729: We discovered multiple instances of malicious PDF files sent as email attachments and were used to distribute an information-stealing Trojan, AZORult, to these organizations.
sentence.2730: In this blog, we describe the details of this campaign, explaining the attack vectors, the malware distribution strategy, and the threat attribution.
sentence.2731: The attack chain begins with an email that appears to be from an official working at the ADNOC and is targeted at officials working in the supply chain and government sectors in the Middle East.
sentence.2732: Each email in this campaign has an attached PDF file.
sentence.2733: This PDF contains download links on the first page that lead to legitimate file sharing sites, such as wetransfer and mega.nz where a ZIP archive is hosted.
sentence.2734: The ZIP archive contains a malicious and packed .NET executable that will decrypt, load, and execute the embedded AZORult binary.
sentence.2735: Figure 2 shows an email message that pretends to come from a senior chemist of lab operations of ADNOC Sour Gas.
sentence.2736: *Figure 2: A fake email sent to officials in the supply chain industry in the Middle East.*
sentence.2737: The two Gmail addresses observed in the attacks were:
sentence.2738: The threat actor also leveraged anonymous email services from Tutanota to create emails registered with keemail.me and tuta.io which were also used in this email campaign.
sentence.2739: The PDF files attached to the email are multipage documents (containing 14 pages) that appear to be Requests for Quotations (RFQ) for supply contracts and legal tenders for various projects related to ADNOC and the Doha airport.
sentence.2740: The decoy documents are carefully crafted to appear legitimate for social engineering purposes.
sentence.2741: The first page of each document contains the instructions to access the specifications and drawings using embedded download links that lead to malicious ZIP archives as described in the attack flow above.
sentence.2742: It bears the logo of ADNOC at the top right and the first page contains the malicious download links.
sentence.2743: *Figure 3: The fake letter contained in the PDF associated with this attack.*
sentence.2744: Figure 4 shows a PDF that pretends to be a Request for Quotation for Hamad International Airport expansion plan for Doha and supposedly comes from a supply chain trading contractor in Qatar.
sentence.2745: The threat actor is specifically interested in Middle East targets, such as organisations in the supply chain and government sectors of the Middle East, especially the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and Qatar.
sentence.2746: Based on the target recipients of the email, the contents of the email, and the attached PDF files, along with the metadata and infrastructure analysis, we conclude that this is a targeted attack on organisations in the Middle East.
sentence.2747: After investigating the metadata of PDF files, we were able to discover several PDFs that we associate with the same threat actor.
sentence.2748: The metadata of the PDF files indicates that they were generated using Microsoft Office Word 2013.
sentence.2749: In addition to the contents of the emails and the documents that were used for threat attribution, we can also infer from the Command and Control (C&C) infrastructure that the threat actor has specifically chosen a C&C server that blends with the theme.
sentence.2750: In addition to the contents of the emails and the documentsthat were used for threat attribution, we can also infer from the Command and Control (C&C) infrastructure that the threat actor has specifically chosen a C&C server that blends with the theme.
sentence.2751: The C&C server in the samples we discovered was crevisoft.net.
sentence.2752: We observed that this domain, when accessed directly, would redirect to a service consulting company from Egypt hosted at crevisoft.com as shown in Figure 6.
sentence.2753: *Figure 6: A legitimate Middle East-based site hosted at crevisoft.com.*
sentence.2754: With a high confidence level, we can conclude that this threat actor is interested in stealing information and gaining access to infrastructure of supply chain-related organisations located in the Middle East.
sentence.2756: For the purpose of technical analysis, we will consider the .NET binary with MD5 hash: 84e7b5a60cd771173b75a775e0399bc7
sentence.2757: This payload, which is present inside the downloaded ZIP archive, is a packed and obfuscated .NET binary.
sentence.2758: Based on static analysis, we can see that the payload pretends to be a Skype application with spoofed metadata as shown in Figure 7.
sentence.2761: Upon execution, it unpacks another payload that is embedded in the resource section.
sentence.2762: Figure 8 shows the custom algorithm that decrypts the payload using a hardcoded key “GXR20”.
sentence.2764: *Figure 8: The subroutine used to decrypt the second stage .NET DLL.*
sentence.2765: Figure 9 shows the decrypted payload, which is a .NET DLL with the **MD5 hash** 0988195ab961071b4aa2d7a8c8e6372d and the name Aphrodite.dll
sentence.2767: *Figure 9: The unpacked and loaded second stage DLL called Aphrodite.*
sentence.2769: This DLL further unpacks another binary, which is embedded as a bitmap image in the resource section of the main executable, as shown in Figure 11.
sentence.2771: *Figure 11: The bitmap image inside the resource section that contains the next stage payload.*
sentence.2772: The custom algorithm is based on XOR using the key indicated by the parameter ugz3**.**
sentence.2773: The resulting unpacked binary is a .NET DLL with **MD5 hash** ae5f14478d5e06c1b2dc2685cbe992c1 and the name Jupiter.
sentence.2775: *Figure 12: The unpacked and loaded third stage DLL called Jupiter.*
sentence.2776: This third stage DLL uses various methods to detect the presence of a virtualization or an analysis environment.
sentence.2777: Below is a summary of the methods used by this DLL to detect the analysis environment.
sentence.2778: Registry key: "HARDWARE\\DEVICEMAP\\Scsi\\Scsi Port 0\\Scsi Bus 0\\Target Id 0\\Logical Unit Id 0"
sentence.2779: Checks for the presence of a DLL with the name: "SbieDll.dll" in the process address space.
sentence.2781: After all the above environment checks are performed, the AZORult payload (**MD5 hash:** 38360115294c49538ab15b5ec3037a77) is injected using the process hollowing technique in a new instance of the main process.
sentence.2782: We will not describe the details of the functionality of AZORult information stealer since it is already well-documented in the public domain.
sentence.2783: It is important to note that based on the flow of the code execution and the anti-analysis techniques used, the .NET packed payload appears to be created using the CyaX packer.
sentence.2784: The final unpacked payload, AZORult, will perform information stealing activities on the machine and exfiltrate the information by sending an HTTP POST request to the URL: hxxp://crevisoft.net/images/backgrounds/ob/index.php
sentence.2785: Upon inspection, we discovered that opendir was enabled on the C&C server as shown in Figure 13.
sentence.2786: *Figure 13: Opendir enabled on the C&C server.*
sentence.2787: The AZORult panel on the C&C server can be accessed atthe URL:hxxp://crevisoft.net/images/backgrounds/ob/panel/admin.php.
sentence.2789: Among other artifacts we discovered on the C&C server, we found a PHP mailing script deployed at hxxp://crevisoft[.]net/images/-/leaf.php.
sentence.2790: This enables the threat actor to send emails using the C&C server’s SMTP.
sentence.2791: *Figure 15: The PHP mailing script on the C&C server.*
sentence.2793: Figure 16 shows the Zscaler Cloud Sandbox successfully detecting this .NET-based threat.
sentence.2795: In addition to sandbox detections, Zscaler’s multilayered cloud security platform detects indicators at various levels, as seen here:
sentence.2796: This threat actor is targeting employees in the supply chain industries in Oil and Gas sector in the middle east region.
sentence.2797: And always be wary of links embedded inside file formats such as PDF since these links could lead to download of malicious files on your system.
sentence.2798: The Zscaler ThreatLabZ team will continue to monitor this campaign, as well as others, to help keep our customers safe.
sentence.2799: | T1566.001 | Spearphishing Attachment | Uses PDF attachments containing malicious URLs |
sentence.2800: | T1204.002 | User Execution: Malicious File | User opens pdf file.

sentence.2855: The Hitchhiker’s Guide to SolarWinds Incident Response
sentence.2856: On December 13, 2020, [multiple](https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2020/12/evasive-attacker-leverages-solarwinds-supply-chain-compromises-with-sunburst-backdoor.html) [security](https://blogs.microsoft.com/on-the-issues/2020/12/13/customers-protect-nation-state-cyberattacks/) vendors in conjunction with [CISA](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/alerts/aa20-352a) disclosed a software supply-chain attack involving the SolarWinds Orion platform.
sentence.2857: The disclosure detailed the activities of an advanced persistent threat (APT) adversary that was able to gain access to SolarWinds systems to create trojanized updates to the Orion platform between March 2020 and possibly as recently as December 2020.
sentence.2858: The trojanized updates included a custom, digitally signed backdoor called SUNBURST.
sentence.2859: SolarWinds Orion is a widely used network infrastructure monitoring and management platform with a reported customer base of over 18,000.
sentence.2860: Based on publicly available data, this adversary demonstrated significant efforts to evade, obfuscate, and clean-up using techniques such as steganography, fingerprinting techniques to identify both target systems as well as analysis systems, rotating infrastructure with a focus on geolocation proximity, as well as executing code in memory as much as possible.
sentence.2861: These techniques, in combination with using a digitally signed component of a trusted software platform as the initial infection vector, are indicative of a highly skilled and covert adversary willing to expend resources to assure the success of their operation.
sentence.2862: Zscaler suggests that all organizations should take several immediate actions, described below, in addition to reviewing the existing security policies and best practices available to Zscaler customers.
sentence.2863: These actions are recommended for any organization that may be impacted by the SolarWinds event.
sentence.2864: Organizations should immediately identify all systems that may have SolarWinds Orion installed.
sentence.2865: Based on public reporting, a SolarWinds Orion system affected by this event—meaning that the SUNBURST backdoor had been successfully installed—would begin network communication to its first stage command and control (C&C) server at avsvmcloud[.]com.
sentence.2866: Zscaler Internet Access (ZIA) customers may be able to perform this search within the DNS Insights or Web Insights area in the portal, or within the log aggregator/SIEM of choice where ZIA logs are sent.
sentence.2867: Additionally, all network activity originating from SolarWinds Orion systems to other internal systems should be reviewed for potential lateral movement.
sentence.2868: The SUNBURST backdoor is a digitally signed DLL file with a specific filename and hash.
sentence.2871: * Newly created or unknown local user accounts
sentence.2872: Once SUNBURST has been deployed, the adversary will most likely begin to perform reconnaissance actions using the privileges of the Orion system and explore what is available in terms of additional assets to compromise or actions to take.
sentence.2873: * Extremely long duration tokens, which may indicate malicious activity (examine SAML tokens for duration)
sentence.2875: As described in our **[ThreatLabZ blog post](/blogs/security-research/zscaler-coverage-solarwinds-cyberattacks-and-fireeye-red-team-tools-theft)**, Zscaler immediately deployed protections to all customers and continues to deploy additional protections and countermeasures as more information becomes available.
sentence.2876: In addition, as we had disclosed in our **[Trust Advisory](https://trust.zscaler.com/posts/6896?_gl=1*7rl9s3*_ga*OTQ0OTgyNTM2LjE2MDAxMTMwNTc.*_ga_10SPJ4YJL9*MTYwODY3OTc4OS40Ny4xLjE2MDg2ODAxNjEuNTI.&_ga=2.98380127.1768883422.1608589514-944982536.1600113057)**, Zscaler was not impacted by this event.

sentence.2881: Ransomware Delivered Using RDP Brute-Force Attack
sentence.2882: Zscaler ThreatLabZ recently published a [report](/blogs/security-research/2020-state-cloud-insecurity) on the 2020 State of Public Cloud Security that showed security misconfiguration to be the leading cause of cyberattacks against public cloud infrastructure.
sentence.2883: In this blog, we will look at one of the commonly abused security misconfigurations—the RDP service port left open to the internet—and how cybercriminals abuse it.
sentence.2884: Brute-forcing RDP (Remote Desktop Protocol) is the most common method used by threat actors attempting to gain access to Windows systems and execute malware.
sentence.2885: The reason is simple: In our public cloud threat research, we have observed that 70 percent of systems keep RDP ports open in the public cloud.
sentence.2886: Threat actors scan for these publicly open RDP ports to conduct distributed brute-force attacks.
sentence.2887: Systems that use weak credentials are easy targets, and, once compromised, attackers sell access to the hacked systems on the dark web to other cybercriminals.
sentence.2888: Ransomware groups such as SamSam and Dharma have been spreading almost exclusively via RDP for years.
sentence.2889: In this case study, we will look at Dharma ransomware attacks.
sentence.2890: Dharma, also known as Crysis, has been distributed under a ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) model since 2016.
sentence.2891: Attackers use open-source port-scanning tools to scan for exposed RDP ports online and then try to gain access to a system using brute-force tools or stolen credentials purchased from the dark web.
sentence.2892: After attackers gain access to the target system, they go on to make the system vulnerable by deleting backups, disabling antivirus software, and changing configuration settings.
sentence.2893: Once the security is disabled and the network vulnerable, attackers deliver malware payloads.
sentence.2894: The process involves installing ransomware, using infected machines to distribute spam, deploying keyloggers, or installing backdoors to be used for future attacks.
sentence.2895: The below figure shows the infection cycle of Dharma ransomware delivered via RDP brute-force attack.
sentence.2896: ![Infection chain of RDP brute force attack delivers Dharma ransomware](/cdn-cgi/image/format=auto/sites/default/files/images/blogs/sadique/rdp_ransom/iv1.JPG)
sentence.2897: *Figure 1: Infection chain of RDP brute-force attack delivers Dharma ransomware*
sentence.2898: Once the attacker gains access to the machine, the following files are uploaded:
sentence.2899: [ns.exe](https://www.softperfect.com/products/networkscanner/) is a network enumeration and scanning tool used by attackers to scan SMB shares, open ports, and services through which they can move within the network.
sentence.2900: [Process Hacker](https://github.com/processhacker/processhacker) is a program used mostly by system administrators for monitoring, debugging, and troubleshooting, but in this case, it was used for malicious purposes such as disabling AV or services.
sentence.2901: Following the pre-execution process, the attacker uploads a ransomware file and executes it.
sentence.2902: Once executed, this variant of Dharma ransomware uses the below commands to quietly delete all of the shadow volume copies on the machine.
sentence.2903: For persistence, the ransomware executes the following commands:
sentence.2906: The ransomware encrypts files with the following extensions:
sentence.2908: The ransomware encrypts files using an AES 256 algorithm.
sentence.2909: The AES key is also encrypted with an RSA 1024 algorithm.
sentence.2910: This encrypted AES key is stored at the end of the encrypted file along with the filename.
sentence.2912: After encrypting the files, the ransomware pops up two different ransom notes on the victim’s computer.
sentence.2913: One is the *Info.hta* file, which is launched via autorun when a user logs into the computer.
sentence.2915: Dharma ransomware uses typical methods for obtaining credentials and propagating laterally within a network.
sentence.2916: In most cases, it uses the Mimikatz tool, which allows it to dump the network share credentials, and in other cases, it uses NirSoft CredentialsFileView, which allows for the recovery of passwords stored in encrypted credential files.
sentence.2917: The obtained credentials are used to attempt lateral movement inside the on-prem as well as public cloud infrastructure.
sentence.2918: In some cases, the ransomware tries to spread through the network by taking advantage of the compromised Domain Controller and deploying a Default Domain Policy that will run the ransomware payload on StartUp for each machine.
sentence.2919: Since Dharma ransomware is usually installed by gaining access to Remote Desktop Services, it is important to ensure that those services are properly locked.
sentence.2920: This includes ensuring that computers running Remote Desktop Services do not connect directly to the internet.
sentence.2921: While applying security patches is always important, most RDP-based attacks rely on cracking weak credentials, so passwords should be long, unique, and random.
sentence.2922: Attackers typically identify potential targets by scanning the internet for systems listening on the default RDP port (TCP 3389).
sentence.2923: Did COVID Cancel Christmas for Cybercriminals?
sentence.2924: ThreatLabZ, the security research team at Zscaler, is responsible for monitoring and tracking global cybercrime activity, which typically drops each year around the Russian Orthodox Christmas on January 7th.
sentence.2925: In contrast, this year’s criminal activity remained at normal levels before, during, and after the Russian Orthodox Christmas.
sentence.2927: ##### ***​Figure 1**: Malware trends before and after the holiday season in 2019-2020*
sentence.2929: ##### ***Figure 2**: Malware trends before and after the holiday season in 2020-2021*
sentence.2930: The following sections describe recent activities for five of the top malware families, including Emotet, Trickbot, Dridex, ZLoader, and Qakbot.
sentence.2932: **[Update]** – On January 27, 2021, Europol announced a [global action in disrupting](https://www.europol.europa.eu/newsroom/news/world%25E2%2580%2599s-most-dangerous-malware-emotet-disrupted-through-global-action) Emotet botnet operations.
sentence.2933: This was a collaborative effort between law enforcement authorities in the Netherlands, Germany, U.S., UK, France, Canada, Lithuania, and Ukraine, with international activity coordinated by Europol and Eurojust.
sentence.2934: Zscaler ThreatLabZ has been closely tracking Emotet for several years (see blogs from [October 2019](/blogs/security-research/emotet-back-action-after-short-break), [February 2019](/blogs/security-research/demystifying-crypter-used-emotet-qbot-and-dridex), and [August 2017](/blogs/security-research/look-recent-emotet-campaigns-august-2017)).
sentence.2935: We can confirm that we haven't seen any updates or activity from the Emotet C&C infrastructure in the past 48 hours, which indicates that the takedown operation has been successful.
sentence.2936: However, we have seen similar gangs push out new variants and resurrect the botnet using a new C&C infrastructure.
sentence.2937: We are closely monitoring for any new Emotet variants and activity.
sentence.2938: Emotet resumed its activity as of Monday, January 4, 2021.
sentence.2939: To take advantage of the holiday season, Emotet briefly ramped up its activity between December 21 and 30, 2020.
sentence.2940: During this ramped-up activity, Emotet was mostly using a *reply chain* (also known as *email thread hijacking)* spam email as the bait.
sentence.2941: A reply chain attack is when threat actors hijack real email threads and utilize legitimate email messages stolen from victims’ email applications.
sentence.2942: This email reply is again targeted to addresses from the original email, allowing it to further gain trust from targets.
sentence.2943: While the first batch of emails was targeting English-speaking countries, spam emails in German, Italian, French,  Spanish, and Polish followed shortly thereafter.
sentence.2944: An example of an Emotet reply chain spam email in Italian is shown in Figure 3.
sentence.2946: The main Emotet loader had some minor changes after returning from a brief break.
sentence.2947: Emotet continued to use spam with malicious Microsoft Word documents attached as the primary distribution method.
sentence.2948: On January 20,2021, Emotet increased the build number to 0x13461C8 (20210120) and the loader version number to 0x1770 (6000).
sentence.2949: Another interesting tactical move by Emotet that started in January was the shift to password-protected ZIP attachments.
sentence.2950: Instead of including the password in the email body text, Emotet started using embedded images that contain the ZIP password.
sentence.2951: The group has also continued to use a DLL file for the loader instead of a standard Windows executable, which may be to further evade detection.
sentence.2952: Emotet was last seen deploying the following modules:
sentence.2957: In addition, Emotet has been observed delivering Trickbot as a second-stage payload.
sentence.2960: Emotet started dropping Trickbot as a secondary payload on victim machines after it returned from the holiday break.
sentence.2961: Trickbot is operated by the same threat actor that deploys Conti and Ryuk ransomware.
sentence.2962: Therefore, these ransomware operations likely resumed around the same time as well.
sentence.2963: Emotet was distributing Trickbot with the group tags *mor12* and *mor13*.
sentence.2964: There have not been any significant changes in Trickbot following the holiday break.
sentence.2965: Trickbot was also distributed by another spam campaign on the same day by the group tag *rob35*.
sentence.2966: This specific campaign was being distributed via SpamEx, which distributed a malicious JavaScript file embedded in a ZIP file.
sentence.2967: When opened, the JavaScript was used to invoke PowerShell to download and execute Trickbot from phishing sites.
sentence.2968: The Trickbot campaigns with the group tags *tot6* and *lib6* have also been observed since the holiday break.
sentence.2971: On January 11, 2021, ThreatLabZ observed the emergence of Dridex with a Cutwail spam campaign.
sentence.2972: The group used an invoice theme to distribute the Dridex loader.
sentence.2973: The Cutwail spam distributed payloads for Dridex sub-botnets 10444 and 10555 as Microsoft Excel attachments.
sentence.2974: Dridex continues using DLL files for the loader instead of Windows executables, a technique that has been recently employed by the Emotet and Qakbot threat groups as well.
sentence.2975: There was another Dridex campaign with botnet 111 observed a day later, which was using the RIG exploit kit (EK).
sentence.2976: The same RIG EK gate was used before the Christmas holiday.
sentence.2979: On January 19, 2021, Qakbot emerged with a new spam campaign dropping a Qakbot payload with the campaign ID *abc118*.
sentence.2980: Similar to Emotet, Qakbot is using reply chain spam email attacks.
sentence.2981: Qakbot was also seen using a “complaint copy" spam theme.
sentence.2982: Qakbot spam campaigns are distributing malicious Excel files embedded inside a ZIP attachment.
sentence.2983: Like Emotet, Dridex, and ZLoader, Qakbot is using a DLL file for the loader instead of Windows executables.
sentence.2984: This technique is now widely used by cybercriminals and is apparently able to evade security and sandbox solutions.
sentence.2985: ##### ***Figure 4****: Reply chain spam email distributing Qakbot*
sentence.2988: ThreatLabZ observed new ZLoader activity on January 11, 2021.
sentence.2989: The botnet then went quiet, resuming with another spam campaign on January 19.
sentence.2990: So far in 2021, four different ZLoader campaigns have been observed, primarily targeting US and EU banks and financial institutions.
sentence.2992: Campaign frequency differs for each malware family.
sentence.2993: Some have more regular Monday through Thursday cycles, while others, such as Emotet and Qakbot, are unpredictable.
sentence.2994: Usually, inactivity by cybercriminals or the absence of a malware strain is a sign of impending changes.
sentence.2995: Malware authors continually adapt their techniques and change their code to improve distribution, persistence, evasion, and overall success.
sentence.2996: ThreatLabZ continuously monitors activity from cybercrime gangs and their evolving malware strains, integrating all threat intelligence into the Zscaler platform so it can be distributed cloud-wide to protect all customers around the world.
sentence.2997: Discord CDN: A Popular Choice for Hosting Malicious Payloads
sentence.2998: During 2020, [research](https://www.analyticsinsight.net/gaming-boom-in-covid-19-times-analysis-insights/) showed a sharp increase in game downloads, and this activity did not go unnoticed by cybercriminals.
sentence.2999: Attackers have often exploited the popularity of certain games ([Among Us](/blogs/security-research/among-us-imposter-google-play) was a recent example) to lure players into downloading fake versions that served malware.
sentence.3000: Recently, the Zscaler ThreatLabZ team noticed new campaigns in which cybercriminals are targeting gamers.
sentence.3001: * Multiple campaigns relying on the cdn.discordapp.com service for their infection chain.
sentence.3002: * Cybercriminals are using Discord CDN to host malicious files as well as for command-and-control (C&C) communication.
sentence.3003: * Malicious files are renamed as pirated software or gaming software to trick gamers.
sentence.3004: * File icons are also related to gaming software to trick gamers.
sentence.3005: * Multiple categories of malware are being served through the Discord app’s CDN infrastructure - ransomware, stealers, and cryptominers.
sentence.3006: The attack usually starts with spam emails in which users are tricked with legitimate-looking templates into downloading next-stage payloads.
sentence.3007: It’s worth noting, however, that using Discord to host payloads is not new.
sentence.3008: This campaign uses Discord services to form a URL to host malicious payloads as follows: *https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/ChannelID/AttachmentID/filename.exe*
sentence.3009: *Figure 1: Malicious files blocked in the Zscaler cloud served via cdn.discordapp.com*
sentence.3010: Discord is a chat application that allows users to chat with each other in real time.
sentence.3011: But attackers also use Discord, often to distribute malicious files and steal information.
sentence.3012: For example, an attacker can upload a malicious file on a Discord channel and share its public link with others—**even non-Discord users can download it**.
sentence.3013: Worse, a file sent from Discord is there forever, so even if an attacker deletes a file within Discord, its link can still be used to download the malicious file.
sentence.3014: *Figure 2: Infection chain of different malware on* cdn.dscordapp.com

sentence.3035: First, it encrypts the files with AES encryption using a randomly generated 32-bit key.
sentence.3036: Then, those encrypted files will again be encrypted with the RC4 algorithm with a randomly generated 256-bit key.

sentence.3041: It also uses custom RC4 encryption that has a 2048-bit variable-length key, whereas actual RC4 encryption uses a 256-bit variable-length key.
sentence.3043: It downloads the ransom note image from the cdn.discordapp.com link to show on the victim’s machine upon successful encryption.

sentence.3053: The next file we saw during our analysis is a Redline stealer.
sentence.3054: This stealer has been available on Russian underground forums since the first quarter of 2020 and is fairly new.
sentence.3055: We have seen multiple samples of the Redline stealer blocked in the Zscaler cloud sandbox and below is our analysis of a recent sample written in .NET.

sentence.3096: The Discord token grabber is a broad term used to describe attacks that use Discord tokens to steal user information.
sentence.3097: In this case, the stealer uses Discord app to steal data from the user and send it to a predetermined C&C server.

sentence.3099: Here, the program collects user information, for example, *Environment.UserName*, and sends it over using a webhook defined in the *dcWebHook.WebHook* variable.

sentence.3103: The name of the attachment can vary from being the name of a software application used by most users or cracked versions of games or tools, such as Discord Server Tool.exe, Galaxy Security Panel.exe, Vron Software.exe, CrackHub 2021.exe, or Vape V4 Cracked.exe.

sentence.3114: Discord is primarily a chatting platform built for gamers and is becoming increasingly popular among other professional communities for sharing information.
sentence.3115: We’re observing an increase in the usage of the Discord app to deliver malicious files by attackers.
sentence.3116: Due to the static content distribution service, it is highly popular among threat actors to host malicious attachments that remain publicly accessible even after removing actual files from Discord.
sentence.3117: The Zscaler ThreatLabZ team will continue to monitor Discord-based malware campaigns to share the information with the community and to keep our customers safe.

sentence.3139: Ares Malware: The Grandson of the Kronos Banking Trojan
sentence.3140: *Kronos* is a banking trojan that first emerged in 2014 and marketed in underground forums as a crimeware kit to conduct credit card, identity theft, and wire fraud.
sentence.3141: In September 2018, a new Kronos variant named [*Osiris*](https://www.proofpoint.com/us/threat-insight/post/kronos-reborn) introduced several new features including TOR for command and control (C2) communications.
sentence.3142: The last update to Osiris appears to have been around mid-2019.
sentence.3143: In February 2021, Zscaler ThreatLabz identified a new Kronos variant that surfaced via [spam campaigns to German speakers](https://blog.morphisec.com/long-live-osiris-banking-trojan-targets-german-ip-addresses), which calls itself *Ares*.
sentence.3144: Thus, the naming convention appears to refer to this new malware variant as the third generation of Kronos.
sentence.3145: Ares still appears to be in development alongside an information stealer that harvests credentials from various applications including VPN clients, web browsers, and the malware can exfiltrate arbitrary files and cryptocurrency wallets.
sentence.3146: The threat actor behind this new variant continues to use both Osiris and Ares in parallel.
sentence.3147: In this blog post, we will examine these new malware developments and campaigns.
sentence.3149: Recent samples of Osiris and Ares have been protected by a malware packer written in C++ that calls itself *DarkCrypter*.
sentence.3150: The packer contains the PDB path d:\scm\Italy\dopplegang\DarkCrypter\Bin\Clean.pdb.
sentence.3151: The code is not related to the commercial packer, DarkCrypter, that has been [cracked and leaked online](https://github.com/0x4xLEAKR/DarkCrypter).
sentence.3152: Interestingly, the packer shares code with Kronos and Osiris including the string encryption algorithm.
sentence.3153: When the string table is decrypted, the first 41 entries are identical to older Kronos variants with eight new string additions (shown below) to detect sandbox environments:
sentence.3154: If the anti-analysis checks pass, the packer proceeds to the next step.
sentence.3155: There are at least two variants of the packer.
sentence.3156: The first variant decrypts the next-stage payload using Blowfish.
sentence.3157: However, the Blowfish decryption implementation in DarkCrypter supports a hardcoded key size that is 288 bytes (although only the first 72 bytes are effectively used).
sentence.3158: The second variant of the DarkCrypter packer embeds the second-stage payload in a compressed format rather than an encrypted Blowfish format.
sentence.3159: The compression algorithm is identical to that found in Ares, and components related to Ares, including a packer that impersonates a bitmap image header.
sentence.3161: The threat actor has also experimented with modifying UPX headers, which has well known section names.
sentence.3162: The modifications that have been made by the threat actor replace the UPX section names (UPX0, UPX1, ...
sentence.3163: This breaks compatibility with the command-line UPX decompression tool, although the file can still be decompressed and executed.
sentence.3165: These changes can easily be restored to the original UPX section names as shown on the right in Figure 1.
sentence.3166: The UPX command-line utility can then be used to statically unpack this binary, producing the final executable payload.
sentence.3168: The threat actor has also been using another packer that Zscaler ThreatLabZ has dubbed BMPack.
sentence.3169: This packer has been utilized to pack both Osiris and Ares payloads.
sentence.3170: BMPack first decrypts embedded data using an XOR-based algorithm, followed by RC4.
sentence.3171: After the decryption stage, the file appears to be a bitmap image as shown in Figure 2.
sentence.3172: Fake Bitmap Image Used to Unpack Osiris and Ares Malware Payloads
sentence.3173: However, a closer inspection reveals that the data is not actually a bitmap image, but has a specific sequence of data structures.
sentence.3175: Each decompressed structure holds a different section of a PE file that is reconstructed and stitched together by a custom loader, and executed.
sentence.3177: Ares is being actively developed and the malware author continues to create and test new plugins and web injects.
sentence.3178: In the most recent Ares samples, there is an embedded DLL module that is compressed within the binary.
sentence.3179: The module contains an export that is designed to establish persistence.
sentence.3180: The code first copies itself to the location %APPDATA%\Adobe\AdobeNotificationUpdates.exe.
sentence.3181: It then creates a scheduled task named *AdobeNotificationUpdates* that is designed to execute Ares every two hours (with an expiration date of 2050-05-02 12:05:00).
sentence.3182: Similar persistence code is also found in many DarkCrypter samples.
sentence.3183: The Ares persistence module has the same compilation prefix as other modules in its PDB path D:\scm\Italy\ares\source\_ob\Release\startup.pdb.
sentence.3184: Ares attempts to locate an export name with the hash value F4S4G3S4U7C6P2P7, which maps to the string [[email protected]](/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection)@[[email protected]](/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection).
sentence.3185: Once the address of this function is located, Ares executes the module.
sentence.3186: Ares uses the same function hashing algorithm as Kronos, which consists of calculating a CRC64 hash, converting the digest to uppercase hexadecimal characters.
sentence.3187: The result is then mapped to an alphanumeric value as shown in the Python code below:
sentence.3188: Ares contains most of the same code as its predecessors: Kronos and Osiris.
sentence.3189: However, there are several notable differences between Osiris and Ares, especially with respect to the C2 communications.
sentence.3190: Most Ares samples currently do not communicate with C2 servers over TOR.
sentence.3191: It is not quite clear, why most Ares samples have the TOR component removed, but it may be to reduce the malware's file size and evade corporate firewalls that block TOR network traffic.
sentence.3192: However, without TOR, the C2 servers are more vulnerable to takedown attempts.
sentence.3193: Some Ares samples attempt to address this limitation by hardcoding a large number of C2 URLs in the binary.
sentence.3194: Zscaler ThreatLabz has observed one Ares sample with [101 hardcoded C2 URLs](https://pastebin.com/XU6YfvWG).
sentence.3195: Ares has also slightly modified the bot ID generation code, replacing the string Kronos with the string Ares as shown in Figure 4.
sentence.3196: Comparison Between Kronos and Ares Bot ID Generation
sentence.3197: Ares uses the HTTP query string parameters shown in Table 1.
sentence.3198: The HTTP request that sends the report.zip file is unique to Ares and discussed in more detail below.
sentence.3202: | a=3 | Send report.zip file created by Ares Stealer |
sentence.3206: Ares supports many of the same commands as Kronos and Osiris.
sentence.3207: However, some of the commands have been modified and the malware uninstall command (0x1) was removed.
sentence.3208: There are four modified commands that are supported by Ares as shown below in Table 2.
sentence.3209: | 0x3 | Set registry value name MSE to 0 |
sentence.3210: | 0x4 | Set registry value name MSE to 1 |
sentence.3211: | 0x6 | Download, decompress, map Ares Stealer into memory, and execute |
sentence.3212: | 0xC | Download, decompress, map module into memory, and execute |
sentence.3214: The commands 0x3 and 0x4 attempt to set a registry value name *MSE* to zero and one, respectively, under the registry key HKEY\_CURRENT\_USER\Software\Microsoft\CurrentVersion.
sentence.3215: This is likely an oversight by the malware author who accidentally left out *Windows* in this registry path between *Microsoft* and *CurrentVersion*.
sentence.3216: The registry value is not referenced elsewhere in Ares, so it may hint at a future use.
sentence.3217: One of the most significant modifications is the command 0x6 that downloads, decompresses, and maps a PE file into memory, and executes it.
sentence.3218: The first string is a pattern provided by the C2 server and the second is hardcoded to the string %APPDATA%\Google\report.zip.
sentence.3219: Zscaler ThreatLabZ has observed this Ares command being used to download a file from the URL http://mydynamite.dynv6[.]net/panel/upload/stealer.dll.
sentence.3220: The file is decompressed using the same compression algorithm as BMPack.
sentence.3221: Ares has code artifacts from the development of command 0x6.
sentence.3222: The file is decompressed and mapped into memory using the same process as command 0x6.
sentence.3223: After the file is mapped, the export CollectInfo is called with the parameters: %userprofile%Documents|*.txt|5 and NULL.
sentence.3224: Zscaler ThreatLabZ has also identified Ares samples that contain another unreferenced function that loads a VNC plugin by attempting to open a file located at d:\scm\Italy\ares\\source\_ob\Binaries\Release\vnc.dll.cmp.
sentence.3225: Similar to the stealer plugin, the file is decompressed, mapped into memory, and the export MakeItStart is called.
sentence.3226: The MakeItStart export name is resolved similar to the other Ares functions using the same CRC64-based hash algorithm and comparing the result with F0U5R4R6Q8H1P3E5.
sentence.3227: Ares then will terminate the VNC plugin by mapping the export name MakeItStop using the same process and comparing the result with the hash value C6P3T6Q8H1P3E5A8.
sentence.3228: The command 0xC is the most recent modification to Ares and only found in newer samples.
sentence.3230: Ares Stealer is downloaded by Ares and invoked via the export name CollectInfo.
sentence.3231: The malware is written in C++ and uses the Boost and Curl libraries.
sentence.3232: Ares Stealer has compilation artifacts showing that the Boost library was compiled in the directory d:\scm\Italy\tools\boost\_1\_74\_0\boost.
sentence.3233: This directory prefix is identical to the DarkCrypter’s PDB path and the location where the Ares unreferenced test functions attempt to load plugins from.
sentence.3234: This artifact along with the shared compression code suggests that the malware author likely has developed DarkCrypter, BMPack, Ares, and Ares Stealer.
sentence.3235: The Ares Stealer export CollectInfo takes two parameters: a pipe-delimited string and a filename string.
sentence.3236: The pipe-delimited string takes three arguments, which are used by the stealer’s file grabber feature.
sentence.3237: The first parameter is the directory in which to start the file enumeration process, the second parameter is a search pattern, and the last parameter is the directory search depth.
sentence.3238: An example command string observed from an Ares C2 server is %userprofile%|pass*.txt|5.
sentence.3239: This command will search a victim’s user profile directory up to five levels deep for text files that have the prefix pass.
sentence.3240: Ares Stealer collects detailed system information and harvests credentials for numerous applications including FTP clients, VPN clients, web browsers, instant messengers, and email clients.
sentence.3241: It can also steal files, cryptocurrency wallets, cookies, and credit cards.
sentence.3242: The stealer will attempt to extract information from the following applications:
sentence.3251: The Osiris version that has been used by this threat actor contains a number of new features since the original version that appeared in April 2018.
sentence.3252: * New beacon request format that includes information about the compromised system
sentence.3253: * Zlib compression to reduce the size of requests and responses (including web injects)
sentence.3254: * Ability to deploy TeamViewer on a compromised host
sentence.3255: * Ability to steal a victim’s Outlook contacts via [Nirsoft’s OutlookAddressBookView](https://www.nirsoft.net/utils/outlook_address_book_view.html) utility
sentence.3256: * Send spam emails to a victim’s contact list
sentence.3257: The threat actor has an Osiris C2 server that is located at http://ylnfkeznzg7o4xjf[.]onion/kpanel/connect.php, which has been instructing infected systems to steal and exfiltrate web browser and email credentials.
sentence.3258: The web browser harvesting command downloads a sqlite3 library from http://qqkzfkax24p4elax[.]onion/kpanel/upload/sqlite3.dll, which is a dependency to extract Google Chrome passwords.
sentence.3259: A second module for harvesting Firefox credentials from a 64-bit system is downloaded from http://qqkzfkax24p4elax[.]onion/kpanel/upload/ffc64.exe.
sentence.3260: The C2 is also serving a web inject configuration file, which targets clients at German financial institutions with the URL patterns shown below:
sentence.3261: When a victim browses to a website that matches one of these patterns, JavaScript code will be injected from the threat actor’s domain https://securebankingapp[.]com/.
sentence.3262: The full list of web injects for this Osiris instance is shown [here](https://pastebin.com/tTxmjA1K).
sentence.3263: The threat actor has another active Osiris C2 server located at http://qqkzfkax24p4elax[.]onion/kpanel/connect.php.
sentence.3264: This C2 server is also serving commands to exfiltrate credentials, but the web inject configuration file is blank.
sentence.3265: However, the C2 server is also providing commands to extract a victim’s email contact list using Nirsoft’s OutlookAddressBookView, which is downloaded from the following locations:
sentence.3266: Ares is a new fork of the Kronos banking trojan that appears to be in the early stages of development.
sentence.3267: The threat actor has invested significant resources in building DarkCrypter, BMPack, Ares, and Ares Stealer.
sentence.3268: Therefore, activity related to this threat is likely to increase as the malware continues to mature.

sentence.3313: Zscaler ThreatLabZ recently came across an interesting campaign involving multiple infostealer RAT families and miner malware.
sentence.3314: We’ve dubbed the campaign “HydroJiin” based on aliases used by the threat actor.
sentence.3315: The threat actor is in the business of selling malware, and lurks around in online forums that are common hangouts for neophyte to mid-level cyber criminals.
sentence.3316: We speculate that the malware author is running widespread campaigns involving different commodity and custom malware to steal information to sell in underground marketplaces.
sentence.3317: Similar to other attacks outlined in the recent [ThreatLabZ State of Encrypted Attacks report](/blogs/security-research/2020-state-encrypted-attacks), this campaign serves as yet another example of the importance of continuous SSL inspection and [zero trust](/resources/security-terms-glossary/what-is-zero-trust) policies to prevent initial compromise as well as communication back to C&C servers.
sentence.3318: While we do not know the impact of this particular campaign, this type of malware is for sale on underground markets to any number of prospective cybercriminals.
sentence.3319: This campaign utilizes a variety of payloads and infection vectors from commodity RATs to custom malware, email spam, backdooring/masquerading as cracked software, and other lures.
sentence.3320: * Custom python-based backdoor deployed along with other RATs (Netwired and Quasar)
sentence.3321: * Python backdoor command checking for MacOS indicating possibility of more cross-platform functionality in the future.
sentence.3322: * Campaign is related to a threat actor who is also involved in distribution of multiple malicious tools via a dedicated malware e-commerce website
sentence.3323: * Possibility of backdoored malware payload similar to [CobianRAT case](/blogs/security-research/cobian-rat-backdoored-rat)
sentence.3324: * Not rare, but heavy use of pastebin to host encoded payloads
sentence.3325: The infection starts with the delivery of a downloader that downloads multiple payloads.
sentence.3326: We could not confirm the delivery vector of this downloader but in we suspect the use of spam emails and cracked software as we have seen in earlier campaigns.
sentence.3327: Once the attackers achieve initial compromise, the downloader downloads three files:
sentence.3328: * Injector - Used as a loader to inject downloaded payloads into legitimate processes.
sentence.3329: * Netwired RAT - A commodity RAT malware used to control the infected system and steal information.
sentence.3330: * DownloaderShellcode - Obfuscated Meterpreter-based shellcode to download further payloads.
sentence.3331: + A Pyrome python backdoor is downloaded by this shellcode.
sentence.3332: This will also download socat and xmrig miner, and finally xmrig miner downloads another RAT named Quasar.
sentence.3333: Each payload and its functionality is explained below.
sentence.3335: First, the downloader downloads a payload from pastebin and saves to %TEMP% path, with randomly generated names.
sentence.3336: The ***payload*** hosted on pastebin is encoded in base64 with the text string reversed.
sentence.3338: The downloaded malware is an injector.
sentence.3339: It downloads two more payloads and passes an argument to the first payload for injection.
sentence.3343: The payloads are also similarly string reversed after base64 encoding.
sentence.3345: The second payload in this case, hosted on pastebin, is a commodity malware known as NetWiredRC.
sentence.3346: NetWiredRC is a publicly available RAT sold by World Wired Labs, active since at least 2012.
sentence.3347: Adversaries often use spam mails and phishing emails to distribute NetWiredRC. In the wild, it has been seen that NetWireRC is also used by APT threat actors.
sentence.3348: Netwired’s main focus is to gain unauthorized control on the victim machine, steal stored credentials, and perform keylogging activity.
sentence.3349: This malware has had multiple version updates with bug fixes and new functionality.
sentence.3350: This sample will communicate with *beltalus.ns1[.]name:8084* for further commands.
sentence.3352: *{'Domains': ['beltalus.ns1[.]name:8084'], 'Proxy Server': 'Not Configured', 'Password': b'Volve', 'Host ID': b'Loader-%Rand%', 'Mutex': b'mKsWHTbK', 'Install Path': b'-', 'Startup Name': b'-', 'ActiveX Key': b'-', 'KeyLog Dir': b'%AppData%\\Logs\_temp\\', 'Proxy Option': 'Direct connection', 'Copy executable': False, 'Delete original': False, 'Lock executable': False, 'Registry autorun': False, 'ActiveX autorun': False, 'Use a mutex': True, 'Offline keylogger': True}*
sentence.3353: The first of the two downloaded payloads is a [Metasploit Shikata Ga Nai Encoder](https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2019/10/shikata-ga-nai-encoder-still-going-strong.html) encoded shellcode capable of downloading another payload from: *r3clama[.]com/files/chrome.exe*.
sentence.3354: The shellcode downloader downloads the following payloads:
sentence.3358: The payload downloaded from *r3clama[.]com* is a Python-based malware bundled using pyinstaller.
sentence.3361: * Download, save and extract socat.zip from *https://r3clama[.]com/files/socat.zip.*
sentence.3362: * Download monero miner exe from *https://r3clama[.]com/files/services.exe* which runs and further downloads QuasarRAT.
sentence.3366: The malware next communicates with C&C server at IP '193.218.118[.]190' and port 8266, first by sending a key to the server and then waiting for .json commands.
sentence.3367: Commands supported by this malware include:
sentence.3369: Both *url* and *upload* commands are supported only for Windows OS—on any other platform these commands are ignored.
sentence.3370: Each of these commands is basically the same, and will download and save a payload from specified url.
sentence.3371: 2.The *url*  command also executes the file in addition to downloading it while the *upload* command does not.
sentence.3372: On receipt of this command, socat runs with following command line:
sentence.3374: And sends hostname+’$>’ back to C&C over socket.
sentence.3375: In short, this command provides a reverse shell on the system to the attacker through socat.
sentence.3377: Socat is an advanced multipurpose data relay tool.
sentence.3378: “socat is a relay for bidirectional data transfer between two independent data channels.
sentence.3379: or a pseudo terminal), a socket (UNIX, IP4, IP6 - raw, UDP, TCP), an SSL socket, proxy CONNECT connection, a file descriptor (stdin etc.), the GNU line editor (readline), a program, or a combination of two of these.
sentence.3382: This is again a .Net based malware.
sentence.3383: It includes a monero miner binary and all the dll dependencies required by a monero miner executable.
sentence.3384: It will drop and run the miner payload.
sentence.3385: Then, it downloads and runs an additional payload, again from pastebin.
sentence.3386: Here is the Miner Dropper sequence:

sentence.3389: Waits for idle before starting miner.
