sentence.3391: CheckActive checks if the miner process is already running, if not then it is started by StartFiles.
sentence.3393: Downloads **Quasar RAT** payload from (https://pastebin[.]com/raw/khzLqKyN) after starting miner:
sentence.3395: This miner could be the **MinerGate Silent Miner** sold on the threat actor’s malware shop.
sentence.3396: If our assumption is true, there is another possibility of that miner being backdoored, similar to an old case of [Cobian RAT](/blogs/security-research/cobian-rat-backdoored-rat), piggybacking on client malware operators to distribute his own RATs.
sentence.3398: QuasarRAT has been active since at least 2015.
sentence.3399: Quasar is an open-source project written in .Net framework and freely available to the public.
sentence.3400: Hence, this malware has become quite popular among cyber criminals.
sentence.3401: It has been used in various campaigns from mass spam campaigns to targeted attacks.
sentence.3404: The C&C address used to control the Python backdoor and socat reverse shell is historically known to host C&C servers for many other malwares.
sentence.3405: Here is list of some malware and corresponding ports used to host C&C servers in the past:
sentence.3412: We believe this campaign is run by a threat actor known by the aliases ‘Hydro’ and ‘JiiN’.
sentence.3413: The threat actor is active on forums such as hackforums[.]net since 2010 and on YouTube at least since 2007.
sentence.3414: Initially the actor was involved with game mods and cracks, and eventually moved into malware space.
sentence.3415: By the other alias *JiiN*, the threat actor runs a malware shop called *JiiN shop* at “*xmr-services[.]com*”.
sentence.3416: Based on the two aliases, we are calling this campaign and actor *HydroJiin.*
sentence.3417: We are attributing this campaign to *HydroJiin* with high confidence due to following reasons:
sentence.3418: * *JiiN shop(*Xmr-services) is used in this campaign.
sentence.3419: * *JiiN shop(*Xmr-services) sells malware tools which Hydro makes videos about.
sentence.3420: * This campaign downloads an encrypted payload from paste by user Hydro59.
sentence.3421: All of the above indicates the relation between HydroJiin, this campaign, and xmr-services.
sentence.3423: The website called “JiiN shop” is based on the username of malware developer/seller and hosted at “*xmr-services[.]com*.
sentence.3424: It is used to advertise and sell different malware products.
sentence.3425: The threat actor is using *https://shoppy[.]gg* for handling cryptocurrency payments.
sentence.3427: Malware sold on this website includes:
sentence.3428: * **Minergate silent miner** - A configurable miner tool to mine multiple cryptocurrencies on CPU or GPU hidden from the user.
sentence.3429: Comes with a builder with options for obfuscation, persistence, etc.
sentence.3430: * **Coak Crypter -** As the name implies, a packer tool to obfuscate other malware to make them undetectable.
sentence.3431: * **NiiJ Stealer -** A very basic stealer to steal passwords from popular tools like Firefox, Opera, Chrome, FileZilla, etc and send to the C&C panel.
sentence.3432: * **INK Exploit -** Claims to make malware FUD, but provides no details about the specific exploit.
sentence.3433: The infection cycle and malware payloads discussed above are just a part of an ongoing campaign.
sentence.3434: And a non-exhaustive list of malicious websites serving malwares, C&C domains is also included in the IoC section.
sentence.3440: The threat actor HydroJiin has been in the malware business for some time now.
sentence.3441: He is selling multiple malware types along with running his own campaigns.
sentence.3442: The malware payload download stats from pastebin indicate he is having decent success.
sentence.3443: SSL inspection is advisable to detect and block such threats using SSL to hide their malicious intent.
sentence.3444: We at ZScaler ThreatLabZ continue to monitor, and strive to protect our customers from, all levels of threats.

sentence.3478: Adversaries generally use Standard Application Layer Protocols for communication between malware and command and control (C&C) servers.
sentence.3479: This is for several reasons: first, malicious traffic blends in more easily with legitimate traffic on standard protocols like HTTP/S; second, companies that rely on appliances for security often don’t inspect all SSL/TLS encrypted traffic as it is extremely resource-intensive to do so.
sentence.3480: However, the massive growth of SSL attacks – [260% higher in 2020 compared to 2019](/blogs/security-research/2020-state-encrypted-attacks) – has turned many security teams’ attention to these encrypted channels.
sentence.3481: For those that do inspect their encrypted traffic, modern network security proxies, gateways, and firewalls are evolved enough to conveniently parse application protocols and strip the SSL layer to scan the underlying data.
sentence.3482: These trends have led some adversaries to turn to custom protocols.
sentence.3483: Although custom protocols for malicious communication are nothing new, almost one-third of prevalent malware families we recently analyzed support communication over non-HTTP/S protocols.
sentence.3484: Almost all of these malware families are Remote Access Trojans (RATs) and are found all over, from campaigns of mass infection to highly targeted attacks.
sentence.3485: In this article, we dissect the custom protocols used in some of the most prevalent RATs seen in recent campaigns.
sentence.3486: At the end, we share a number of signatures and Snort rules that aid in detecting these attacks.
sentence.3487: Below are statistical representations of traffic that Zscaler blocked for non-HTTP/S C&C communication, as well as the most active RAT families that we observed over a three-month period.
sentence.3488: *Fig.1: Hits of top threats communicating over non-HTTP/Sin the last quarter.*
sentence.3489: *Fig.2: Hits of top non-HTTP/S based RAT families in last quarter.*
sentence.3491: Remcos is remote access and surveillance software developed and distributed by an organization called Breaking Security.
sentence.3492: The Remcos RAT appeared in hacking forums in late 2016.
sentence.3493: Since then, it has been favored by many cyber criminals and even adopted by APT actors such as the [Gorgon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0078/) and [Elfin Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064/).
sentence.3494: Remcos is primarily delivered to victims via malicious attachments in phishing emails.
sentence.3495: Its capabilities range from logging keystrokes to executing commands, stealing credentials, and capturing microphones and webcams.
sentence.3496: RC4 key and encrypted configuration data is kept in the resource section “SETTINGS” under “RCData”.
sentence.3497: The configuration contains the C&C address, port, mutex name, and encryption key for C&C communication.
sentence.3500: Remcos communicates over non-HTTP/S channels/ports on custom protocols.
sentence.3501: The bot can be configured to communicate in plain text, which makes it fairly straightforward to detect C&C traffic.
sentence.3502: The custom protocol contains the header “[DataStart]” followed by the size of data and then followed by the exfiltrated data.
sentence.3503: *Fig.5: Data sent to C&C server in plain text.*
sentence.3504: However, in most cases, the communication is encrypted using the RC4 algorithm with a key present in the configuration.
sentence.3505: It is not possible to match signatures in encrypted binary data.
sentence.3506: Upon execution, Remcos sends system information to its C&C server, and in return the server replies with commands to execute.
sentence.3507: As this request and response is encrypted with the same symmetric key, the header “[DataStart]” will generate the same encrypted stream of bytes in place of the header for all communication generated by the executable.
sentence.3508: *Fig.6: Data sent to C&C server as RC4 encrypted.*
sentence.3509: The repeated stream pattern of 11 bytes in requests and responses—plus a combination of other heuristics such as entropy and data length limits—can be considered for flagging RC4 encrypted Remcos traffic.
sentence.3511: Crimson RAT has been favored by threat actors for targeted attacks on governments and organizations in the financial, healthcare, and space technology sectors.
sentence.3512: Crimson is typically delivered to the victim via a phishing email containing a malicious .doc file or link to a malicious executable.
sentence.3515: The NetWire RAT is a malicious tool that emerged almost a decade ago and has been updated many times since then.
sentence.3516: NetWire has been detected in various campaigns such as [Hydrojiin](/blogs/security-research/look-hydrojiin-campaign) and advanced persistent threat (APT) attacks including [SilverTerrier](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0083/) and [The White Company](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0089/).
sentence.3517: Typically, the NetWire RAT is downloaded as a second-stage payload to systems that have been compromised using other malware such as GuLoader.
sentence.3518: NetWire communicates with custom protocols over TCP and communication is encrypted with AES encryption.
sentence.3519: The initial packet sends a 32-byte seed value along with 16-byte IV value and hardcoded password specified in the binary to generate the AES key.
sentence.3520: The C&C server generates a session key for this information.
sentence.3521: *Fig.8: Data sent to C&C server as AES encrypted.*
sentence.3522: As the communication is AES encrypted, it is not possible to scan for signature patterns in communication.
sentence.3523: However, there is enough information in the initial packet to flag the traffic as NetWire C&C communication.
sentence.3525: AsyncRAT is an open-source RAT designed to remotely monitor and control other computers through a secure encrypted connection.
sentence.3526: AsyncRAT provides functionality such as keylogger, screen viewer, command execution, and many more.
sentence.3527: Because of its feature of secure communication, AsyncRAT is used for malicious motives by cybercriminals and weaponized in APT campaigns such as "[Operation Spalax](https://www.welivesecurity.com/2021/01/12/operation-spalax-targeted-malware-attacks-colombia/).
sentence.3528: AsyncRAT has been found to be delivered via various methods such as spear-phishing, malvertising, and exploit kits.
sentence.3529: AsyncRAT communicates over secure TCP channels.
sentence.3530: As the custom certificate is carried in the binary itself and matched against the C&C certificate, it is not possible to strip the TLS layer at the proxy/gateway level.
sentence.3531: *Fig.9: Server certificate having subject and issuer name as “AsyncRAT Server”*
sentence.3533: Quasar is an open-source RAT that has been observed being used maliciously by cybercriminals and APT actors including “[Gorgon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0078/)” and “[Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040/).
sentence.3534: Its features include remote desktop, keylogging, password stealing, and many more.
sentence.3535: Quasar encrypts communications using an AES algorithm with a pre-shared key hardcoded in the client binary.
sentence.3536: However, the distinctive characteristics of encrypted data packets can be leveraged to flag Quasar's AES encrypted traffic.
sentence.3537: *Fig.10: Data sent to C&C server as AES encrypted.*
sentence.3538: The distinctive first 4 bytes of the payload can be used to identify Quasar traffic.
sentence.3539: Specifically, the first 4 bytes can identify the first packet sent from the server to the client following the TCP handshake.
sentence.3540: The first 4 bytes of the TCP payload contain "40 00 00 00" which is the size of the data that follows in little endian.
sentence.3542: The Agent Tesla RAT has been very active and prevalent.
sentence.3543: Over the last couple of years, there have been huge ongoing phishing campaigns delivering Agent Tesla RAT.
sentence.3544: Agent Tesla has evolved over time, varying its behavior from campaign to campaign.
sentence.3545: Cybercriminals use this RAT to steal user credentials and spy on victims through screenshots, keyboard logging, and clipboard capturing.
sentence.3546: Credential stealing is supported across various software ranging from browsers to mail clients, VPNs, and wallets.
sentence.3547: Agent Tesla communicates and exfiltrates data to its C&C server on HTTP, FTP, SMTP, and Telegram API.
sentence.3548: All collected data is encapsulated into an HTML page, and that HTML page is sent to a C&C over one of the aforementioned protocols.
sentence.3549: For communication over FTP, the HTML page is sent as a file to an FTP C&C server.
sentence.3550: *Fig.11: Data to be sent via FTP.*
sentence.3552: For communication over SMTP, the HTML page is sent as a mail body to the C&C server.
sentence.3555: CyberGate allows an attacker to browse and manipulate files, devices, and settings on the victim's machine as well as download and execute additional malware.
sentence.3556: It also has a wide range of information-stealing abilities including browser credential theft, keylogging, screen capture, and remote enabling of webcams.
sentence.3557: The CyberGate RAT communicates on a custom protocol over TCP.
sentence.3558: CyberGate collects the info as per the command received from the C&C server, compresses data by ZLib, encrypts it by RC4 with a hardcoded key, and then sends it to the C&C server.
sentence.3559: *Fig.14: Compressed and Encrypted data sent to C&C.*
sentence.3560: To flag the CyberGate RAT traffic, a combination of data length, marker, and delimiter can be considered.
sentence.3562: Though NanoCore RAT emerged almost a decade ago, it is still one of the most prevalent RAT families, and multiple versions have appeared since then.
sentence.3563: NanoCore RAT is modular malware which comes with plugin support to expand its functionality.
sentence.3564: Basic plugins feature remote surveillance via remote desktop, monitor webcam, capture audio, etc.
sentence.3565: Additional plugins have been found to be used for cryptocurrency mining, ransomware attacks, credential stealing, and more.
sentence.3566: NanoCore RAT has been found to be delivered via phishing emails containing .doc macros that load a NanoCore binary with fileless infection techniques.
sentence.3567: NanoCore communicates on a custom protocol over TCP and uses the DES algorithm with hardcoded key and IV value to encrypt the communication between bot and its C&C server.
sentence.3568: The communication packet begins with a 4-byte data length followed by DES-encrypted data of that length.
sentence.3570: It is not possible to scan for patterns in DES-encrypted data.
sentence.3571: This results in some encrypted traffic that will be the same across all bots generated using the publicly available bot-builder.
sentence.3572: For a more generic detection, we need to check for heuristics of data length value against TCP packet size and entropy of data.
sentence.3573: Fig.16: Fix length first response from C&C server.
sentence.3575: Gh0st is an open-source RAT that has been observed being used maliciously by cybercriminals and APT actors such as “[TA459](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0062/)” and “[APT18](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0026/).".
sentence.3576: Its features include remote desktop, logging keystrokes, stealing credentials, capturing microphone and webcam, and many more.
sentence.3577: Gh0st communicates on a custom protocol over TCP.
sentence.3578: It uses a sequential byte-to-byte encryption algorithm to encrypt communication with the C&C server.
sentence.3579: Upon execution, it collects system data such as system information, version, processor description, installed antivirus, etc.
sentence.3581: Discovered almost a decade ago, njRAT, also known as Bladabindi, is the most active and prevalent remote access trojan.
sentence.3582: It allows attackers to do surveillance and control the victim's computer.
sentence.3583: njRAT is mostly found to be delivered via phishing email campaigns containing malicious Word document attachments.
sentence.3584: It is also found to be delivered by masquerading as a legitimate application installer uploaded to file-sharing services and luring victims via drive-by download campaigns.
sentence.3585: Since the leak of source code 2013, njRAT has become widely adopted by cybercriminals and APT actors including [Gorgon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0078/) and [APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096/).
sentence.3586: Some variants have been found to be communicating over standard HTTP protocol and others were found to be communicating over custom protocols over TCP.
sentence.3587: The packet begins with data length in a decimal format null-terminated string followed by command and then delimiter followed by exfiltrated data.
sentence.3588: *Fig.18: Fix length first response from C&C server.*
sentence.3589: Zscaler’s multilayered cloud security platform detects indicators at various levels.
sentence.3590: The following are the Cloud IPS (non-HTTP/S) signatures that enable detection of the above RATs:
sentence.3591: All of the above-discussed RATs are communicating on custom and encrypted protocols over TCP.
sentence.3592: When communication is encrypted, it is more difficult to scan for their signature patterns in network traffic.
sentence.3593: However, we have discussed alternative ways to flag RAT traffic based on the heuristics of encrypted data.
sentence.3594: Four properties that are common to most RAT traffic on non-HTTP/S are:
sentence.3595: Adding 4 to the little endian value of the first 4 should give the total length of TCP data.
sentence.3596: 3.The C&C server responds in the same packet format as the client.

sentence.3609: Skimmer groups are growing rapidly and targeting various e-commerce platforms using a variety of ways to remain undetected.
sentence.3610: The Zscaler ThreatLabZ research team has been tracking these skimmer groups and monitoring the techniques they're using.
sentence.3611: The latest techniques include compromising vulnerable versions of e-commerce platforms, hosting skimmer scripts on CDNs and cloud services, and using newly registered domains (NRDs) lexically close to any legitimate web service or specific e-commerce store to host malicious skimmer scripts.
sentence.3612: In this blog, we will provide an overview of the recent trends we are seeing in JavaScript skimmer attacks.
sentence.3613: Skimming is a technique by which cybercriminals steal credit card information from e-commerce sites and other internet payment portals.
sentence.3614: Threat actors exploit software vulnerabilities to gain access to a website's source code.
sentence.3615: Once they have access, they inject malicious JavaScript that allows them to exfiltrate data.
sentence.3616: Historically, the Magento platform has been the most highly targeted in skimmer attacks.
sentence.3618: The use of NRDs in skimmer attacks for hosting malicious scripts exfiltrating skimmed data provides an advantage to attackers since each NRD's lack of reputation makes it easy to evade reputation-based engines.
sentence.3619: In most attacks, newly registered domains are typosquatting for legitimate web services, such as Google ads, CDNs, Jquery, Magento, etc., as typosquatting increases the chance of remaining undetected in legitimate traffic.
sentence.3620: Recently, threat actors have most frequently utilized domains lexically close to Google and Google services, followed by domains lexically close to Jquery/ JavaScript and web analytics.
sentence.3621: ![Trend for newly registered domains lexically close to legitimate services.](/cdn-cgi/image/format=auto/sites/default/files/images/blogs/JSskimmer-2021/3.PNG)
sentence.3622: Figure 3: Trend for newly registered domains lexically close to legitimate services.
sentence.3623: Websites in the shopping category are the most common targets for skimmer attacks, but other URL categories have also fallen victim to these attacks, as shown in the following chart:
sentence.3624: **Abusing legitimate communication and analytics services in skimmer attacks**
sentence.3625: Starting last year, we've seen skimmer groups abusing legitimate communication and analytics services, such as Telegram and Google analytics, for data exfiltration.
sentence.3626: Some of these skimmer techniques can be defeated by configuring Content Security Policy (CSP).
sentence.3627: CSP is an added layer of web security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks.
sentence.3628: These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement to distribution of malware.
sentence.3629: By configuring CSP, web admins can specify domains that should be considered valid sources for scripts—though such specifications can often be bypassed by attackers abusing the Google Analytics API, which is used legitimately by a large number of websites.
sentence.3630: ThreatLabZ observed a significant spike during February and March 2021 in such attacks, where legitimate communication and analytics services are abused, but they have trailed off in recent weeks.
sentence.3631: ![Hits of skimmer groups abusing legitimate services over 90 days.](/cdn-cgi/image/format=auto/sites/default/files/images/blogs/JSskimmer-2021/5.PNG)
sentence.3632: Figure 5: Hits of skimmer groups abusing legitimate services over 90 days.
sentence.3634: Recent skimmer attacks have heavily leveraged NRDs for malicious script injection and data exfiltration, as well as the use of compromised third-party scripts or CDNs.
sentence.3635: Below are two examples of recent skimmer attacks using NRDs and CDNs to serve content to specific websites.
sentence.3636: **Case 1:** In one of the skimmer attacks, we observed two NRDs involved—one for injecting malicious skimmer code and the other for data exfiltration.
sentence.3637: These domains are lexically similar to the keywords *jquery* and *CDN* to help attacks remain undetected in legitimate traffic.
sentence.3640: The skimmer script has a Base64-encoded fake payment page and skimmed data is sent to the attacker-controlled domain.
sentence.3641: ![Data exfiltration domain and base64 encoded fake payment page.](/cdn-cgi/image/format=auto/sites/default/files/images/blogs/JSskimmer-2021/7.PNG)
sentence.3642: Figure 7: Data exfiltration domain and Base64-encoded fake payment page.
sentence.3643: Currently, both of these NRDs are resolving to the same IP 34.125.186[.]248, which hosts multiple (possible) skimmer domains lexically close to legitimate services.
sentence.3644: ![Multiple possible skimmer domains resolving to the same IP address.
sentence.3645: Figure 8: Multiple possible skimmer domains resolving to the same IP address.
sentence.3646: In the recent past, these domains resolved to the following IP addresses, each of which hosted newly registered domains lexically close to legitimate domains and possibly connected to the skimmer attacks.
sentence.3647: During our analysis of the above-mentioned IP addresses and domains, we observed that domain ajaxtracker[.]com was resolving to IP address 34.125.186[.]248 from April 26, 2021, to April 29, 2021, and during this time it was connected to the Raccoon Stealer.
sentence.3648: **Case 2**: We observed another recent chain of Magecart infections on a few German shopping websites.
sentence.3649: The malicious JavaScript that was being used can be seen below.
sentence.3652: Once the malicious JavaScript is loaded it calls a function named "Default\_Send()" as shown in the image below.
sentence.3653: ![Function to grab all the inputs provided by the victim user](/cdn-cgi/image/format=auto/sites/default/files/images/blogs/JSskimmer-2021/11.PNG)
sentence.3654: Figure 11: Function to grab all the inputs provided by the victim.
sentence.3655: The Default\_send function is responsible for collecting the URL of the infected page and grabbing all the inputs provided by the victim who is shopping on the compromised website.
sentence.3656: ![Function to send victim’s card details to attacker.](/cdn-cgi/image/format=auto/sites/default/files/images/blogs/JSskimmer-2021/12.PNG)
sentence.3657: Figure 12: Function to send victim’s card details to attacker.
sentence.3658: Once the script has collected the data, it will call the SendData function, which has the target URL to which the collected data will be uploaded.
sentence.3659: The URL is stored in Base64-encoded format in the SendData function, as displayed below.
sentence.3661: Figure 13: Base64 encoded data exfiltration domain.
sentence.3662: If we decode the Base64 URL, we find that the data was being exfiltrated to the malicious domain google-sanek[.]com.
sentence.3663: By doing a DNS lookup for the domain, we saw that the domain resolves to the IP 82.148.31[.]214, which helps us identify other domains hosted on the same IP involved with Magecart activity.
sentence.3664: The attacker serves JavaScript using legitimate-looking domains in an attempt to make the traffic look benign.
sentence.3665: Skimmer groups continue to infect e-commerce sites in large numbers and improve techniques to remain undetected.
sentence.3666: The use of newly registered domains lexically close to legitimate domains or services helps attackers evade reputation-based engines, as their domains are too new to have a low rating.
sentence.3667: Zscaler ThreatLabZ actively tracks malicious campaigns and protects customers from skimming and other types of data-stealing attacks.
